Date:  Mon, 05 Jan 2004 16:50:40 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Welcome to the Comet-Imaging Board
With the bright comets incoming hopefully, it will be necessary for
all who will image these comets to have a place to show, link, and
discuss there images. This board will act as an overflow for the
many images which will be created. It is not to stop an individual
from posting at his regular boards rather a place for the day to day
images a person might have or a newcomer who has no place to post.
Please post a link to your published images, ask questions, and give
advise. Try to keep the "back patting" and "WOWS" to a minimum as
space is for all but limited. If you image everyday and want to post
a new link every day then feel free to do so. All kinds of comet
images are welcome. Film, ccd through telescopes, cameras or any
other way you can come up with. All I ask is that the ones who know
answer the questions from those who don't and be kind---please! This
is for all comets not just the brighter T7 and Q4 and most of all ---
all Comet Imagers. If you have a problem - Come to me and I will try
to help. Remember that you have the choice of what to read and what
not to read, so exercise it. Enjoy, learn and most of all post your
images for all to see. Mike H. 

Date:  Mon, 05 Jan 2004 21:06:40 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Some images to start the group off
Just to get us started, here are my recent (past few years) comet
image collection:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/comets.htm

I've updated it to include the latest images that I've processed of
C/2002 T7 from 12/27/2003.

Dave Kodama 

Date:  Tue, 06 Jan 2004 18:35:02 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Image Documentation
Dear Group,

I have a suggestion regarding documentation of comet images. It
stems from a suggestion made by John Bortle of Comets ML. I suggest
we provide documentation in our linked images of:
1) Date/time in UTC. Specify mid-point of a long integration.
2) Image scale: Arc seconds per pixel, horizontal FOV or ruler.
3) Orientation: Arrows or text indicating North and West.

Other imaging information is of course to be included. I am always
interested in the scope, mount, camera and processing information in
images I look at.

Adding these data was a first a burden for me as I had no idea of my
images' orientation. The orientation of my images varies between
SCT, refractor and piggyback images, and also depends on which side
of the GEM the scope is on. But now, at last, I think I have it
figured out. I have a cheat sheet to remind me to rotate images 180
degrees when imaged with the scope on the west side of the mount.

The image scale is initially a bit difficult as for many it will
involve a bit astrometry to figure out how many pixels there are
between two stars of know angular separation. Fortunately it only has
to be done once for a given camera/scope combination.

I feel that documentation of the above parameters will lend a note of
professionalism to our images and make them more useful to all comet
followers. I have some examples of the documentation I use at my 26
Dec T7 Comet images
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 18:11:32 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  prova



Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 18:35:27 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  first message
A warm regard to everybody.
Am I me from little affiliate and don't I know if you will receive this message, considering that I
succeed to see your messages on the site of the ml, but I don't receive your messages... to thing
can be due?

A first thing: attachments I can be sent or are they sent you address him where the images are? Or
can the folder of the ml be used?

I have read how much written by Dennis and I am me of accord with him to 100%, following his
indications we can have a certain homogeneity in the visualization of the images.

For the discourse arcsec/pixel, without for strength to make some astrometric reduction ,
it is enough to know the dimension of the pixels, or the granularity of the film, and the focal
used, then the following equation is used:

d" = Dpix x 206265 / focal ( Dpix = dimesion of pixel in mm focal = focal of the optics)

I for example have a ccd SXV H9 with pixel from 0.00645mm and use an Apo from 600mm
this way I get : d" = 2.2"/pixel if it is used the binning he picks this value and up it multiplies
him for the binning.

Best regards
Rolando Ligustri
rolando.ligustri@tin.it
===============================
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete
Sezione Comete UAI
http://comete.uai.it/ 

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 19:13:48 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Files and Photos Section
These are active for the use of the members. I am not sure about the
attachments. This is new to me and if not set as the members would
like can be changed. At this time I beleive it is set up just as the
ml group. If someone has applied to the group but received no
notification, try posting and if it didn't go through reapply. David
and I are both working this board. I will be gone from today to
Sunday for a vacation in Tunica Mississippi to visit some old one
armed friends. Mike H. 

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 13:33:21 -0600
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  T7 Attachment Test
Hi Group,

Here is a test posting with an attachment. I had to send the message to
Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com as an email with an attachment.
I was not able to attach anything to the post created out of the groups menu page
under “Post a Message”.

Did it work????

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Dec 26 T7 comet images
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm 
Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 12:33:35 -0800
From:  "D. Kodama" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] T7 Attachment Test
Dennis,

I replied via the web interface, but after quite awhile, have not seen my
post appear, so I'm sending this (again) via the email interface...

The attachment did work for me when receiving direct email from the
server, but it's not preserved in the online archives. I don't think it
will be sent to those who subscribed as a digest either (or maybe it will
be a big block of ASCII-encoded binary).

At any rate, since viruses can be propagated via attachments, it is
probably best for attachments to be disabled for the group (I think this
can be done by myself or Mike). Images are best referred to by a link to
your own page, or if necessary to a link to our file or photo section. I
encourage using your own page as the Yahoo storage is limited and may have
to be purged occasionally.

Dave Kodama

> Hi Group,
>
> Here is a test posting with an attachment. I had to send the message to
> Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com as an email with an attachment.
> I was not able to attach anything to the post created out of the groups
> menu page under Post a Message.
>
> Did it work????
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
>
> Dec 26 T7 comet images
> http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

kodama@alumni.caltech.edu
kodama@eanet.com 

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 12:47:33 -0800
From:  "D. Kodama" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] T7 Attachment Test
More fine tuning updates...

I found the place to disable attachments and will do so. If anyone really
objects, I can re-enable it, but as I mentioned earlier, since it doesn't
get preserved in the online archive and can be a problem with viruses, I
think it's best if it is disabled.

I'm also setting the "reply-to" for all distributed email to go back to
the list rather than the person who posted a message.

Dave Kodama

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 13:10:24 -0800
From:  "D. Kodama" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Image Documentation
Dennis,

Per your suggestion, I've updated my recent T7 image with approximate
scale, orientation, and UTC:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2003/1227/4.htm

However, I don't recommend anyone use my images (especially web versions)
for serious measurements. The image above was taken on film, scanned at
2500 DPI, adjusted for contrast and color balance (based on the background
sky), cropped, and downsized (~1:4).

My interest in imaging comets is only for aesthetics and I hope that
anyone in the group is not inhibited from posting images because they
don't have the technical info to go along with the image. At least I will
be enjoying it regardless!

Dave Kodama

> Dear Group,

From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: T7 Attachment Test
Hi Dave,

Excellent decisions on both counts.

The reply-to setting is the most important one, and explains why
there have been so few messages to the group so far: The replies
never went to the group! They went to the originators. That was not
a good idea -- thanks for fixing it!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 21:57:10 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Image Documentation
Hi Dave,

That is a beautiful image, and that wide FOV could only be captured
on film. I note that the Borg refractors are showing up more and
more now in excellent images. You have tight, round stars right into
the corners and that's at a fast f/4. Quite a neat little astrograph!

I looked at the 3D but I am unable to get the 3D effect. I prefer
the 3D images that require the red/blue glasses  much easier on my
eyes!

What mount do you use?

Nice work!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 14:15:12 -0800
From:  "D. Kodama" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Image Documentation
Dennis,

Thanks. I'm using the Borg on a Losmandy G11 mount, guided by an STV
through a 3" Borg. This is actually my first image from my new (still in
progress) observatory ("Vanishing Point Observatory") on the site of the
Orange County Astronomers Anza, CA site. I do indeed like my little Borg
100ED scope for its wide field in conjunction with medium format film.
The diagonal across a 6x7 frame is 12.7 degrees, so I ought be ready for a
comet with a long tail!

As for the 3D version, I guess I'll have to research how to create the
red/blue version. The reason I don't normally like to view those is that
the color gets affected strangely. However, it'll be another good
rainy-day project to research.

Dave

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 18:21:10 -0600
From:  GUILLERMO SERRA 
Subject:  3d images
Hi Dennis, i am in comet-images group, my job is to make flip and 3d images. if you realy like to have the picture in 3d, i can make it for you and all the people in the group free. I just need to know what stars go forward and rear.
Chears,
Guillermo

Date:  Thu, 08 Jan 2004 00:41:05 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: 3d images
Hi Guillermo,

Thank you for your kind offer. You may become very busy making 3D
comet images!

Do you make the kind that requires the blue and red glasses or the
anaglyph kind like Dave posted? I like the kind that requires the
glasses because my eyes don't seem to work on the other kind.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 16:49:03 -0800
From:  "D. Kodama" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 3d images
Guillermo,

The image is already "3D" because the comet moved slightly between two
frames, so the stars should be flat and the comet raised out of the
background slightly. The image is here:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2003/1227/5-s.htm

Can you convert it to the red-blue type that requires glasses? I'd be
interested in knowing how you do that also.

Dave

> Hi Dennis, i am in comet-images group, my job is to make flip and 3d
> images. if you realy like to have the picture in 3d, i can make it for
> you and all the people in the group free. I just need to know what stars
> go forward and rear. Chears,
> Guillermo
>
> Dennis Persyk wrote:
> Hi Dave,
>
> That is a beautiful image, and that wide FOV could only be captured on
> film. I note that the Borg refractors are showing up more and more now
> in excellent images. You have tight, round stars right into the
> corners and that's at a fast f/4. Quite a neat little astrograph!
>
> I looked at the 3D but I am unable to get the 3D effect. I prefer the
> 3D images that require the red/blue glasses much easier on my eyes!
>
> What mount do you use?
>
> Nice work!
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "D. Kodama" wrote:
>> Dennis,
>>
>> Per your suggestion, I've updated my recent T7 image with
> approximate
>> scale, orientation, and UTC:
>>
>> http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2003/1227/4.htm
>>
>> However, I don't recommend anyone use my images (especially web
> versions) for serious measurements. The image above was taken on film,
> scanned at 2500 DPI, adjusted for contrast and color balance (based on
> the backgroundsky), cropped, and downsized (~1:4).
>>
>> My interest in imaging comets is only for aesthetics and I hope that
>> anyone in the group is not inhibited from posting images because
> they don't have the technical info to go along with the image. At
> least I will be enjoying it regardless!
>>
>> Dave Kodama
>>
>> > Dear Group,
>> >
>> > I have a suggestion regarding documentation of comet images. It
>> stems from a suggestion made by John Bortle of Comets ML. I
> suggest
>> > we provide documentation in our linked images of:
>> > 1) Date/time in UTC. Specify mid-point of a long integration. 2)
>> Image scale: Arc seconds per pixel, horizontal FOV or ruler. 3)
>> Orientation: Arrows or text indicating North and West.
>> >
>> > Other imaging information is of course to be included. I am
> always
>> > interested in the scope, mount, camera and processing information
> in
>> > images I look at.
>> >
>> > Adding these data was a first a burden for me as I had no idea of
> my
>> > images' orientation. The orientation of my images varies
> between SCT,
>> > refractor and piggyback images, and also depends on which side
> of the
>> > GEM the scope is on. But now, at last, I think I have it
>> > figured out. I have a cheat sheet to remind me to rotate images
> 180
>> > degrees when imaged with the scope on the west side of the mount.
>> >
>> > The image scale is initially a bit difficult as for many it will
>> involve a bit astrometry to figure out how many pixels there are
>> between two stars of know angular separation. Fortunately it only
> has
>> > to be done once for a given camera/scope combination.
>> >
>> > I feel that documentation of the above parameters will lend a
> note of
>> > professionalism to our images and make them more useful to all
> comet
>> > followers. I have some examples of the documentation I use at
> my 26
>> > Dec T7 Comet images
>> > http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
>> >
>> > Clear skies,
>> >
>> > Dennis Persyk
>> > Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
>> > Hampshire, IL
>> >
>> > Yahoo! Groups Links
>> >
>> > To visit your group on the web, go to:
>> > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/
>> >
>> > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
>> > Comet-Images-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>> >
>> > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to:
>> > http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>>
>> ---
>> kodama@a...
>> kodama@e...
>
> ---------------------------------

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2004 20:26:58 -0600
From:  GUILLERMO SERRA 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 3d images
Yes I can make a anaglyph (red/blue), I do it with a software call super3d genius.

frames, so the stars should be flat and the comet raised out of the
background slightly. The image is here:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2003/1227/5-s.htm

Can you convert it to the red-blue type that requires glasses? I'd be
interested in knowing how you do that also.

> the backgroundsky), cropped, and downsized (~1:4).

>> My interest in imaging comets is only for aesthetics and I hope that
>> anyone in the group is not inhibited from posting images because
> they don't have the technical info to go along with the image. At
> least I will be enjoying it regardless!

>> Dave Kodama
>>
>> > Dear Group,
>> >
>> > I have a suggestion regarding documentation of comet images. It
>> stems from a suggestion made by John Bortle of Comets ML. I
> suggest
>> > we provide documentation in our linked images of:
>> > 1) Date/time in UTC. Specify mid-point of a long integration. 2)
>> Image scale: Arc seconds per pixel, horizontal FOV or ruler. 3)
>> Orientation: Arrows or text indicating North and West.
>> >
>> > Other imaging information is of course to be included. I am
> always
>> > interested in the scope, mount, camera and processing information
> in
>> > images I look at.
>> >
>> > Adding these data was a first a burden for me as I had no idea of
> my
>> > images' orientation. The orientation of my images varies
> between SCT,
>> > refractor and piggyback images, and also depends on which side
> of the
>> > GEM the scope is on. But now, at last, I think I have it
>> > figured out. I have a cheat sheet to remind me to rotate images
> 180
>> > degrees when imaged with the scope on the west side of the mount.
>> >
>> > The image scale is initially a bit difficult as for many it will
>> involve a bit astrometry to figure out how many pixels there are
>> between two stars of know angular separation. Fortunately it only
> has
>> > to be done once for a given camera/scope combination.
>> >
>> > I feel that documentation of the above parameters will lend a
> note of
>> > professionalism to our images and make them more useful to all
> comet
>> > followers. I have some examples of the documentation I use at
> my 26

Date:  Thu, 08 Jan 2004 19:10:23 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] T7 Attachment Test
Hi Dennis I have regularly received the image, but after having read your mails, thing we do? Do we put her on you a site or within to a folder, or do we send her as attached? Sincerely, even if more uncomfortable, is better the first hypothesis, there are too many viruses that turn in the net!

A question to everybody, as do you do to calibrate the three files color to get at the end the correct color? I adopt two systems (for ccd with or without antoblooming) but I would like to know which system done use you?

regards
Rolando
----- Original Message -----
From: Dennis Persyk
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, January 07, 2004 8:33 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] T7 Attachment Test

Hi Group,

Here is a test posting with an attachment. I had to send the message to
Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com as an email with an attachment.
I was not able to attach anything to the post created out of the groups menu page
under �Post a Message�.

Did it work????

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 08 Jan 2004 18:51:13 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: T7 Attachment Test
Hi Rolando,

No more attached images to avoid viruses  good idea!

Images can be posted to:
1) The poster's own web site, with a link posted to the group
2) The Photos section of the group  about 550 (?) pixels wide maximum
3) The Files section of the group  larger images can go here

I work only in black and white with CCD  color is too difficult for
me.

Clear skies,

Dennis
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net

Date:  Sat, 10 Jan 2004 00:38:50 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 - Another image attempt.
Hi..

Nothing fantastic, just another attempt at this comet, getting some
practice in before the big event.

This time I managed to squeeze the F/6.3 focal reducer in with 2mm
clearance to the fork base of the telescope. I think my focus is
slightly off though. Also I tried combining several exposures - 10 x
60 second exposures. Mixed results with the stacking, I am yet to
try several programs suggested to me by people replying to my
previous post a couple of weeks back.

http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/gallery/photo/galleryComets/i
ndex.html

Oh, and a satellite in the top right of coures.

Roger.
================================================
Roger Groom rog1[AT]iinet.net.au
http://www.iinet.net.au/~rog1/
* Photography, Graphic Art & Astro Photography
* "Southern Amateur Astronomy" Info Pages.
================================================ 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 03:37:28 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2002 T7-Image-01112004(UT)
I have posted an image of this comet taken 0130UT-01112004. Actually
a mosaic composed of 3x120 each for the two images. I don't have
much info but will post this after some sleep along with the color
images which have not been processed. The tail shows lots of
different areas of thickness which could be tail disconects, I don't
know. I do know the whole image covers about 120 arc-min and I
rotated the camera to easier put the comet on two frames which put
north a little to the left of center and east to the lower left.
Click the t7-01/11/2004 Image at the link below. Thanks, Mike H.
http://hometown.aol.com/tricks46/myhomepage/photo.html?mtbrand=AOL_US 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 04:16:13 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: C/2002 T7-Image-01112004(UT)
Mike,

You are getting some top images of this comet. Keep them coming!

I ran an histogram equalisation on your recent image at it confirms a
couple of things:

1. Extreme coma diameter of about 15'.
2. Obvious disconnection type feature is visible.
3 Total length of tail is 1.5 degrees and is possibly longer - you
will have to do a 3rd frame next time :).

Terry 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 12:36:46 +0100
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: C/2002 T7-Image-01112004(UT)
Mike:

As Terry points out, the extreme diameter of C/2002 T7 outer coma
measured in your recent image is about 15', in good agreement with our
visual observations (13'). This is an obvious increase in size from
previous weeks.
But the faint tail is for me the most interesting feature in your
image, because is now difficult to observe visually in detail with
binoculars ( I've estimated about 12' of tail in Jan. 9.78 UT, very
short compared to that 1.5 degrees in the image ).

Keep on with your good and useful work.

J. J. González

-----------------------

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 15:21:12 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  T7-Color Image's-01112004(UT)
I have added a couple of images. #1 is a single frame consisting of
16 minutes of total exposure stacked on the comet. Each RGBL is 4
minutes.
The second, #2, is a two frame mosaic with each image consisting of
rgbl of 4 minutes each. 8 minutes for each image of the mosaic. The
tail structure does not show unless you increase the levels to the
point that it ruins the image. Lum will be the way to show detail
untill the tail increases, at least for me. Both images are at the
link below. Click the t7-color-01112004 link #1 & #2
Thanks, Mike H.

http://hometown.aol.com/tricks46/myhomepage/photo.html?mtbrand=AOL_US 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 10:14:16 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] T7-color-01112004(UT)
Hello Mike....
I cannot open these files; my computer is timing out before they will open and resulting in a "Page Not Available Online."
They appear to be quite large; perhaps you can reduce the effective page size of each, rather than the dpi resolution and repost them.

Thanks...I look forward to seeing them. No matter how good they are, I will NOT respond with a single "atta boy" after I have viewed them, so just assume that I have enjoyed and used them.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatory
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mt.)
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: Mike Holloway
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, January 11, 2004 9:02 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] T7-color-01112004(UT)

I have a color image which is 16 minutes of total exposure time all
stacked on the comet. 4 minutes each of RGBL. The tail structure
does not show much at all through the color filters unless you
increase the levels to the point that it destroyes the image
http://www.fototime.com/5F8EFD5D2C78307/orig.jpg
This color image is a two image mosaic. Only 8 minutes of exposure
time for each of the two images. This coveres about the same fov as
the lum image posted before but once again the tail in color is still
weak. Files are about 600mb each to preserve jpg detail.
http://www.fototime.com/272E38E020609D8/orig.jpg
Thanks, Mike H

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 16:33:50 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: T7-color-01112004(UT)
Dr. Clay. Sorry about that. The page I am saving these two
sometimes looses a lot in the publishig so I have linked the highest
resolution image possible. I'll try to link a smaller file also in
the future. In the mean time the 4 links below show the 4 images
from last night. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/392695B0D42B924/standard.jpg
http://www.fototime.com/272E38E020609D8/standard.jpg
http://www.fototime.com/5F8EFD5D2C78307/standard.jpg
http://www.fototime.com/B5483F5B643BD81/standard.jpg
For the record I don't discourge "back patting", I only ask that it
be held to a manageable level. I think everyone needs to be thanked
once in a while, Don't you?

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 17:43:18 +0100
From:  skorupa@t-online.de
Subject:  T7-color 2004-01-10 1758UT
Hello,
a small hole in the clouds made it possible to take an image of T7.

My friend Norbert used a 180mm f4 tele-lens of his downtown balcony....

You'll find the image in the "new Images" section of www.schweifstern.de

Greetings
Waldemar

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 18:05:32 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: T7-color-01112004(UT)
Hi Mike,

Of the four images, I like the B5483F5B643BD81 one best  the
negative one. It seems to show the long tail structure best of all.

Please work on giving us an image scale. I need to know if I have to
abandon imaging with my scopes and use a telephoto lens piggyback on
my next imaging session! I'm not good at astrometry, but I'm sure
Terry or Dr. Clay can tell you how many arc seconds per pixel in your
images.

I certainly don't mind expressions of thanks or appreciation for my
images, be they scientific or merely illustrative. In fact, I really
welcome feedback, good and bad points, on my images so I can improve
them.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

> For the record I don't discourge "back patting", I only ask that it
> be held to a manageable level. I think everyone needs to be
thanked once in a while, Don't you?
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "P. Clay Sherrod"

> wrote:
> > Hello Mike....
> > I cannot open these files; my computer is timing out before they
> will open and resulting in a "Page Not Available Online."
> > They appear to be quite large; perhaps you can reduce the
effective page size of each, rather than the dpi resolution and
repost them.
> >
> > Thanks...I look forward to seeing them. No matter how good they
> are, I will NOT respond with a single "atta boy" after I have
viewed them, so just assume that I have enjoyed and used them.
> >
> > Clay

Date:  Sun, 11 Jan 2004 18:12:28 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2002 T7-Image-01112004(UT)
Hi Terry,

Could you please post a protocol on using histogram equalization? It
would be a good thing to put into the Files section. I would like to
learn about the various analysis tools that can be applied to
cometary images.

Thanks.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "terryjlovejoy"
wrote:
> Mike,
>
> You are getting some top images of this comet. Keep them coming!
>
> I ran an histogram equalisation on your recent image at it confirms
a
> couple of things:
>
> 1. Extreme coma diameter of about 15'.
> 2. Obvious disconnection type feature is visible.
> 3 Total length of tail is 1.5 degrees and is possibly longer -
you
> will have to do a 3rd frame next time :).
>
> Terry

Date:  Tue, 13 Jan 2004 07:07:38 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  T7 13 Jan 2004
Images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

I was able to eek out only a 22 arc minute tail imaging through high
cirrus clouds that finally became solid overcast. After seeing Mike's
image with the long tail I was hoping for better results. The tail
is four-fold longer in tonight's image than in my Jan 1st image,
however.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Tue, 13 Jan 2004 18:53:12 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: T7 13 Jan 2004
That looks good Dennis for a seeing of 2/10. I had about the same
conditions but the weather man said better times were on the way -
now it's raining. If you start using a telephoto lense, will you use
a camera or ccd attached to it. I was thinking about attaching a
camera body to the 4" and use some film if the comet gits into the
5.5 or 6 magnitude range. Mike

Date:  Tue, 13 Jan 2004 19:45:44 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Camera Lenses was Re: T7 13 Jan 2004
Hi Mike,

I have lots of Canon 35 mm lenses from 24 mm to 300 mm and an adaptor
to my MX716 CCD camera. I even have a 12.5 mm C-mount lens that gives
a 30 degree wide FOV! The CCD sees well into the near IR, so I get a
lot of chromatic aberration  bloated stars  unless I stop down the
lens a couple of stops or use a red filter. I'm sure you can pick up
an old lens that is quite good and an adaptor for your SBIG camera.
The older lenses don't have autofocus and are a good bargain these
days.

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:
> That looks good Dennis for a seeing of 2/10. I had about the same
> conditions but the weather man said better times were on the way -
> now it's raining. If you start using a telephoto lense, will you
use a camera or ccd attached to it. I was thinking about attaching
a camera body to the 4" and use some film if the comet gits into the
> 5.5 or 6 magnitude range. Mike

Date:  Tue, 13 Jan 2004 20:57:51 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Camera Lenses was Re: T7 13 Jan 2004
Dennis. The only 35mm or film camera of any kind I have left is a
Minolta MAXXUM 5Xi. Good camera but has the 100/300 auto zoom/ auto
focus which I don't think would be of much use. Not sure how the two
comets will perform in the future so with some continued luck with
the mosaic combinations, I will stick with the 4" for now. I could
always piggyback the Minolta if things got bright enough. Mike

Subject:  Comet T7 has sprung a Leak!
This doesn't even look like the same comet from the 11th. It now has
too tails. This image is 12 minutes total exposure time with a
negative insert. It is really something. Mike

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 00:12:52 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  greetings
I am interested in sketching, photographing and observing comets.
I also created the comet observers award for the Astronomical League. You all
are welcome to try to gain the silver and/or gold awards with any of these
methods. I wanted the awards to be as fleixble as possible. I have pics of the
comets I have taken at my website. ? let me know.

My listserve newsletter serves to try to keep updated with all the events
about comets and comes out about twice weekly. It is meant also to keep updated
with those who have attained the comet awards or are working towards there
completion.

I look forward to hearing more about the groups images and observations.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA
send information to Dr.Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com) or
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com
FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) (http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm); State of
Kansas- Solar System Ambassador - JPL (Jet Propulson Lab);
7 total solar eclipses and counting 

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 08:22:17 +0100
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: Comet T7 has sprung a Leak!
Mike:

It is very interesting indeed. C/2002 T7 is now at a distance of
1.94 AU from the Sun,
and it seems that important changes are developing, needing a continuos
CCD monitoring. (
Visual observation of this double tail is now difficult ).

J. J. Gonzalez

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 15:31:46 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  Help identifying this FOV?
I may just get laughed at for this, but here goes nothing.. got to
learn somehow.

I thought I'd try shooting the area where P/2004 A1 is, just incase
I could see it. I don't seriously expect to be able to.

I don't have enough stars in my TheSky database to know if I've hit
the right area dead on. I don't understand the comet information
enough to know how fast it is moving to know if I should see any
movement over a period of 15 minutes. I don't know what the limiting
magnitude of my CCD+Telescope setup is at 60sec exposure, bin2x2.

Hence, if anyone is able to and feels like it, could they match this
FOV up to see if P/2004 should be anywhere within it?

I believe the bright rings are from Asellus Australis (SAO 98087).
Centered somewhat near (give or take a bit of backlash & pointing
innacuracy): RA:08h 45m 6.6s Dec:+18d 14' 47"

http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/1582004A1_question.jpg

Images taken ending at 15:10 14th Jan 2004 (UT).

Series of 15 x 60sec, stacked.

Roger.

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 18:50:17 +0100
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: Help identifying this FOV?
Roger:

P/2004 A1 is in your FOV ( if the ephemerides are accurate enough:
MPEC 2004-A51, ttp://cfa-www.harvard.edu/mpec/K04/K04A51.html ).

For reference I post in the Files section of this list two
non-inverted images:

- An jpg image ( C2004A1-track-15,10UT-14Jan2004-SMP8.jpg , from SkyMap
Pro 8 ) with the comet initial position at 15.10 UT ( 14 Jan 2004 ),
plus 24 hour-tracking positions for one day span. The brightest star in
this image field is Asellus Australis ( delta Cnc, 3.9 mag ), and the
dimmer are 15-16 mag stars from GSC catalog. The galaxy is IC 2392 (
14.6 mag, 54" x 42" ).

- Another deeper jpg image ( DelCnc+IC2392-RS-DSS-G8.jpg ,from Guide 8 -
Real Sky DSS ) with approximately the same field ( delta Cnc, IC 2392,
etc ).

Regards,

J. J. Gonzalez

--------------------------------

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 17:54:16 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Help identifying this FOV?
I just took a quick glance, but it looks like the Sky Map image and
Roger's image are right-left reversed. In that case the prominent
fuzzy spot at the left is the galaxy on the map and the comet might be
very faintly visible.

Dave

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 18:12:34 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  T7 Tail Evolution
I received some mail wanting to know what the difference in the tail
was. To show the difference, I have put a negative of both images on
one frame which shows the change in three days. Thought this might
help.
Thanks, Mike
Click on the "T7-3 Day Change"
http://hometown.aol.com/tricks46/myhomepage/photo.html?mtbrand=AOL_US 

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 19:16:03 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Help identifying this FOV?
I've created a quick-and-dirty overlay of Roger's image on Juan's map
(reversed to match) here:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/misc/roger.htm

It works best if you enable Javascript. Then as you move the mouse on
and off the image, the overlay will appear and disappear.

Roger, feel free to grab the files for your use if you want.

Dave 

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 23:45:24 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  Re: Help identifying this FOV?
Hi Everyone,

Thanks very much for everyone's reply's ... it's great to see I
actually did manage to get it in the FOV !

Thanks for the star map image Juan, exactly what I needed ... and
thanks to Dave for putting it together with the image.

I will take a closer look at the original images tonight (having
just woken up and having work to go to all day - don't you hate
that) .. I may be able to do a better job of stacking them to bring
out the comet's path now I know where I should be looking for the
faint little dot.

Thanks again everyone.

Roger

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 16:37:56 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  new member- old comet
Hello: just learned that this group exists and thought I would join the
party. Brought along an animation of comet Encke taken this past November
using an Mx7c through a 300 mm Nikon ED F4.5 lens. Animation is from 40
1-minute images. Hope it's not too stale. Have been imaging DSOs for some
time; but I really get off on comet images. Looking at Dennis Persyk's
posts on other boards has been quite motivating. Glad this group is here.

Clear skies.

-Mike

http://psych102-143.ucsd.edu/~Mike/encke.html 

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2004 01:32:48 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: new member- old comet

that comet myself. Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2004 01:47:15 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  T7-01/15/2004-0100UT
I was hoping to see a different look tonight and I did. The tail
which was coming off the top last night has gone or at least I
couldn't get it. The main tail is much stronger but some high thin
clouds have washed out the faint parts. A star on the south side of
the comet head gives it a lumpy look. Turning the image negative
still showed no sign of the second tail. This is a 3x120 sec exp
with a fov of 74x56 arc-min with North up. At this link, click the
T7-01/15/2004. Thanks, Mike H.
http://hometown.aol.com/tricks46/myhomepage/photo.html?mtbrand=AOL_US 

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2004 20:04:38 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] T7-01/15/2004-0100UT
I too imaged a single strong tail and looked for your earlier second extension; to 90 sec. CCD with the 0.4m, nothing but one very nice long and tapering tail. I will post an image on the ASO site later tonight.

Clay
----------------------------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
drclay@arksky.org
Arkansas Sky Observatory
10 Observatory Hill Drive, Petit Jean Mt.
MPC/cbat Obs. H41 / Petit Jean Mountain
MPC/cbat Obs. H43 / Conway
MPC/cbat Obs. H44 / Cascade Mountain
http://www.arksky.org/

I was hoping to see a different look tonight and I did. The tail
which was coming off the top last night has gone or at least I
couldn't get it. The main tail is much stronger but some high thin
clouds have washed out the faint parts. A star on the south side of
the comet head gives it a lumpy look. Turning the image negative
still showed no sign of the second tail. This is a 3x120 sec exp
with a fov of 74x56 arc-min with North up. At this link, click the
T7-01/15/2004. Thanks, Mike H.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/

b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
Comet-Images-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2004 03:58:20 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Re: Help identifying this FOV?
What is your telescope/camera setup? If you are polar mounted then
you could use something like astrometrica to perform a track and
stack on the comet itself - 3 sets of 5 images and then blink them
to see what is moving.

Cheers

David Higgins
E14
Canberra, Australia
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Roger" wrote:
> I may just get laughed at for this, but here goes nothing.. got to
> learn somehow.
>
> I thought I'd try shooting the area where P/2004 A1 is, just
incase
> I could see it. I don't seriously expect to be able to.
>
> I don't have enough stars in my TheSky database to know if I've
hit
> the right area dead on. I don't understand the comet information
> enough to know how fast it is moving to know if I should see any
> movement over a period of 15 minutes. I don't know what the
limiting
> magnitude of my CCD+Telescope setup is at 60sec exposure, bin2x2.
>
> Hence, if anyone is able to and feels like it, could they match
this
> FOV up to see if P/2004 should be anywhere within it?
>
> I believe the bright rings are from Asellus Australis (SAO 98087).
> Centered somewhat near (give or take a bit of backlash & pointing
> innacuracy): RA:08h 45m 6.6s Dec:+18d 14' 47"
>
> http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/1582004A1_question.jpg
>
> Images taken ending at 15:10 14th Jan 2004 (UT).
>
> Series of 15 x 60sec, stacked.
>
> Roger. 

Date:  Thu, 15 Jan 2004 04:30:41 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  Re: Help identifying this FOV?
Hey David,

12" LX mounted polar. ST7-ME using CCDSoft v5 and Thesky v4 (only
level II).

I tried using CCDSoft to blink the images I took, but not knowing
exactly where to look in the image, the brightness of the comet (in
the image) being unknown and all, I didn't spot it (there were plenty
of specs that moved, especially in the centre, but likely just noise).

With a better idea of the brightness & possition now I'll try
blinking them again tonight, probabbly alter the levels somewhat too.

Roger.

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2004 03:04:11 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Re: Help identifying this FOV?
Just make sure you co-add on the comet position (track and Stack)
rather than the star positions - that way you'll be adding the
signal from the comet. If the comet is around magnitude 17.5 then
you should be able to easily see the comet in a well stretched ccd
image 5 x 60 seconds. I can get to 18 with my 10" LX200GPS at f/3.4
with 5 x 60 seconds at bin 2x2 and my SX716 (Same chip dimensions
and pixel size as your ST7)

If you have a lot of noise then try a median combine.

Cheers

David

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Roger" wrote:

Date:  Sat, 17 Jan 2004 10:46:12 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  Color C/2002 T7 Linear
Hi,

I am new to this group; Dennis Persyk informed me about it and I thought I would join. I am rather new to CCD imaging (starting last
May), so most of the time I have been on the starlighxpress site learning and improving. I have a one shot color MX7c from
starlightxpress and for the most am enjoying the fun on making nice looking pictures, which of course I also like to share with anyone
who might be interested. I have always been most interested in comets, because especially if they are fainter, finding them probably
invokes a kind of hunting instinct in me and also because each shot is more or less unique. I do not know if these shots are of any
scientific interest at all, but when I find some more time, I want to learn more about how I can progress here too.

We have had nothing but bad weather the last weeks here in Austria/Europe lately, with one short exception on the 14.1.2003. Here is
a shot of T7 12 x 5 min with the MX7c at f6.3 (Celestron 8) using Starguide2000 on the coma. Each 5 min. image was then corrected
with dark frames and after synthesis to R,G,B and L, each was stacked on the coma. Then processing was done in photoshop.

I hope you like it, I uploaded it to the files section.

Mike

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/T7.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 18 Jan 2004 12:17:25 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  color t7
Nice image Mike.
It is reddish in your picture. I thought myself and others were seeing
greenish. Is the color changing?
Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA
send information to Dr.Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com) or
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com
FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) (http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm); State of
Kansas- Solar System Ambassador - JPL (Jet Propulson Lab);
7 total solar eclipses and counting

Hi Eric and Mike,

Perhaps the color balance is off a bit. I'd expect to see more of
the greenish cast from the CN (cyanogen gas) radical emission.

Date:  Sun, 18 Jan 2004 21:23:53 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: color t7
> Perhaps the color balance is off a bit. I'd expect to see more of
> the greenish cast from the CN (cyanogen gas) radical emission.

Hello Dennis,
just for the record: the CN emissions are mainly concentrated in the violet; the green-blue hue visible in most comets is originated by the diatomic Carbon (C2).
Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 00:38:22 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: color t7
Hi Giovanni ,

Thank you very much for the correction. I have lots to learn about
comets.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gvnn64\@l...\.it"
wrote:
> > Perhaps the color balance is off a bit. I'd expect to see more of
> > the greenish cast from the CN (cyanogen gas) radical emission.
>
> Hello Dennis,
> just for the record: the CN emissions are mainly concentrated in
the violet; the green-blue hue visible in most comets is originated
by the diatomic Carbon (C2).
> Cheers,
> Giovanni 

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 04:30:15 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet C/2002 T7-Images-01192002UT
I gave it a shot even though the clouds were passing overhead and a
north wind was gusting to over 30mph. I am listing the links to a
3x120 B&W and a rgbl of 8 minutes total. FOV is 74x56 arc-min with
North up. I will work on a mosaic which shows the extent of the tail
tomorrow. Thanks, Mike

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 17:45:25 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  T7 19 Jan 2004
Images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Tail 30 arc minutes long tonight by my measurements. The tail is
very low in contrast relative to the sky background and difficult (at
least for me) to image well from my VLM ~3.5 light-polluted skies. I
keep getting gradients from somewhere that interfere with bringing
out the faint tail details.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 18:59:16 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Hi Doug,

Nice animation. I've never made one in negative and you have given
me some new ideas.

The relative motion of T7 is only 1.05 arc second per minute so it is
not moving along very fast. That is good for general imaging but
means you have to acurie for a long time to get a good animation.

Clear skies,

Dennis
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 12:04:38 -0700
From:  Doug Snyder 
Subject:  C/2002 T7 'Movie'
Here is a first attempt at putting together 11 each (cropped) ST-8
frames into a .gif animation. It is 11 (unguided) x 60 sec. x 10 minute
spacing between frames, using a .25 meter LX200 at f/5. The images
were processed and converted to negative format with MaximDL. The
time period is approximately from Jan. 19, 0200 -0400 UT. As weather
permits, I'll attempt further images.

Changes in both the coma and the tail can be seen over this 2 hour
period, although it is not as high a resolution as I had hoped.

Doug 

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 13:34:52 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  C2002 T7 Linear

Hello: Just posted two comet images of T7 Linear on my site: This will link
you to a 36-minute animation.  FOV = 16.4 x 15.7 arc minutes  (should download
pretty fast as it's only a 1.3MB file):

http://psych102-143.ucsd.edu/~Mike/T7_anim36.GIF

This will link you to a color image. Larger FOV; composite of 25 unguided
1-min
images:

http://psych102-143.ucsd.edu/~Mike/T7Linear.JPG

Imaged Sat eve from our dark sky site in the Ansa Borrego Desert, east of San
Diego. Temp at the time was 28 degrees F. Imaged using a Starlight Mx7c at
prime focus through an 8" SCT 800 mm fl, F3.9 mounted on a Losmandy G-11.
These were unguided images.

Enjoy/Coments welcome.

-Mike 

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 21:54:50 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  T7-2frame-negative
This is a 2-frame mosaic from 01/19/2004. Shows the extent of the
tail under less than good conditions. Each of the two frames is a
combination of 3x120 images. Looks like tonight will be the best
viewing for this area so I hope to compair with last nights images.
I am still hoping to find that outburst again. Thanks, Mike
http://www.fototime.com/07A8566B2DD3CD4/orig.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 14:59:17 -0700
From:  Doug Snyder 
Subject:  Comet Movie Info
Other information that should have accompanied my first posting about the
comet 'movie'.

North is up, East is left.
The FOV for those cropped images is 17' x 13' (arcminutes).
The full frame, uncropped, was about 33' x 22'. The image scale is 2.58
arcseconds per pixel.
The rate of motion for the comet is about 1.05 arcminutes per hour, so it
moved about 2 arcminutes during the 2 hour period.

Doug 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 02:47:36 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  2Comets from Tonight
I once again put T7 on the chip to look for differences in the tail
from last night. Once again it is totally different. Last night it
was a smooth arching streak and tonight it is a twisted waving mess.
http://www.fototime.com/BB6430F43926B1A/orig.jpg
While in the area I imaged 43P. Nice comet and showing a decent tail
for a 13+ mag. comet.
http://www.fototime.com/DEC179EEE3B9A4B/orig.jpg
I have got to check guide and my images to find out what the curley
spots are in the bottom center of the 43P image. Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2004 19:14:38 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2Comets from Tonight
Mike - Thanks for posting these images.  It's quite a study to see how T7 is
changing.  Perhaps it's melting?  Will 43P emerge as a showpiece in the near
future?  Also, I would like to have a little information on your set-up.  Can
you send a link to your site or post imaging paramaters.  Thanks.

-Mike

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 17:39:23 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 2Comets from Tonight
Hello Michael. It is good to have you posting at this board. As far
as my setup goes, I am, at this time, using a 4" Tak. FSQ106 at F5.3
and a ST2000 CCD. The brighter comets need the bigger FOV this gives
me. Normally I would use my 10 F6.3 SCT but I am now looking for the
different tail structure the FSQ gives with a 74x56 arc-min field.
As far as comet 43P/Wolf-Harrington , I don't think that it will
improve much over what it is now although those in the southern skys
could get a little better view over the next few months. I hope that
the members here will try and image the faint comets as well as the
brighter ones. Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 18:20:16 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  T7 Getting Brighter and Lower
I visited Seiichi Yoshida's comet web site and looked up T7's
magnitude chart:

http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/2002T7/2002T7.html

Seiichi-san shows T7 brightening to magnitude 1.5 or so in the coming
months. I was all excited.

Then I checked out the position of T7 for imaging at magnitude 1.5 in
SkyMap Pro and discovered it would be below the horizon. Now I was
disappointed.

It really should not come as a surprise as T7 is well past the
meridian now at astronomical twilight. Here's what is in store for
imaging T7 at the onset of darkness  astronomical twilight  in
Northern Illinois.

Jan 20 1831 local time m = 7.9 elevation = 56 degrees
Feb 20 1906 local time m = 6.9 elevation = 20 degrees

So in one month T7 brightens by a whole magnitude but drops down to
just 20 degrees above the horizon. At 20 degrees I am imaging
through a lot more atmosphere and there is a lot more sky glow from
neighboring cities. Overall I think the brightening will overpower
the other two effects, but I won't have the opportunity to stack an
hour's worth of images any more. After one hour T7 sinks to 9
degrees off the horizon.

I like Mike H's call to image other dimmer comets. We really have no
choice as T7 is sinking fast.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Latest T7 images
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 18:40:54 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  t7's Tail Structure from 01202004
I had a chance to work on the image of T7 from 01/20/2004. It shows
what looks to me to be a twisting or rolling. Anyway you can look for
yourself and decide on what you see - or not. I hope to put the
color info together tonight. Thanks, Mike
Go to the link below and click the t7-01/20/2004 Negative link.

http://hometown.aol.com/tricks46/myhomepage/photo.html?mtbrand=AOL_US

Mike

<<
Message: 1
Date: Sat, 17 Jan 2004 10:46:12 -0000
From: "androsc2003"
Subject: Color C/2002 T7 Linear

Hi,

I am new to this group; Dennis Persyk informed me about it and I thought I
would join. I am rather new to CCD imaging (starting last
May), so most of the time I have been on the starlighxpress site learning and
improving. I have a one shot color MX7c from
starlightxpress and for the most am enjoying the fun on making nice looking
pictures, which of course I also like to share with anyone
who might be interested. I have always been most interested in comets,
because especially if they are fainter, finding them probably
invokes a kind of hunting instinct in me and also because each shot is more
or less unique. I do not know if these shots are of any
scientific interest at all, but when I find some more time, I want to learn
more about how I can progress here too.

We have had nothing but bad weather the last weeks here in Austria/Europe
lately, with one short exception on the 14.1.2003. Here is
a shot of T7 12 x 5 min with the MX7c at f6.3 (Celestron 8) using
Starguide2000 on the coma. Each 5 min. image was then corrected
with dark frames and after synthesis to R,G,B and L, each was stacked on the
coma. Then processing was done in photoshop.

I hope you like it, I uploaded it to the files section.

Mike

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/T7.jpg

>>

least for me) to image well from my VLM ~3.5 light-polluted skies. I

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 19:59:37 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: t7's Tail Structure from 01202004
Hi Mike,

You have captured a lot of detail in the tail in what I assume is
just a single image as I don't see trailed stars.

The tail near the comet head is about 20% above the background.
Towards the end the difference is only about 6% and things get pretty
noisy. If you stacked a dozen or so I think you would have more tail
detail.

I hope you will supply us with a little more data on your images so
we can make some comparisons and know what to expect when we image.
Camera, scope and image acquisition times would be appreciated. You
know all that stuff but we don't.

Thanks for moderating a great group!

Clear skies,

Dennis
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 20:24:29 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: t7's Tail Structure from 01202004
Dennis. This image is a total of 3x120 second exposures. It was
taken with a 4" Refractor @ F5.3 and an ST2000 ccd which gives a FOV
of approx 74x56 arc min. All images were stacked on the stars not
the comet. I had 6x120 sec images but gained no more detail than
with 3. I am having, like you, a gradient problem on the east side
of my images the past few nights so Hopefully some new flatts are in
order. In this image the camera was rotated a bit so north is not
directly up but instead to the left of center. The images were
aquired in CcdSoftV5 and final processing was done in Photoshop7.
Hope that helps. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 21:58:07 +0100
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: 2 Comets from Tonight - Imaging faint comets.
About faint ones:

Although my main interest is visual observation, I'm also a
long-time photographer - imager ( black & white in the sixties, digital
now ). So I agree completely with Mike:

" I hope that the members here will try and image the faint comets as
well as the brighter ones. "

The good images of bright comets like C/2002 T7 posted here (
previously in Comets-ml ) and in other pages are both beautiful and
useful. In the same "beautiful and useful" way, faint comets are not
only objects for astrometric purposes ( CCD imagers make a great work in
this area ): several of them are also an interesting subject matter for
a photographer's mind.

So, try more faint comets like 43P/Wolf-Harrington and the others
that will brighten in the future: C/2003 H1 ( now ~13th magnitude ), ...

( a good site for that information is Seiichi Yoshida's Home Page:
http://www.aerith.net/index.html )

J. J. Gonzalez

P.S.:
SPECIALLY USEFUL is the image DATE / TIME in UT, as some members had
emphasized.

-------------------------

From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet T7-color from 01/20/2004
This is a combination of 1x120sec each - RED GR BL and in Photoshop I
added 2x120 sec lum. I has surprised to see the blue on the frenges
but after looking at the raw image I realized that last night it was
stronger. Image taken with a 4" refractor at F5.3 and st2000 ccd.
FOV is app. 65x48 arc-min and comes complete with man made streak.
Still I like the way the color has progressed and hope the blue
continues to grow. File is 380kb. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/90822340A510DFE/orig.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jan 2004 22:41:04 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: t7's Tail Structure from 01202004
Hi Mike,

Thanks for the info. Probably would be better to append it to the
image or put it in a caption along with the image when you first put
it up.

That gradient to the east is driving me nuts. I think it is just
normal sky glow that is interfering with bringing out the very faint
tail structure. I can see that the tail is probably much longer than
my 30 arc minutes but beyond that it just gets lost in the noise.

I made up a cardboard cylinder that fits over the refractor. It has
about 6 layers of waxed paper taped on the end. I hope to use it to
take flats by pointing the scope at the observatory wall and shining
a light on the wall. That may help.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Wed, 21 Jan 2004 19:00:17 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Processing T7s Tail
Here is my standard technique for processing a comet images:

1) Co-register images by aligning on the comet nucleus
2) Combine registered images with Adaptive Add
3) Histogram stretch
4) Form negative
5) Further stretch of negative as required

Adaptive Add in ImagesPlus performs a linear addition until a pixel
nears saturation, and then logarithmically compresses it. It seems to
work better than Average for me. I sometimes use Median combine to
reduce the effect of star trailing, but this produces a much nosier
image.

My problem is that the T7's tail signal-to-noise ratio does not seem
to improve with stacking more images, and I don't understand why.
Last night I took a sequence of 9 images of 6 minutes each. I
achieve about the same image quality in the tail processing one image
as I do with a stack of 9.

I have considered the possibility that the tail is actually changing
over a time period of minutes, but this seems unlikely to me because
such changes would require large spatial displacements, of the order
of tens of arc seconds.

Any ideas why stacking doesn't work at present on T7's tail?

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

19 Jan T7 images
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm 

Date:  Wed, 21 Jan 2004 19:31:31 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: Processing T7s Tail
Denis,

Not sure if this helps but I make sure my sub-exposures have no
gradients first and that the background level is the same for all
images. For this I use IRIS. I always try to get the best possible
flat.

Regards,
Terry 

Date:  Wed, 21 Jan 2004 19:32:00 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  Color T7 reprocessed
Hi,

I reprocessed my image from the 14th by giving it more saturation,
reducing the red and adding more contrast. Now I think the colors are
more as they should be - thanks to your comments. Getting good color
balance with the one shot MX7c is not all that easy. I have to do a
lot by "feeling". What do you think of it now?

Mike

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/T7_3.jpg

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 03:36:49 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Color T7 reprocessed
Hi Mike,

Big improvement. The tail looks longer now. It is uncanny how we can
go back to an image and improve it after spending hours working on it
initially. I could never get the hang of color processing when I was
using a borrowed MX7C which is why I got an MX716. You seem to have
figured it out.

Don't forget to add an image scale so we can see how long the tail is.

Dennis

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 03:42:43 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet T7 from 01222002 - 0130UT
This is a mosaic of 4 images. Each one is 74x56 arc-min but the
final image was croped to save space. Each of the 4 is a composit of
3x120 sec subframes. It was all put together in Photoshop. I am
not sure yet of the exact area covered but North is up and east /
west is approx. 130 arc-min across. There is also a negative with
false color added to try and gain as much tail as possible. I was
hoping for more to show but maybe next time. Images with a 4"
refractor and ST2000ccd. Thanks, Mike
http://www.fototime.com/3B5DF7456F50991/orig.jpg
False Negative
http://www.fototime.com/61BE9EA7AA18434/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 03:49:39 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C2002T7 as of 2004.01.21
Extraordinary image, Juan! You must have very dark skies, good
equipment and excellent technique to bring out so much detail in the
tail. You are not using very long exposures either, as the stars are
not trailed.

Thank you for sharing the image with us. I hope you will pass along
some of your techniques to us so we can improve our images.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 07:30:10 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /T6-ngc2261.jpg
Uploaded by : aletti_a
Description : T6-NGC2261_17-01-2004

You can access this file at the URL

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/T6-ngc2261.jpg

aletti_a 

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 08:43:31 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz 
Subject:  Re: C2002T7 as of 2004.01.21
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
wrote:
> Extraordinary image, Juan! You must have very dark skies, good
> equipment and excellent technique to bring out so much detail in
the
> tail. You are not using very long exposures either, as the stars
are
> not trailed.
>
> Thank you for sharing the image with us. I hope you will pass
along
> some of your techniques to us so we can improve our images.
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis
Thanks very much Dennis,

For those of you who want to know the details, I took 4 series of 7
images 60 seconds each, image calibration was done as usual with
flats and darks, then I tracked and stacked the images on the comet's
movement with astrometrica, then I opened the stacks in astroart and
exported them, log scaled, as jpg files. I then used photoshop to
paste them in a big 4 layered file, the alignment of individual
layers was acomplished by setting the opacity of the layer to 50% and
dragging it until visuall match.

Finally the title was added and 2003 was written instead of 2004,
which is now corrected in my web site.

If you need any further detail, please don't hesitate contacting me.

Juan 

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 02:44:34 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet T7 from 01222002 - 0130UT
Cannot resist, Mike....this is showing the finest detail that I have seen to date within the tail immediately out of the coma; beautiful shot ["atta-boy!"]

Clay

Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
drclay@arksky.org
Arkansas Sky Observatory
10 Observatory Hill Drive, Petit Jean Mt.
MPC/cbat Obs. H41 / Petit Jean Mountain
MPC/cbat Obs. H43 / Conway
MPC/cbat Obs. H44 / Cascade Mountain
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: Mike Holloway
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, January 21, 2004 9:42 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet T7 from 01222002 - 0130UT

This is a mosaic of 4 images. Each one is 74x56 arc-min but the
final image was croped to save space. Each of the 4 is a composit of
3x120 sec subframes. It was all put together in Photoshop. I am
not sure yet of the exact area covered but North is up and east /
west is approx. 130 arc-min across. There is also a negative with
false color added to try and gain as much tail as possible. I was
hoping for more to show but maybe next time. Images with a 4"
refractor and ST2000ccd. Thanks, Mike
http://www.fototime.com/3B5DF7456F50991/orig.jpg
False Negative
http://www.fototime.com/61BE9EA7AA18434/orig.jpg

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 16:01:06 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4's strange tail - actually 3 tails
Hello,

I have updated my webpage with a new Q4 image from January 22,
showing some strange tail structure. Apologise for the noisy image
but I had to maximise contrast to show the faint tails.

I have drawn a PA direction marker on the image and the primary ion
tail is visible along PA 130. The tail at PA 95 could be dust, but
the tail that starts at PA 70 might be a gas tail feature, judging by
the contorted appearance.

Visually, the comet is doing well and I estimated magnitude 8.8 in
15x70 Binoculars tonight.

Terry Lovejoy
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

much to look fordward to.
One more thing. Please keep the dimmer comets coming. Changes of
these are just as exciting and valuable.

done by a handfull of people in the world and personally I think

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 18:28:23 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: All Comet Images
Hi Mike,

Thanks for the words of encouragement and for moderating a rapidly
growing and very friendly international group. It is very exciting
for me to see comet images from both hemispheres taken with different
equipment.

I took your advice and the other night and I imaged 43P Wolf-
Harrington. It is about magnitude 12.4 and looks very impressive with
its obvious tail amongst a dense star field of little points of
light.

Keep those comet images coming!

Clear skies,

Dennis
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 20:34:03 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  Re: Color T7 reprocessed
Hi Dennis,

thank you! I added a scale bar to my image; hope it is correct, since
I did this for the first time. I printed a DSS image of the area in
30 x 30 min., measured the distance between the two brightest stars
that can be seen in my image and the width of the DSS image. The two
brightest stars are approx. 11.6 min. apart. This I could then relate
to my own image. Is there a better way of doing this?

Mike

P.S.: Juan and Mike H.: great images!

Date:  Fri, 23 Jan 2004 03:29:34 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Another T7 Mosaic
Images from 01/23/2004 0145UT. Image is 4 part with each frame
consisting of 5x120 sec images. Total for the image is 40 minutes.
North is up and the East/West size is about 130 arc-min.
http://www.fototime.com/CA518AECCFED24A/orig.jpg
Also a negative to show extent of the tail which splits to the left
(east) end.
http://www.fototime.com/A4AA48995369566/orig.jpg
Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 19:42:47 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Another T7 Mosaic
Wonderful images Mike. These depict the longest tail I've seen yet. One thing
I've learned about imaging this particular comet is that one needs a arc
sec/pixel resolution near 1.0 to bring out the tail. My images have a
resolution of 2.3 arc sec/pixel and even with comparable integration times,
the
tail is too diffuse. I don't recall from previous posts what your imaging
resolution is? Thanks for posting.

-Mike

Date:  Fri, 23 Jan 2004 04:13:39 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Color T7 reprocessed
Hi Mike A,

That is pretty much the technique I use with my SCT where the focal
length varies with the backfocus distance. For my refractor I just
use Ron Wodaski's CDD calculator to determine image scale. It has a
whole bunch of cameras and scopes and you just pick your
combination. I do have to be careful as I usually resize my images
smaller for use on my website.

There are many group members who are skilled at astrometry and they
could probably check your calculations for you.

The scale bar on your image looks good. On my monitor it is 15 mm
long, so it was easy for me to just hold up a ruler and determine
that you had imaged about a 10 arc minute tail.

I have been using MaximDL to make my rulers and it is pretty easy. I
just specify how many pixels per ruler length and whether I want a
black or white ruler. I have also used Adobe PhotoDeluxe but Maxim
is easier (but more expensive!).

Clear skies,

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "androsc2003"
wrote:
> Hi Dennis,
>
> thank you! I added a scale bar to my image; hope it is correct,
since I did this for the first time. I printed a DSS image of the
area in 30 x 30 min., measured the distance between the two brightest
stars that can be seen in my image and the width of the DSS image.
The two brightest stars are approx. 11.6 min. apart. This I could
then relate to my own image. Is there a better way of doing this?
>
> Mike
>
> P.S.: Juan and Mike H.: great images!
> 

Date:  Fri, 23 Jan 2004 04:27:05 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Another T7 Mosaic
Hi Mike H,

Outstanding images, Mike! The tail detail is exquisite, especially
in the negative. The bifurcated (two-pronged) structure is now
clearly evident. Very nice work.

I held a ruler up to my monitor and measured 275 mm = 130 arc
minutes. The tail measured about 220 mm, starting at the left edge
of the head. That puts the tail length at 104 arc minutes, or 1.7
degrees.

Clear skies,

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:

Date:  Fri, 23 Jan 2004 04:46:05 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Another T7 Mosaic
Hi Mike C,

Sure are a lot of Mikes in the comet imaging business these days.

I have been torn between imaging at 3.25 arc seconds per pixel binned
1x1 or 6.5 arc seconds per pixel binned 2x2, with four times the
sensitivity. In the observatory I like the 1x1 images more with just
a quick peek at the unprocessed versions, but I have not made a
careful comparison yet.

My images also all have a very diffuse, low-contrast tails, but I
attribute that to poor signal-to-noise ratio  the tail is just not
very bright.

I believe Mike H is using an FSQ106 and SBIG ST2000. According to
Ron Wodaski's CCD calculator, that is 2.88 arc seconds per pixel,
pretty much what I use.

Do you have any examples of different resolution images to illustrate
your preference for the higher resolution? My transparency varies so
much from night to night that I have not been able to make a good
comparison yet.

Clear skies,

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Michael Caligiuri

comparable integration times,
> the tail is too diffuse. I don't recall from previous posts what
your imaging resolution is? Thanks for posting.

> -Mike

Date:  Thu, 22 Jan 2004 22:41:25 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Another T7 Mosaic
Dennis: You must be correct about Mike H's resolution of 2.88. The level of
detail in "de tail" given that modest resolution is a testimony of what sharp
focus and dark skies will produce. When I get the chance I may take your
advice and experiment with different focal lengths to see if resolution is more
important than sky conditions in bringing out low contrast information. Then
again, Mike may be a magician when it comes to image processing. All the
same, yours and Mike's images have been a joy to view.

-Mike C

Date:  Fri, 23 Jan 2004 13:40:13 +0100
From:  St=?ISO-8859-1?B?6Q==?=phane GARRO 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Larson-Sekanina Filter  was Re: New file
Hello,

> Thank you for the link to the Larson-Sekanina filtered image. I have
> that filter in AstroArt but I have not yet learned how to apply it.
> I received a Babel Fish translation of an Italian paper from a member
> of Comets-ML but it did not help me much. If you could offer some
> tips in using and interpreting the filter I would appreciate it. I
> have not found any references to its use in English.
>

Dennis,

The principe of this filter is to eliminate the coma if it is of same
(radial decreasing) contrast so it enhances the contrast of any structure
present within the coma. For this, each pixel intensity if recomputed by
substracting the mean value obtained with two nearby pixels. These pixels
are taken:
* at the same PA but different distances from the comet-center
---> parameter "dr"
* or at the same distance from the comet-center but at different PA
---> parameter dteta

Of course, you can combine both parameters.
Mathematically, the image is transformed by a formula (in polar
coordinates):

I'(r,teta) = I(r,teta) - 0,5 * ( I(r-dr,teta-dteta) + I(r+dr, teta+dteta) )

Of course, the software has to manage the rectangular (x,y) to polar
coordinates (r,teta).

Try several values for both parameters :

dr (in pixels) is useful for showing structures with circular symetry (like
halos for example)

dteta (in degrees) is very powerful for showing radial structures (like
jets)

In practice, I find the second parameter is the most useful, I use typical
values of 10 to 20 degrees.

With smaller values, stuctures often don't emerge from the noisy background,
larger values are useful for enhancing tail detection but you also increase
the risk of merging structures one with each-others.

Hope this can help !

I also tried such analysis on C/2002 T7 images taken on january 21. An
interesting structure can be seen towards south-east (PA about 130 deg), but
due to bad weather I haven't enough images to detect any rotation... Weather
in France is unfortunately very bad, and observations very scarce.

C/2002 T7 is very interesting now but unfortunately it will be no more
visible for me next lunation, too low in the evening sky.

Best observations to everybody !

Stephane 

Date:  Sat, 24 Jan 2004 00:04:46 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  T7 again
Hi,

tonight I got in another image of T7 (12 x 5 min., MX7c with C8 at
f6.3). 1 h was the most I could get because it was below -15 °C and I
started to get worried about my toes...I still could not get enough
tail-detail. This would have needed probably double the amount of
time because it is so faint and the MX7c is not so sensitive with
starguide2000 running.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/linear.jpg

Mike 

Date:  Sat, 24 Jan 2004 08:51:34 +0100

Date:  Sat, 24 Jan 2004 19:33:18 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  43P Wolf-Harrington
Taking up Mike H's suggestion, I have imaged a much dimmer comet. My
images of 43P Wolf-Harrington are found at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Max Wolf (Königstuhl Observatory, Heidelberg, Germany) discovered
this comet photographically in December, 1924. The P designates a
periodic, or reoccurring, comet. It returns every 6.46 years. The
magnitude is currently 12.5 .

I think it looks rather austere with its obvious tail and large coma
amongst a lonely star field.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2004 09:08:53 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  wolf -harr
Dennis
Thanks for posting another picture of WH. I guess I need to take another
picture of it and see if I can find this time (since last photographing it with my
telescope) to see the noticeable coma.
Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA
FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) (http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm); State of
Kansas- Solar System Ambassador - JPL (Jet Propulson Lab);
7 total solar eclipses and counting

Max Wolf (Königstuhl Observatory, Heidelberg, Germany) discovered

this comet photographically in December, 1924. The P designates a

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2004 19:09:10 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  T7 01/24/2004
I have been working on the information from the 24th for a couple of
days off and on. I started to simply discard it but kept trying
different process to salvage bad focus and rapdly changing
temperatures before the storms moved in. I ended with this single
74x56 arc-min image. It is 5x120 sec exp with north up taken with
the 4" @ F5.3 and ST2K ccd. I wish I had the color but I didn't take
any. Thanks, Mike
http://www.fototime.com/E56523B434817C3/orig.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 26 Jan 2004 23:49:57 +1030
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  comet  image update Jan 23rd 2004
Hello all,

Please find a comet image update on my website at:

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

C/2001 Q4 NEAT CCD image on January 23rd 2004.
8x15 second exposures, C11 telescope operating at f/3.3 and starlight
express MX7c imager. Field Of View 12 arc minutes.

C/2003 H1 LINEAR CCD image on January 23rd 2004.
10x15 second exposures, C11 telescope operating at f/3.3 and starlight
express MX7c imager.

Cheers,

Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Mon, 26 Jan 2004 14:11:48 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: comet  image update Jan 23rd 2004
Hello Michael,

Thanks for the Southern Hemisphere images -- very nice. I also like
your web site  very professional looking. It is interesting to see
comets that are below the horizon here.

I also have tried imaging with my C-11 and Meade 3.3 FR and the
result is serious vignetting  well over 50% edge fall off on the
MX716. The coma is also quite severe. How do you have the FR and
camera rigged up and what FR are you using? I would love to image at
f/3.3 with my C-11!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

43P Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Mattiazzo"
wrote:
> Hello all,
>
> Please find a comet image update on my website at:
>
> http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/
>
> C/2001 Q4 NEAT CCD image on January 23rd 2004.
> 8x15 second exposures, C11 telescope operating at f/3.3 and
starlight express MX7c imager. Field Of View 12 arc minutes.
>
> C/2003 H1 LINEAR CCD image on January 23rd 2004.
> 10x15 second exposures, C11 telescope operating at f/3.3 and
starlight express MX7c imager.
>
> Cheers,
>
> Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Mon, 26 Jan 2004 07:41:44 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet  image update Jan 23rd 2004
Michael -- I enjoyed navigating around your site. Particularly appreciated the
light curve you are working on. Plenty of useful data and nice images from the
Southern Hemisphere. There a some wonderful comets that we in the North
miss. Thanks for posting.

-Mike C.
