Date:  Mon, 26 Jan 2004 19:34:58 +0100
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: comet  image update Jan 23rd 2004
Michael,

Nice images. Thanks specially for posting the C/2003 H1 one. After
my Jan. 20th visual m1 estimate ( m1 = 13.3 ), and knowing yours ( Jan
23th, m1 = 12.8 ), is good to see this faint comet in such good "health"
( although fainter than ephemeris predictions ).

J. J. Gonzalez

> express MX7c imager. Field Of View 12 arc minutes.
>
> C/2003 H1 LINEAR CCD image on January 23rd 2004.

>
> express MX7c imager.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 00:09:54 +1030
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Re:comet image update

Hi Dennis,

Yes the C11 with Meade 3.3 reducer does produce edge distortion but the FOV
is a reasonable 24'x18' with my MX7c.
I crop the image down to about 15' to remove the distortion.
The benefit of f3.3 is greater detail in a much shorter exposure time, plus
it's easier to focus. I seldom use my f/6.3 FR.
A well collimated telescope is also important. Coma with my setup doesn't
appear to be a major problem.
I'm also currently imaging using an altazimuth mount. Wait till it's on an
equatorial setup!

cheers,
Michael

> Message: 4
> Date: Mon, 26 Jan 2004 14:11:48 -0000
> From: "Dennis Persyk"
> Subject: Re: comet image update Jan 23rd 2004
>
> Hello Michael,
>

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2004 14:48:57 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 & Comparison
Hi everyone,

http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/gallery/photo/galleryComets/i
ndex.html

Some more images of C/2001 Q4. It was tough imaging last night but I
was determined to get something so have add another image to the
gallery. The wind was very strong and gusty.

Of interest is a comparison image I have also added, comparing my
image from Dec 30th to last night's (26th Jan). I may be incorrect
in my interpretation as the image specifications are not equal but
it looks like the tail has become quite a bit wider, splitting more
distinctly into two tails. Is it normal for a comet to do this as it
approaches the sun? I see posts in the recent thread re C/2001 Q4
about the two tails but that still leaves me wondering about it
widenning out as it appears to have.

Also are there programs which will show where comets are in relation
to earth and the sun at a specific time? (top-down view style). This
would be really helpful in learning the phases of a comet's life
with respect to how it appears.

Thanks,
Roger. 

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2004 17:20:31 -0000
From:  Johannes Schedler 
Subject:  Linear T7 image update Jan 22
Had some delay in processing my comet image from last Thursday, the
first light for the new STL camera. The tail is quite extended,
especially on the inverse image:
http://panther-observatory.com/comets.htm#13

Johannes 

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2004 17:45:41 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 & Comparison
Hi Roger,

It is fascinating to note the progress of Q4 over a short period of
time. May I suggest that you orient the images all the same way 
the refractor and SCT images are mirrored and the tail is pointing a
different way. That is disconcerting to me when comparing images.

For visualizing comet progression along its orbit, I like
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/Astronomy/OrbitViewer/index.jsp
and
http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/orbits/

I think they both use the same application. I have the 3D orbit
representation pasted into my current New Images page for 43P Wolf-
Harrington if you want to see what it looks like
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Keep us posted on the progress of Q4!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2004 19:26:00 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Linear T7 image update Jan 22
Greetings Johannes, and welcome to the group.

It is a good thing that you have acquired the large chip CCD. The
tail is easily 36 arc minutes long in your negative image. That large
chip will be needed as the tail lengthens. Keep us posted!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2004 15:39:48 -0800
From:  "Michael P. Caligiuri, Ph.D." 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Linear T7 image update Jan 22
Johannes -- Great web page. It's so well organized; scrolling down helps
you appreciate the changes these comets undergo from month to month. Your
images are very fine indeed. I only wish you had a link on your page to
your equipment, OTA, cameras guiding systems, etc. The B/W contrast also
adds information not apparent from most other web sites. Keep up the
great work.

-Mike

Date:  Tue, 27 Jan 2004 19:40:21 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Linear T7 image update Jan 22
Howie: On the comet page of my web site I have an animation of 2P/Encke along
with a rather detailed description of the processes involved:
http://psych102-143.ucsd.edu/~Mike/mx7c.php Others may have used simpler
approaches, but this will give you an idea of what's involved.

-Mike C.

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 02:59:52 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet T7-01/28/2004-0200UT
The comet is once again showing a tail disconnect or some kind of
disruption. It appears the second tail which I imaged a couple of
weeks ago is showing or maybe not this but something else. It is a
mess at this time. I am posting two images. The first is a 74x56
arc-min image of 5x120 sec frames.
http://www.fototime.com/DA09FD56B9AEE48/orig.jpg

The second is a mosaic negative of 4 frames croped down to approx.
130 arc min. each of the 4 frames is composed of 5x120 sec sub
frames combined in Photoshop7. There is a small version
http://www.fototime.com/C284E1AFF913C13/standard.jpg

Or the full size which is almost 1 mb but nice to look at for
detail. All images taken with the 4" and ST2k CCD
http://www.fototime.com/C284E1AFF913C13/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 05:05:59 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Comet T7-01/28/2004-0200UT
Hi Mike,

You have captured a very interesting change all right!
Congratulations. The sky cleared in time for me to image T7 tonight
but between the moon and 7 F (-14 C) temperature, I decided to stay
in the warm house. I'm glad you braved the moon and cold to image
that very interesting tail structure.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Comet 43P images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 06:56:06 -0000
From:  Johannes Schedler 
Subject:  Re: Linear T7 image update Jan 22
Howie,

ISO800 just means the sensitivity setting of the D_SLR.
No film at all.

Movies are done with the Adobe Imageready program.

Johannes

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 10:49:10 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Re: Comet T7-01/28/2004-0200UT
Damn Mike, you're getting some brilliant images.

The disruptions looks very similar to an image of a tail
disconnection on comet Halley captured on 10 March 1986 by the ESO
1m schmidt.

The image is shown in the book "Comet Science", 2000, Jacques
Crovisier and Therese Encrenaz, Cambridge University Press.
Apparently the plasma tail (Ion Tail?) disconnects when the comet
crosses the boundary between two oppositely polarised magnetic
regions of the interplanetary field.

Cheers

David Higgins
E14
Canberra, Australia
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 11:24:50 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 & Comparison
Dennis,

Thanks for your reply..

You have a good point about rotating the images to be all the same.
It's something I should do but don't often get around to. I didn't
even do it for most of my Mars images last year! but eventually
transformed most of them.

One problem I have is working out which way is north and south. I
should work it out at the time I take the image I suppose, when I
can move the telescope in N/S/E/W to know what direction is what,
but from just looking at the image the next day when I process them
I haven't a clue which direction is which.

It'd be nice to have consistant exposure/brightness too, to be able
to compare in that respect also. But I always end up processing just
to get the most detail rather than comparison exposures.

Roger.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
wrote:

> Keep us posted on the progress of Q4!
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Roger" wrote:
> > Hi everyone,
> >
>
http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/gallery/photo/galleryComets/i
> > ndex.html
> >
> > Some more images of C/2001 Q4. It was tough imaging last night
but
> I was determined to get something so have add another image to
the
> > gallery. The wind was very strong and gusty.
> >
> > Of interest is a comparison image I have also added, comparing
my
> > image from Dec 30th to last night's (26th Jan). I may be
incorrect
> > in my interpretation as the image specifications are not equal
but
> > it looks like the tail has become quite a bit wider, splitting
more
> > distinctly into two tails. Is it normal for a comet to do this
as
> it approaches the sun? I see posts in the recent thread re C/2001
Q4
> > about the two tails but that still leaves me wondering about it
> > widenning out as it appears to have.
> >
> > Also are there programs which will show where comets are in
> relation to earth and the sun at a specific time? (top-down view
> style). This would be really helpful in learning the phases of a
> comet's life with respect to how it appears.
> >
> > Thanks,
> > Roger. 

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 14:08:19 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Question to Johannes re STL/10D
Johannes,

Have you thought about doing a piggyback 10D shot with your 300mm
f2.8 lens + combining this with a luminance shot with your STL/TMB
combo taken the same time? The field of view should be very similiar
and it appears the 10D has good sensitivity to the blues/greens and
yellows of typical of comets.

Terry 

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 09:38:23 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Comet T7-01/28/2004-0200UT
Indeed a wonderful image; I know better than anyone the types of conditions here in Arkansas that Mike must contend with in his capturing of images.

I do not believe however that this is a disconnect event; the contortions that are evident in Mike's image appear to be more on the order of a relationship between actual physical activity of the comet coincident in time with its interaction with solar plasma, solar wind.

Wonderful work, Mike.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatory
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mt.)
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: David Higgins
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, January 28, 2004 4:49 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: Comet T7-01/28/2004-0200UT

Damn Mike, you're getting some brilliant images.

The disruptions looks very similar to an image of a tail
disconnection on comet Halley captured on 10 March 1986 by the ESO
1m schmidt.

The image is shown in the book "Comet Science", 2000, Jacques
Crovisier and Therese Encrenaz, Cambridge University Press.
Apparently the plasma tail (Ion Tail?) disconnects when the comet
crosses the boundary between two oppositely polarised magnetic
regions of the interplanetary field.

Cheers

David Higgins
E14
Canberra, Australia
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj

Date:  Wed, 28 Jan 2004 16:03:47 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Image Orientation was Re: C/2001 Q4 & Comparison
Hi Roger,

I process like you do  try and get the most out of each image. I
have a real hard time when I make animated GIFs because the
background level changes from one frame to the next even though
conditions are ostensibly the same. Trying to match background
intensities in 100 or so images is boring.

As for orientation, deciding which end is up and so forth, T7 is
currently oriented with the tail trailing off to the upper left. This
will give you the North up, East left orientation that most imagers
favor.

To get the angle right, take an exposure while slewing in RA and
adjust the camera until the star trails are parallel to the bottom
edge.

I believe Dr. Clay prefers the North down "Astronomical" convention,
but I don't see that applied in modern texts or images much any more.
I believe it originated from gazing though scopes with inverted
images. I don't think image orientation matters as long as one
specifies what it is.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Roger" wrote:
> Dennis,
>
> Thanks for your reply..
>
> You have a good point about rotating the images to be all the same.
> It's something I should do but don't often get around to. I didn't
> even do it for most of my Mars images last year! but eventually
> transformed most of them.
>
> One problem I have is working out which way is north and south. I
> should work it out at the time I take the image I suppose, when I
> can move the telescope in N/S/E/W to know what direction is what,
> but from just looking at the image the next day when I process them
> I haven't a clue which direction is which.
>
> It'd be nice to have consistant exposure/brightness too, to be able
> to compare in that respect also. But I always end up processing
just
> to get the most detail rather than comparison exposures.
>
> Roger.
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
> wrote:
> > Hi Roger,
> >
> > It is fascinating to note the progress of Q4 over a short period
> of
> >time. May I suggest that you orient the images all the same way 
> > the refractor and SCT images are mirrored and the tail is
pointing a different way. That is disconcerting to me when
comparing images.
> >
> > > > Keep us posted on the progress of Q4!
> >
> > Clear skies,
> >
> > Dennis Persyk
> > Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> > Hampshire, IL
> > 

Date:  Thu, 29 Jan 2004 21:42:20 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2002 T7-01/29/2004-0120UT
I was hoping to catch the comet once again going a little crazy but
instead it acted just the opposite. This image is a combination of
5x120 sec exp lum. and 1x120 sec each RGB. Almost no tail visible
compaired to the previous night and except for the Moon a bit
brighter the skys were the same. Image is 74X56 arc-min with a 4"
@F5.3 & CCD.
Thanks, Mike H
http://www.fototime.com/FBC9687BF52E042/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 29 Jan 2004 14:21:22 -0800
From:  "Michael P. Caligiuri, Ph.D." 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2002 T7-01/29/2004-0120UT

Hi Mike: I've been following your journey with T7 the past few weeks and
am amazed at the variability in the comet structure. Generally, the
quality of your images has been rather uniform (and outstanding, by the
way), so the variation in comet structure was not likely due to image
processing. That being said, this current image is qualitatively different
(at on my monitor) from the others -- much higher contrast; saturated
colors, etc. I wonder if you noticed this as well.

-Mike C.

At 09:42 PM 1/29/2004 +0000, you wrote:

>instead it acted just the opposite. This image is a combination of

>compaired to the previous night and except for the Moon a bit
>brighter the skys were the same. Image is 74X56 arc-min with a 4"
>@F5.3 & CCD.
>Thanks, Mike H
>http://www.fototime.com/FBC9687BF52E042/orig.jpg

Date:  Fri, 30 Jan 2004 00:50:29 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: C/2002 T7-01/29/2004-0120UT
In the past couple of months and especially for the past three weeks
I have taken the same length of exposures and used the same number of
subimages. This along with processing the comet in the same way each
time gives me a day by day change and I can pretty much tell what
would be comet and noise. I have never had the opportunity to follow
any comet like this so I am quite surprised at the variance during
only one day. In the images from 1/28 I took 5x120 second images
which covered a 10 minute period and in a short movie could see the
tail move. The color image from today not only had the usual 5x120
but the three color filtered images which gave it a deaper look.
After looking for tail structure which was not there for some reason
I added the color info and processed for the color and not
grayscale. Sometimes when the Moon interfears, the color image is a
better way to produce and show more of the comet. I am sure that
after the 6th of next month, we can once again regain the faint tail
structure and then some. One other thing. This comet is now easly
imaged for longer periods as we are moving more inline where a few
weeks ago a 60 sec exposure was all the time allowed without
streaking of the comet. Mike H.

Date:  Fri, 30 Jan 2004 19:42:47 +1300
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Q4 image
Hi all,

was trying out a Canon EOS 10D digital SLR camera that was lent to me and I photographed Comet Q4 with it last night. It was taken with a 16" f4.5 and had a 1 minute exposure (set at 3200 ASA). See the link below...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/50-05-CometQ4.htm

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sat, 31 Jan 2004 02:50:52 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet C/2002 T7-01/31/2004
Ok, the Moon is a problem right now and the air was freezing on the
outside of the building even though it was not foggy. I thought that
I would over come the brightness of the sky with long exposure. I
ended tonight with 20x120 sec exposures. I stacked all on the comet
and then did a median combine with some levels in PS. I remember not
too long ago when 15th magnitude comets were all that were out there
so you won't hear me complain about this comet.
Storms moving in and a bright moon will probable keep me in untill
next weekend. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/35CF250254B5118/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 31 Jan 2004 08:10:50 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

Description : color photos of the comet C2002T7 of last night

You can access this file at the URL

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/CAST%20Italy/C2002T7_040130.jpg

Date:  Sun, 01 Feb 2004 20:34:16 -0000
From:  Johannes Schedler 
Subject:  LinearT7 Jan 30, 2004
As Mike and the others have stated I also have to confirm that the
tail of T7 mow is less pronounced recently.

Even with my 55 min L exposure it is hard to follow it, a strange
weak double appearance seems to be there.

Image and data:
http://panther-observatory.com/comets.htm#14

Johannes 

Date:  Sun, 01 Feb 2004 21:03:57 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: LinearT7 Jan 30, 2004
Hi Johannes,

You have captured about 21 arc minutes of tail even with the bright
moon. That is considerably better than I was able to get on Jan 30th
with 14 x 2 minutes at f/5.4 with my 4-inch refractor. See
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

I wonder how much tail length we are losing due to moon
interference?

The comet is sinking fast in the west for me so next new moon may be
my last chance for good images of T7. We'd better get it while the
getting is good.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Sun, 01 Feb 2004 15:49:07 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  About Mike Holloway
Hello to all....
I thought that you would all be interested in learning a bit more about Mike
Holloway, who has provided us with some very fine images of comets Encke and
Linear T7 as late; Mike lives in my neck of the woods and I was pleased when
informed that this group had feature both him and his fine observatory.

You can find this article describing both at:
http://www.aoas.org/
and scrolling down to the lead article.

This was posted by the Arkansas-Oklahoma Astronomical Society's Bob Moody.

Congrats, Mike.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatory
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mt.)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Sun, 01 Feb 2004 15:10:18 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] LinearT7 Jan 30, 2004
Does not the brightness of the moon now almost full
have an interaction with the atmosphere so as to dim
faint comet tails?

Or are you reporting a comet phenomenon?

Date:  Mon, 02 Feb 2004 05:50:18 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: LinearT7 Jan 30, 2004
Johannes,

I think you have captured the ion tail (top) and the shorter but
somewhat brighter dust tail (bottom). The ion tail seems to be
slight disconnected near the coma. It is normal for the ion tail to
fluctuate in brightness and shape, but the encouraging thing is the
coma seems to be still getting brighter. I am pretty confident the
best is still to come...

Terry

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Johannes Schedler"
wrote:
> As Mike and the others have stated I also have to confirm that the
> tail of T7 mow is less pronounced recently.
>
> Even with my 55 min L exposure it is hard to follow it, a strange
> weak double appearance seems to be there.
>
> Image and data:
> http://panther-observatory.com/comets.htm#14
>
> Johannes 

Date:  Mon, 02 Feb 2004 13:29:25 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  2004 A1 Animation
G'day All,

For some reason I have become quite interested in capturing images
of this comet, probabbly largely because of it's relatively faint
brightness (mag 17.2) and recent discovery.

With gusty winds and half a moon up I was surprised I managed to get
this animation from the other night.

It is actually a combination of two sets of 10 exposures. So the
exposure times vary:

10x 120sec
10x 180sec

ST7-ME Binned 2x2; Fl=1920mm; A=F/6.3

http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/gallery/photo/galleryComets/

You can see the comet moving from just above centre towards the
bottom left.

Roger.
================================================
Roger Groom rog1[AT]iinet.net.au
http://www.iinet.net.au/~rog1/
* Photography, Graphic Art & Astro Photography
* "Southern Amateur Astronomy" Info Pages.
================================================

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2004 A1 Animation

enjoyed browsing your website -- nice work.

-Mike

Date:  Wed, 04 Feb 2004 17:19:48 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Photometry with MaximDL
I would like to quantify my comet images by photometry. If any of you
are doing comet photometry with MaximDL. I'd like some tips on using
it. In particular, the choice of aperture size. I'd also like some
guidance on m1 and m2 as regards cometary CCD magnitude.

Thanks,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

31 Jan T7 images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2004 01:35:23 -0000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  Calendar
Mike,

A suggetion for the Yahoo Group set up. You can set the default
display for the calendar to Month, instead of day. Only the Owner or
moderator can do it. If you go to the calendar page, there is a link
on the lower right that only you can see. From there you can set the
default view to Month, then when people go to the Calendar they get a
regular Month type calendar that displays all the events for the
month and they can click the events for details. Instead of getting
just that days view in a ledger type format.

Pretty good club, 152 posts the first month! I laughed though when I
looked under Photos to see peoples comet pictures and found none. I
had to look at the name again; Comet-Images. I have some that are
not great, taken with 35mm camera. I'm getting a new Digital SLR
this month, cant wait.

Carey 

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2004 02:37:12 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Calendar
Mike & Carey,

I went ahead and set the calendar option since probably no one was
concerned about the setting before anyway.

Carey, check the "Files" section. I've found that Yahoo somehow
mangles the images placed in the photo section so using the files
section is better. Anyway, everyone is encouraged to post images on
their own web page and reference a link in their posting to the group
messages. Yahoo's file space is very limited and would soon be
overwhelmed at the rate that we've seen everyone taking pictures!

Dave Kodama

Date: Mon, 02 Feb 2004 13:29:25 -0000
From: "Roger"
Subject: 2004 A1 Animation

G'day All,

For some reason I have become quite interested in capturing images
of this comet, probabbly largely because of it's relatively faint
brightness (mag 17.2) and recent discovery.

With gusty winds and half a moon up I was surprised I managed to get
this animation from the other night.

It is actually a combination of two sets of 10 exposures. So the
exposure times vary:

10x 120sec
10x 180sec

ST7-ME Binned 2x2; Fl=1920mm; A=F/6.3

http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/gallery/photo/galleryComets/

You can see the comet moving from just above centre towards the
bottom left.

Roger.

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2004 11:37:25 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: Photometry with MaximDL
> are doing comet photometry with MaximDL. I'd like some tips on
using
> it. In particular, the choice of aperture size.

Hello Dennis,
as far as I know, there isn't yet a real standardization about CCD
photometry of cometary comae. Some people is used to integrate within
a window as large as the coma itsef, while others, like the Italian
Comet Section and the CARA project, prefers to scale the window
aperture to a fixed size (e.g. 100,000 Km) at the comet distance.
This step has the advantage to fix at least one variable.

If you decide to follow these last suggestion the equivalent circular
aperture for your window should be calculated according the formula :

Aperture (arcsec)= 138/Delta
where Delta= Eatch-comet distance in UA

If you are using a square aperture (like those in Astroart)
then the formula becames:

Aperture (arcsec) = 122.3/Delta

Ciao,
Giovanni 

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2004 14:05:29 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  Re: nice site
Eric,

Thanks for your reply. That's odd that the animation isn't working
for you. It did take me a couple of goes right now, but it did work
on the second try. I'm not sure what is going on there, I don't
think there is much I can do to improve it sorry.

As for predictions of the two comets - Best to check the Ephemerides
yourself rather than getting the info second hand through me (I'm
not the best with technicalities) but... It seems to me that the
peek of Q4 has "slipped back" a little (maybe I'm just remembering
wrong). It looks like it's peaking in early May, where as I thought
it was expected to be best in late Feb through mid March (which
suits me fine as I can't photograph it during Feb & early March
anyway). Time will tell. I haven't kept up with T7 as it hasn't been
visible from my location. I'm hoping to get some good photo's of
both in March & April though.

Roger.

Roger Groom rog1[AT]iinet.net.au
http://www.iinet.net.au/~rog1/

* "Southern Amateur Astronomy" Info Pages.

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2004 11:45:35 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Place to put your images on the internet
Most yahoo accounts come with about 30 megs of space
in your briefcase or photos that you can put your
pictures in.

Many images when saved as jpg files should be less
than 100K. That makes it possible to store
approximately 300 or more photos.

Then you won't crowd out others in the photos section
of the yahoo group.

=====
Charles Bell

__________________________________
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Finance: Get your refund fast by filing online.
http://taxes.yahoo.com/filing.html 

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2004 20:20:16 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: Place to put your images on the internet
Charles is correct. The space is provided for members to use. Some
may not have space to publish images and this will give those a place
to go. If and when the photo section reaches capacity we will need
to delete older files and images to make space for recent work.
Personally I would rather publish to my own space and simply post a
link because most of my images are bigger file sizes. The main thing
here is the images getting published --- no matter where. Thanks,
Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2004 14:06:23 -0800
From:  "D. Kodama" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Place to put your images on the internet
I might add that if you use the group's file or photo section to post an
image, you might want to create folder with your name on it and place your
images in it rather than at the "root" of the photo or file section. I
could imagine being buried in files all called c2002t7...

Dave

> Charles is correct. The space is provided for members to use. Some
> may not have space to publish images and this will give those a place
> to go. If and when the photo section reaches capacity we will need to
> delete older files and images to make space for recent work.
> Personally I would rather publish to my own space and simply post a
> link because most of my images are bigger file sizes. The main thing
> here is the images getting published --- no matter where. Thanks,
> Mike H.
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Charles Bell
> wrote:
>> Most yahoo accounts come with about 30 megs of space
>> in your briefcase or photos that you can put your
>> pictures in.
>>
>> Many images when saved as jpg files should be less
>> than 100K. That makes it possible to store
>> approximately 300 or more photos.
>>
>> Then you won't crowd out others in the photos section
>> of the yahoo group.
>>
>> =====

Date:  Sun, 08 Feb 2004 03:08:06 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet C/2002 T7-02082004-0145UT
Just between Moonrise and Sunset, I managed a number of shots. This
is a composit of 5x120 sec exp with the 4" and ccd. Tail is strange
once again and appears to break at even intervals. Comet appeared
brighter and I am waiting for the first naked eye sighting. I have
some color information that I will work with but incoming clouds
might have rendered them no good. Thanks, Mike H
http://www.fototime.com/DA05911C58E60B6/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 08 Feb 2004 13:03:15 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  2001 Q4 - Image Feb 8
Hi,

For all the northerners on the list Q4 is developing nicely, and
tonight there was a narrow margin between end of astronomical
twilight and moonrise. I used this time to get an image before cloud
and strong moonlight began to interfer. Unfortunately, for visual
observation the comet was sitting right next to a mag 7.6 star, but I
still made it mag 8.3 in 15x70 Binoculars.

The ion tail seems wider than in late January, with vague hints of
structure, however my camera is not particularly sensitive to blue
(unlike the interline CCDs).

My image is at:

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

Terry Lovejoy 

Date:  Sun, 08 Feb 2004 19:31:03 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2002 T7  8 Jan 04
I imaged T7 between twilight and moonrise but lost precious time
focusing and positioning. There is a hint of two tails. I did manage
to capture magnitude 15.1 galaxy PGC 1237 in the same FOV. The dim
galaxy is much brighter than the tail.

http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

I hope I get a good imaging night before T7 sinks to low in the west!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Mon, 09 Feb 2004 19:02:50 +0000
From:  Alan Cahill 
Subject:  New Member
Hi there,

Just a quick note to say Hi to everyone.
I was recommended to this group by Dennis Persyk, who I know through the
LX90 group.
My main field of research is the search for asteroids, and I have been
involved in this for around 5 years.
Over the last couple of years I've been starting to image comets (with
limited results!), but seeing the work Dennis has been doing has led me
here.
My small collection of images of comets, can be found at

http://www.mountabbeydale.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/Comet.htm

Please note however, that they were taken with a variety of scopes etc.
and the quality isn't that good at the moment.

Best Regards

Alan
Alan Cahill
Abbeydale Observatory,
Gloucester U.K.
MPC Code J94
http://www.mountabbeydale.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/ 

Date:  Thu, 12 Feb 2004 10:21:08 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz

I've posted the last night's composition of C/2002 T7

Date:  Fri, 13 Feb 2004 03:16:12 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2002 T7-02/13/2004-0150UT
Comet is becoming harder to image. The streak from the right (west)
side of the image to the comet is the 2nd mag star playing tricks.
This star and the lower position are causing gradients for me. This
is a 12x120 sec exposure and there still is less tail length showing
under good skys. FOV is 74x56 arc-min. I am linking a negative
also. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/1CCA9728E2746C6/orig.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/AE10F935408D951/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 15 Feb 2004 10:11:02 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /CAST Italy/C2002T7_040214.jpg
Uploaded by : astroligu2002
Description : C2002T7 of last evening in LBVR

You can access this file at the URL

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/CAST%20Italy/C2002T7_040214.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit

http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

astroligu2002 

Date:  Mon, 16 Feb 2004 03:17:50 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2002 T7
I cut the image time from 120 sec to 60 sec each and doubled the
exposures from 5 to 10. It is a shame that our position is not a
little better. This image taken 02/16/2004 - 0200 UT. FOV is
approx. 74x52 arc-min after a small crop. I overbrightened the image
to better show the faint tail. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/FFC600534B9D842/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 15 Feb 2004 19:40:07 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2002 T7
Very nice image Mike. I hope to get out this weekend and try this comet with
my new 480mm F6 refractor. Can I assume the gradient in the lower right is
light polution? Did you use a median combine or sum? I would think that
averaging the 10 images would blur the gradient. All the same, excellent
detail.

-Mike C

Date:  Mon, 16 Feb 2004 15:12:51 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: C/2002 T7
Thanks. The gradient in this case is caused by bad flatts. I am
pretty sure the position of the camera moved so today I will create
some new flatts to apply. The horizion is becoming more polluted
each day, so I wouldn't waste any time putting your new scope to
work. Mike

Date:  Mon, 16 Feb 2004 18:32:53 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2002 T7  16 Jan 04
I imaged T7 last night. The two-pronged tail is prominent. There are
two magnitude 15 galaxies in the same FOV.

I imaged the comet down to 17.4 degrees above the horizon. The comet
is much brighter which seems to aid imaging at low elevations. At
these low elevations I am troubled more by sky glow than by
atmospheric extinction. This is especially true now that the ground
is white with snow.

The two-pronged tail is still evident but imaging is becoming
increasingly difficult due to twilight and low elevations. I hope I
can get it as a morning comet but it does not look promising.

Images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Wed, 18 Feb 2004 08:25:11 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  C/2002 T7 Linear
Hi,

Last night I finally got a short time of imaging in weeks before the
next bad weather front rolled in. Linear was low in the sky and
already enveloped in a thin whispy cloud layer. Wind gusts were
another problem but I tried anyway. I binned 2x2 this time and
averaged 5 x 5 min. with my MX7c at f6.3 on a C8. The tail I could
get much of  too noisy  but still, the size of this comet and the
brightness/color were impressive for me.

Hope you like it anyway,

Mike A.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/linearKopie.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 19 Feb 2004 12:51:05 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 - February 18, 2004
Hi,

Despite summer heat and low altitude of C/2001 Q4 I was able to
capture a bit of faint - but interesting - tail detail on February
18th. See:

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

I have also put up some more info on C/2001 Q4 including a collation
of cropped older images from 2003 to show how the comet has developed.

Regards,
Terry 

Date:  Sat, 21 Feb 2004 04:05:34 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet C/2002 T7-02/21/2004-0230UT
I started with 5, went to 10 then 15 and ended with 53x60 sec. images
to complete this image. Seeing was not that great and the comet is
low in the west but I really thought I would not drop off to this.
Very tough now and unless really great skys happen tomorrow night
this could be my last image for now of this comet. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/AE8B7AE3B94E0C5/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 22 Feb 2004 21:01:10 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  C/2002 T7 Linear
Hi again,

this time I tried imaging Linear with my 300 mm camera lens. The link
is:

http://www.members.aon.at/fandrosc/page_7_8.html

Data is with the image. I got two horizontal stripes in the image and
I do not know where they come from (some artifact, also present in
the raw images). This is probably my last Linear image, since it is
already very low in the evening sky.

Mike 

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2004 23:53:40 +1030
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Website update
Hello all,
I've updated my website with the following:

C/2001 Q4 NEAT colour image taken on February 20th 2004.
10x15second stacked LRBG exposures, Celestron C11 at f/3.3 and Starlight
Express MX7c imager.
Plus processed image to enhance ion tail.

C/2003 H1 LINEAR CCD image on Feb 20th 2004.
8x15 second exposures, C11 telescope operating at f/3.3 and starlight
express MX7c imager. Note the dust tail sweeping downwards to the edge of
the frame

See http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

cheers,
Michael 

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2004 19:01:53 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2003 T4  Comet Images
Up until now, I have been imaging relatively bright comets, magnitude
9 and brighter. This comet at magnitude 16.3 was a real challenge!
Whereas I usually see the comet in a 5 second centering image, this
comet remained invisible until I stacked 11 5-minute images. I had
to trust my digital setting circles that the comet was somewhere in
the FOV.

Image 11 x 5 minutes unguided with 4-inch refractor at f/5.4; MX716
camera.

Note how bright magnitude 13.1 nebula IC 381 is in comparison to the
comet.

The relative motion was 0.33 arc seconds per minute. Over the 55
minute period this caused an 18 arc second blurring of the comet,
equivalent to 6 pixels. I could not see the comet in the individual
frames, so I could not co-register on it. I guess I am going to have
to learn how to use Astrometica! It displaces each frame according to
the relative motion of the comet as determined by ephemeredes.

Image at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2004 11:14:07 -0800
From:  "Michael P. Caligiuri, Ph.D." 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2003 T4  Comet Images
Impressive work Dennis. I wonder what a short animation (11 frames) would
do to confirming that this "smudge" is indeed the comet. Great work under
difficult conditions.

-Mike C.

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2004 19:25:57 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2003 T4  Comet Images
Hi Mike,

Thanks for checking out my faint (for me, anyway) comet.

To be honest, I was not sure I had imaged it until I compared my 15
image stack (aligned on stars) image with Guide 8 and noted the
smudge was right where it should be.

The trouble with an animation is that I can't see the comet in a
single frame  the signal-to-noise ratio is too poor.

I need a faster scope!

Dennis

Date:  Tue, 24 Feb 2004 08:15:39 +1100
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2002 T7 Linear

>>Data is with the image. I got two horizontal stripes in the image
>>
>and I do not know where they come from (some artifact, also present
>in the raw images). This is probably my last Linear image, since it
>is already very low in the evening sky.
>
>>Mike
>>

Hi Mike,
I wonder if you do your imaging remotely using VNC? I had similar
banding problem and found the cause to be moving the mouse (in order to
refresh the VNC window) during digitization/download. Once I figured it
out it was easy to see that they were correlated. I moved the mouse at
the start and end of the download which gave me bands at the top and
bottom of the image. Left it alone; no bands. Moved it for a longer
period in the middle of the download, and got a single wide band in the
center of the image!
Anyway, there are lots of causes of interference so this may not be the
cause in your situation. I hope it helps.

Cheers,
Vello

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 24 Feb 2004 19:09:16 +0100
From:  Mike Androsch 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2002 T7 Linear
Hi Vello,

maybe your right because I do move the mouse a lot during imaging and
downloads. I'm not working remotely but I sit at the screen and continuously
make manual corrections additionally to the starguide 2000 automatic
corrections if necessary when guiding. I will observe this more closely in
the future. Thank you for the tip!

Mike

Subject: C/2003 T4 Comet Images

Up until now, I have been imaging relatively bright comets, magnitude

9 and brighter. This comet at magnitude 16.3 was a real challenge!

Whereas I usually see the comet in a 5 second centering image, this

comet remained invisible until I stacked 11 5-minute images. I had

to trust my digital setting circles that the comet was somewhere in

the FOV.

Image 11 x 5 minutes unguided with 4-inch refractor at f/5.4; MX716

camera.

Note how bright magnitude 13.1 nebula IC 381 is in comparison to the

comet.

The relative motion was 0.33 arc seconds per minute. Over the 55

minute period this caused an 18 arc second blurring of the comet,

equivalent to 6 pixels. I could not see the comet in the individual

frames, so I could not co-register on it. I guess I am going to have

to learn how to use Astrometica! It displaces each frame according to

the relative motion of the comet as determined by ephemeredes.

http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Fri, 27 Feb 2004 04:29:36 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comet C/2002 T7-02272004
Just thought I would give this comet another chance to show up on my
chip and it did ok. The finer details are being lost through the
horizonal muck and the gradient from the low position is pretty bad
but it was good to see at least 50 arc-min's of tail showing in a
nice upswing to the N/NE.
http://fototime.com/B113311668AEC01/orig.jpg
Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Fri, 27 Feb 2004 06:45:12 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2002 T7-02272004
Wow Mike, you are a dedicated T7 follower! Imaging it with a bright
moon and low in the sky is really difficult. But you sure got a nice
image there with a long tail. I guess the brighter magnitude is
making up for the negative factors. Thanks for showing us that it is
not quite gone yet.

Out of curiosity, how low was it when you imaged it?

I wanted to image 123P and C/2003 H1 in the wee hours but heavy fog
rolled in at around midnight local time. I did get a couple of
emission nebulae with my H-alpha filter which I use to combat moon
light pollution.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Fri, 27 Feb 2004 15:53:58 +0100
From:  Mike Androsch 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2002 T7 Linear
Hi Juan,

no, only this image. It is very slightly seen on every raw I stacked only
from this image. Bringing out the tail of the comet in processing also
enhances the artifact. Maybe you could be right, since I have seen this
artifact for the first time.

Mike

Date:  Sun, 29 Feb 2004 17:00:12 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2002 T7-02272004
Dennis. I truthfully don't know how low it was but guessing I would
say 12 or 13 degrees above the horizion. I actually still have an
hour of imaging time left with clear skys. I don't think that the 10
SCT that I piggyback on likes to work at near horizonal views as the
stars are really making some strange shapes but I take the Images
that are given. Mike H.

Subject:  C/2002 T7-03062004

negative to try and gain some tail detail. It is there, just hard to
image under the conditions that this comet sits in. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Sun, 07 Mar 2004 15:22:26 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  T7-03072004
More images from 0200UT with clear skys. Comet is a very bright
central point. I guess the only reason I still image it is to make
sure it is still there. Perhaps if the weather holds I can get a day
or two without the Moon but even then this comet is a different
sight. Dennis I will follow it right into the ground, weather
permitting, and hopefully I will pick Q4 up coming the other way the
first part of May.
http://fototime.com/D24D73DC7234602/orig.jpg
Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Mon, 08 Mar 2004 03:04:26 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  T7-03082004-0200UT
Well I feel kind of alone here but what the heck I got this dude
again. I changed my imaging a bit and it helped along with about 30
minutes of Moon free sky. Let me say that my scope computer and
laptop software said that this object was below the horizion.
Ok the images here may not look like much but they are a
combination of 25x40 sec exp. There are 10x40 lum and 5x40 each of
RGB. All were combined and converted to grayscale. The camera was
working at a 1x1 bin and the comet was placed on a portion of the
chip to minize the really bad gradient that was present. The second
image is a median combine which I turned negative and actually got
some tail structure which I haven't seen in a while. The central
portion of this comet is brighter to me as an imager for the past 3
days. I imaged this comet untill it buried it's self in a far off
mountain. Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/799C6B39AABECBC/orig.jpg

http://fototime.com/43985FBEC69D924/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 07 Mar 2004 19:20:37 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] T7-03082004-0200UT
We're all here with you Mike. Outstanding work on this difficult object. Why
do I get the feeling that you'll probably move to Australia to follow T7 into
the Spring and Summer? Thanks for posting and keeping watch on this one for us.

-Mike C

Date:  Sun, 14 Mar 2004 16:35:50 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2003 H1 LINEAR Images


Images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

I imaged C/2003 H1 LINEAR with considerable difficulty last night.
The comet was low in the sky towards Chicago at an elevation of only
20 degrees. The sky glow was bright and my visual limiting
magnitude in that sector was about 1.0 . I could barely see
magnitude 8 stars in the 11 inch SCT.

Imaging was a balance between short exposures to minimize comet head
trailing and longer images to improve the signal to noise in the
tail structure. After experimenting with exposures between 30 and
480 seconds, I opted for 360 seconds. I accumulated 7 frames but
after processing them the next morning I wished I had taken more to
get better definition of the tail.

I also have a very short video showing the comet's track for 28
minutes across Hydra.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Mon, 15 Mar 2004 22:57:08 +1030
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  website image update
Hello all,
Please find my webite updated with the following:

C/2001 Q4 NEAT colour image taken on March 12th 2004.
10x15second stacked LRBG exposures, Celestron C11 at f/3.3 and Starlight
Express MX7c imager.

My personal light curve of comet C/2001 Q4 NEAT.

C/2003 H1 LINEAR animation on March 12th 2004. 310KB file
4x(5x15 second) exposures, C11 telescope operating at f/3.3 and starlight
express MX7c imager.

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

Date:  Fri, 19 Mar 2004 00:17:02 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Re: asteroid 2004 FH image
That would be due to its 0.05039 hr synodic rotation period with an
amplitude of ~0.9 mag (Lightcurve determined by Peter Kusnirak and
announce by Dr Petr Pravec)

Cheers

David Higgins
E14
Canberra, Australia
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj

From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 - Mar 18.77 UT
I have just uploaded a new image for Q4 on my webpage at:

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

This one was at quite low elevation in the morning sky (at 14
degrees) so gradients were a bit of problem, but the ion tail does
seem to be gaining intensity.

Terry

In a message dated 3/20/04 6:53:57 AM, Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com writes:

<< Date: Sat, 20 Mar 2004 01:31:11 -0000

Date:  Sun, 21 Mar 2004 06:11:46 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: q4 closeup nice shot
Dr Eric,

I am glad you like the image. Magnification doesn't have any meaning
when talking about photographic images, the closest equivalent term
would be image resoluion which is about 3.5 arc-sec per pixel in the
original image - so the planet Jupiter would appear about 15 pixels
wide at this scale. Hope that helps..

Currently, the comet is about magnitude 6.5 and easily visible in
ordinary binoculars. You are right about the tail, I would have
liked to have seen a more developed tail but it should improve
significantly by May.

Terry 

Date:  Sun, 21 Mar 2004 11:48:17 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  thanks for the clarification
Terry
Thanks for the clarification. I am still trying to look for several comets
that might be in my images (like west-hartley and others). I look forward to
hearing more about Q4 and T7 in the future and photographing them when we can see
them in the Northern Hemisphere.

Olathe, KS. USA

Dr Eric,

I am glad you like the image. Magnification doesn't have any meaning
when talking about photographic images, the closest equivalent term
would be image resoluion which is about 3.5 arc-sec per pixel in the
original image - so the planet Jupiter would appear about 15 pixels
wide at this scale. Hope that helps..

ordinary binoculars. You are right about the tail, I would have
liked to have seen a more developed tail but it should improve
significantly by May.

Date:  Mon, 22 Mar 2004 05:23:12 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 - Mar 18.77 UT
Terry,

You continue to get good images of this comet. I have been having
extreme troubles imaging Q4 because all night it pops in and out of
behind trees, so I ended up with a patchy view and blurred tree's at
best :-)

It's nice to see the long tail - the first amateur image I've seen
with what looks like the full tail length. The only other image I had
seen with it was in space.com's Image Of The Day site from a pro obs
in Chile.

Roger.

Roger Groom rog1[AT]iinet.net.au

Date:  Wed, 24 Mar 2004 16:59:17 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz 
Subject:  Recent images links

thanks Dennis

http://www.geocities.com/juan_lacruz/Comets/123P_20040320_J87.jpg

Date:  Wed, 24 Mar 2004 17:43:19 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Recent images links
Hi Juan,

I like the H1 imagery very much! You have captured a much longer
tail than I did a couple of weeks ago.

The isophotes superimposed over the negative image is an excellent
way of highlighting the tail structure. I hope you don't mind if I
use your technique on my next comet image. You were fortunate to
capture the comet when its tail was not washed out by bright stars.

On the middle isophote image you have a axis drawn through the
nucleus. I assume this is a line through the sun. The axis of the
tail makes about a 30 degree angle with the line solar axis. I think
I know how to draw such a line now but I've not tried yet in an
image.

If the tail were an ion tail, we would expect it to be along the
solar axis, whereas a dust tail curves as it follows along the
curving orbit of the comet  is this correct?

Perhaps you could put together a little tutorial on these aspects
for the group. I'm sure there would be considerable interest.

Thanks for sharing the images with us. They are truly inspiring.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Juan Lacruz"
wrote:
> Dennis reported the attachement had problems, here are the links,
> thanks Dennis
>
> http://www.geocities.com/juan_lacruz/Comets/123P_20040320_J87.jpg
>
http://www.geocities.com/juan_lacruz/Comets/C2003H1_20040320_J87.jpg
>
> Juan 

Date:  Wed, 24 Mar 2004 20:14:19 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz 
Subject:  Re: Recent images links
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
wrote:
> Hi Juan,
>
> I like the H1 imagery very much! You have captured a much longer
> tail than I did a couple of weeks ago.

Thanks for your kind comments Dennis, it seems I have very good sky
at La Cañada Observatory 1400m (when it is not overcasted ;-)

> The isophotes superimposed over the negative image is an excellent
> way of highlighting the tail structure. I hope you don't mind if I
> use your technique on my next comet image. You were fortunate to
> capture the comet when its tail was not washed out by bright stars.

Of course I don't mind, this is not something I've invented, please
give it a try and we'll be able to compare and discuss.

> On the middle isophote image you have a axis drawn through the
> nucleus. I assume this is a line through the sun. The axis of the
> tail makes about a 30 degree angle with the line solar axis. I
think
> I know how to draw such a line now but I've not tried yet in an
> image.

This is the line drawn at the sub Solar position angle as from JPL
horizons (column 16). I draw a vertical line in photoshop and then I
rotate it counter clock wise by that amount. Then it's just copy and
paste layer.

> If the tail were an ion tail, we would expect it to be along the
> solar axis, whereas a dust tail curves as it follows along the
> curving orbit of the comet  is this correct?

Yes, I think you're rigth.

> Perhaps you could put together a little tutorial on these aspects
> for the group. I'm sure there would be considerable interest.

I make a note of this.

>
> Thanks for sharing the images with us. They are truly inspiring.
>

Thanks again for your words and clear skies.
Juan

> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
>

Date:  Fri, 26 Mar 2004 23:48:42 +1100
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
I took a few wide-field images of C/2001 Q4 with a telephoto lens + CCD
to see how much tail I could capture. The resulting 6 minute exposure
isn't a work of art as I binned the images 3x3 to increase sensitivity,
and the lens was slightly defocussed (for a photometry project I'm
working on). The comet was low and in a strongly light polluted part of
my suburban sky. Despite this, a heavily enhanced version of the image
show at least 2.5 degrees of tail!
http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2001q4/2001q4.htm

Cheers,
Vello Tabur 

Date:  Fri, 26 Mar 2004 14:38:20 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Vello Tabur wrote:
> I took a few wide-field images of C/2001 Q4 with a telephoto lens +
CCD
> to see how much tail I could capture. The resulting 6 minute
exposure
> isn't a work of art as I binned the images 3x3 to increase
sensitivity,
> and the lens was slightly defocussed (for a photometry project I'm
> working on). The comet was low and in a strongly light polluted
part of
> my suburban sky. Despite this, a heavily enhanced version of the
image
> show at least 2.5 degrees of tail!
> http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2001q4/2001q4.htm
>
> Cheers,
> Vello Tabur

Thanks Vello. Are you looking at the comet as it is coming directly
at you? If this is so would this be the ion tail and would this mean
that there is no way to know how long the dust tail is? I am just
trying to picture the way it sits now. Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Fri, 26 Mar 2004 19:28:12 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
Thanks for sharing the image, Vello. I am excited about imaging Q4
in April from my Midwest USA site. I guess I'd better practice
imaging with the 135 and 50 mm camera lenses piggyback as it
assuredly is not going to fit in the FOV of my scopes!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Vello Tabur wrote:
> I took a few wide-field images of C/2001 Q4 with a telephoto lens
+ CCD to see how much tail I could capture. The resulting 6 minute
exposure isn't a work of art as I binned the images 3x3 to increase
sensitivity, and the lens was slightly defocussed (for a photometry
project I'm working on). The comet was low and in a strongly light
polluted part of my suburban sky. Despite this, a heavily enhanced
version of the image show at least 2.5 degrees of tail!
> http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2001q4/2001q4.htm
>
> Cheers,
> Vello Tabur 

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 12:34:01 +1100
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
Mike Holloway wrote:

>Thanks Vello. Are you looking at the comet as it is coming directly
>at you? If this is so would this be the ion tail and would this mean
>that there is no way to know how long the dust tail is? I am just
>trying to picture the way it sits now. Thanks, Mike H.
>
Hi Mike,
I find that the following site is great for trying to visualize the
comet's orbital geometry:
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/Astronomy/OrbitViewer/index.jsp
If you adjust the view to look down through the ecliptic plane and then
side on, you can see that the dust tail is currently greatly
fore-shortened as we look along the orbit.. Q1's inclination is 99
degrees, so it's pretty much heading up straight up toward the ecliptic
plane from below.
Cheers,
Vello 

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 04:27:51 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
Hi Vello/list,

Great photo Vello!

For comparsion I did a 9 minute exposure with Canon 300D and 100mm
f3.2 lens the previous evening. Not as deep as yours but there is
just a hint of nearly ~2 degrees of tail + a dust tail <1 degree.
Agree gradients are a real problem for Q4 at the moment (Q4 for was
just 15 degrees high for me). Bring on April and May!

The photo is at

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

Cheers Terry 

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 06:13:15 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Q4  / T7

should be able to image it the second week of April or close if skys

south and look fordward to the Q4 progress. Mike H. 

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 17:37:09 +1100
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
terryjlovejoy wrote:

>For comparsion I did a 9 minute exposure with Canon 300D and 100mm
>f3.2 lens the previous evening. Not as deep as yours but there is
>just a hint of nearly ~2 degrees of tail + a dust tail <1 degree.
>Agree gradients are a real problem for Q4 at the moment (Q4 for was
>just 15 degrees high for me). Bring on April and May!
>
>The photo is at
>
>http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm
>
Hi Terry,
You've really captured the dust tail well! Apart from the triangular
coma, it's hardly visible on my image.

BTW, I looked at your 300D page. Impressive LMC shot! It should perform
nicely when the comet gets brighter. I tested a Canon Powershot S30
recently. The lens is tiny, max ASA rating is 800 and exposures are
limited to 15sec, so I'm going to need a lot of stacked images. I was
hoping for a better result but it doesn't look like the right tool for
the job. Here's hoping for a really bright comet to compensate for the
camera's inadequacies ;-)

Cheers,
Vello 

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 13:56:51 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
Hi,

I put the 300D on my Tak Epsilon E160 tonight, before the rain came
in, and got 16 minutes of exposure which shows 2 degrees of faint ion
tail reasonably well (were it then leaves the field of view). The
comet was only 19 degrees above the horizon mid-exposure and there
was a strong gradient (from moonlight and scattered cloud) that I
could not cleanly remove, so I have done my best to maintain an
asthetic appearance while showing the extent of the tail.

The image is at the usual URL:

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

All up I think the 300D is an excellent wide angle camera for
comets...

Terry

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 16:09:07 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
Hi Terry,

Excellent image! I also clicked on the "click here" on your web
site and was treated to a comprehensive image chronology of the
comet  very instructive.

I just got a Takahashi Epsilon 160 astrograph myself and have lots
of questions:
1) How do you mount the 300D?
2) How do you judge best focus  I assume you are rotating the rack
and pinion knob by hand. Do you have a video output or are you using
the built-in LCD screen?

My mentor says I should really use film with the E160 to take
advantage of its large flat field. I sold my darkroom equipment
about 20 years ago and I consider film a large step backwards in
time. Hence my interest in the 300D.

Keep the images coming, Terry. Pretty soon the comet will be
visible in my neck of the woods.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 21:12:35 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Takahashi 10 to 1 focuser

Date:  Sat, 27 Mar 2004 21:37:06 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 with 2.5 degree tail
Dennis,

Congratulations..the Epsilon 160 is fine astrograph!

As for mounting the camera you should have got a T ring attachment
with the scope (I think it is called a Takahashi Wide T-Adapter or
similiar). This has a screw-thread on one side that attaches to the
focuser and on the other side a tapered flange (The 'T'). To complete
the equation you then need to get a Canon EOS T-Adapter (I think
Parks/Orion sell them - I got mine off astromart) which attaches the
T to the EOS mount.

I am using the preview screen to focus using a star (using the rack-
and-pinion) - problem is there is not enough zoom magnification on
the preview. Maybe DSLRfocus is the next item to get and then a
precision focuser like Mike pointed out.

I made a custom back for my E160 a while back, and it covers an image
circle of 54mm - about 6 degrees. Although sharp to the edges, its
major drawback is vignetting. Even with 35mm film the edges are
noticeably vignetted. I think the 300D/Rebel is a good match as the
field is still well illuminated and - at least for comets - you
should gain some sensitivity to make up for the loss of FOV. Of
course ease of use is in favour of the DSLR....

Terry 

Date:  Sun, 28 Mar 2004 16:46:41 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz 
Subject:  J87 comet images
I've re-organised my comet images at :

http://www.geocities.com/juan_lacruz/Comets/page1.htm

Juan 

Date:  Sun, 28 Mar 2004 20:12:32 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2003 K4
O-the weather. While waiting on a break from the many inches or rain
that we are receiving I thought I would look just a little ahead. K4
visible in the morning sky will start to increase in brightness and
should be one to keep on the chip. According to Guide8 this comet
will increase to magnitude 9.5 by the first week in May and the
position should give for some really good wide field views especially
for the DSLR users. April 16th the comet will move within 30 arc-min
of NGC 6885. It will then cross the Milkyway which should be prime
for imaging. 5 May it is 5 arc-min from Diffused Neb. LBN158. For
the next few days it will travel N-N/W and on 8 May be next to the
Nebula LBN158. At this time this comet will be around 9.4 according
to prediction. Moving ahead to July 28 2004 the comet will be in the
West sitting on top (?) of NGC 5466 mag.9. At this time the comet
shows to be at magnitude 6.5. Always helps to plan just a little
ahead for me so I can start gathering my info. Mike H.

Date:  Mon, 29 Mar 2004 21:32:52 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz 
Subject:  Re: J87 comet images
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, KCStarguy@a... wrote:
> Juan
> Nice negatives. When were these taken and what was the exposure and
times? Is this one of the comet wild pics?

Thanks Eric for your comments. When you click on the thumbnails, the
picture opens, you'll see, at the bottom, a label with the time stamp
in UT and relevant technical information.
All the pictures were adquired by me from La Cañada Observatory at
1400m near Avila, SPAIN.
Most of them are 60 sec. frames stacked on the comet's movement using
Herbert Raab's Astrometrica.

Best regards,
Juan

Date:  Wed, 31 Mar 2004 07:28:19 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 21&26 march UT
Thanks Kearn!

You will be glad to know I still have a old but good Pentax film
camera that I intend to do widefield piggyback.

The 300D is indeed an excellent camera especially on the telescope,
but remember it's sensor is smaller than a 35mm neg by a factor of
1.6 across the diagonal. So to get the same field of view as your
135mm lens I have to use a 85 mm lens. So you end up much the same
as far as resolution and limiting magnitude are concerned (for the
same field of view). There is also little Ha sensitivity which means
that emmission nebula appear green blue...not that is of much concern
to comet people.

Terry

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, belatrix wrote:
> Hi all
> Not much yet to photograph for our old 35mm film camera's - but a

indeed!!
> Stunning! the future looks very good. :)

Date:  Wed, 31 Mar 2004 23:30:03 +0930
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2001 Q4 21&26 march UT
Terry,
You know we love the old Pentax 35mm cameras being piggybacked - and it is
very encouraging to hear the old K1000 may be coming out from mothballs! :-)

Personally i dont care overly about red sensitivity in imaging - i mean i
cant physically see much red in the night sky (apart from red stars of
course and the odd aurora, sunsets ect.) so if one was trying to closely as
possible reproduce how the night sky appears to the human eye, than the red
nebula's are not truly representative of that view, i think anyway. It is
good to see stuff brought out in widefield/all images that you wouldnt see
naked eye, but there are plenty of people already doing that maybe.
But if there were suddenly a bright red comet, of course i would change my
tune!

Cheers
Kearn

Date:  Wed, 07 Apr 2004 07:19:05 +0200
From:  Maik Meyer 
Subject:  Call for observations
FYI (translation by myself):

>From May 7 - 8, 2004, observations of comet C/2001 Q4 are planned
with the X-ray satellite XMM-Newton.

According to the current planning the observations will start on May 7,
2004, at about 13:30 UT and will last until May 8, 02:33 UT. A delay by
half or a full day is possible; this will be fixed on short term.

Simultaneous observations are desirable for a comparison with the
X-ray data. Especially interesting are images where details of the
inner coma can be seen and images which show the full extension of
the coma, respectively. Still even better if the images are done with
narrow-band filters, which preferably let pass the emission lines and
supress the continuum, in order to detect the distribution of the gas
in the coma.

Since we reckon for this comet with a large coma in the X-ray region
(about 2 degrees) a direct overlay of the X-ray images with optical
images with a field of view of several degrees would be ideal. Images
that show structures within the tail are useful, too, because they
deliver hints about the characteristics of the solar wind.

Kind regards,
Konrad Dennerl

kod[at]mpe.mpg.de

--
If they give you ruled paper, write the other way. * Juan Ramon Jimenez
________________________________________________________________________
maik@comethunter.de http://www.comethunter.de
German Comet Section http://www.fg-kometen.de
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/comets-ml 

Date:  Wed, 07 Apr 2004 16:47:34 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Call for observations
Hi Maik,

Thanks for the posting and the translation. I will need some help
with the narrow-band filer request.

Please provide us with filter specifications, and, most importantly,
sources of filters in standard 1.25 screw-in filter holders.

Thanks.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Wed, 07 Apr 2004 22:34:30 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Mike Holloway in May Astronomy Magazine
Mike Holloway's C2002 T7 image appears in the May Astronomy magazine
on page 107. Interestingly enough, beside it is a picture of T7
taken with a 12.5 inch RC scope. I think Mike's image is better with
his 4-inch scope. Nice technique, Mike. Congratulations.

There were a lot of comet images in both S&T and Astronomy, so
perhaps other group members had their images published as well.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

Date:  Thu, 08 Apr 2004 01:43:32 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Re: Call for observations
How about spectra? Note that I have NEVER done spectra before but
am about to start experimenting. I'm planning on using a EO
Holographic sheet to make a star spectra filter (same arrangement as
a Rainbow Optics filter but with many, many more lines/inch). Q4
should be bright enough in my 14" to produce something usable -
Yes/No?. Could this be a better than narrow band filters (it will
certainly be cheaper)?

Cheers

David Higgins
E14
Canberra, Australia
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj

<of my mail - and I am entering them via the Yahoo web interface!>>

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Maik Meyer" wrote:
> FYI (translation by myself):
>
> From May 7 - 8, 2004, observations of comet C/2001 Q4 are planned
> with the X-ray satellite XMM-Newton.
>
> According to the current planning the observations will start on
May 7,
> 2004, at about 13:30 UT and will last until May 8, 02:33 UT. A
delay by
> half or a full day is possible; this will be fixed on short term.
>
> Simultaneous observations are desirable for a comparison with the
> X-ray data. Especially interesting are images where details of the
> inner coma can be seen and images which show the full extension of
> the coma, respectively. Still even better if the images are done
with
> narrow-band filters, which preferably let pass the emission lines
and
> supress the continuum, in order to detect the distribution of the
gas
> in the coma.
>
> Since we reckon for this comet with a large coma in the X-ray
region
> (about 2 degrees) a direct overlay of the X-ray images with
optical
> images with a field of view of several degrees would be ideal.
Images
> that show structures within the tail are useful, too, because they
> deliver hints about the characteristics of the solar wind.
>
> Kind regards,
> Konrad Dennerl
>
> kod[at]mpe.mpg.de
>
> --
> If they give you ruled paper, write the other way. * Juan Ramon
Jimenez
>
_____________________________________________________________________
___
> maik@c... http://www.comethunter.de
> German Comet Section http://www.fg-kometen.de
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/comets-ml 

Date:  Wed, 07 Apr 2004 17:37:34 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Mike Holloway in May Astronomy Magazine
Mike's images are showing up everywhere; I can be proud to say that he is from Arkansas and that once upon a time I provided just a nod of encouragement for his work. Perseverance translates to excellence, always.

Congrats, Mike and see you on April 16.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatory
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mt.)
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: Dennis Persyk
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 07, 2004 5:34 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Mike Holloway in May Astronomy Magazine

Mike Holloway's C2002 T7 image appears in the May Astronomy magazine
on page 107. Interestingly enough, beside it is a picture of T7
taken with a 12.5 inch RC scope. I think Mike's image is better with
his 4-inch scope. Nice technique, Mike. Congratulations.

There were a lot of comet images in both S&T and Astronomy, so
perhaps other group members had their images published as well.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New DSO Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Fri, 09 Apr 2004 21:08:11 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: Latest images -  9th April 2004
John,

Well done! I had a scan through your DSO's as well and very
impressive for 30-60 second exposures...

Mike,

I have just posted 2 new images of Q4 and T7 at my website

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

I must admit I am on a learning curve with processing the DSLR
images. Gradients are a lot worse to start with, especially when the
individual RGB channels have different gradients! Also IRIS by
default stacks RGB images by adding, however this causes unsightly
trailing artifacts...when I get some more time I try some different
stacking techniques so I get some smoother backgrounds.

Terry 

Date:  Fri, 09 Apr 2004 21:23:11 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Latest images -  9th April 2004
Terry. I am just glad to see T7 still in one piece and at a 4+
magnitude. But Q4---WOW I can really see the improvement from your
last image. I hope you guys can keep us updated at least once a week
now. If you need some space to publish use the yahoo at this sight
and if you need more than that let me know and we will find the
space. That is execellent work Terry and John. Thank you I can't
wait to resume my imaging after the welder comes this weekend to
improve my shakey mount. Mike H.

Date:  Sat, 10 Apr 2004 21:46:45 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  T7 - More 'Live' Coverage
I have just updated my webpage with another T7 image from this
morning. This time I sat the camera on the roof of my car and made
12 consecutive exposures all 5 seconds each - totally unguided.
After stacking them together, I was quite impressed to reach mag 10
with a 100mm telephoto lens that deep in twilight....

Regards,
Terry
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm 

Date:  Sun, 11 Apr 2004 10:10:43 +1200
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Comet 2001 Q4 (NEAT) image - 10 April 2004
Hi all,

thanks for the positive feedback...

Here is another image of Q4 taken last night. It is a single 45 seconds exposure (ISO 3200). I have ImagesPlus but have yet to sit down and learn how to stack multiple images - I am VERY new to this digital photography game...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/Comet2001Q4-NEAT-040410.jpg

Of note is the thin gas tail shooting out to the left (SSE).

John Drummond

Date:  Mon, 12 Apr 2004 13:44:54 -0000
From:  Roger Groom 
Subject:  Q4 finally appears from behind the tree's
G'day All,

After starting imaging Q4 back in December 03 and then it disappearing
behind tree's for the last few months it has finally re-appeared for me to
snap a few short images between the branches. It was only visible for 10
minutes total so this 5 minute exposure is the best I have unfortunately.

Still, it's not bad. Wider FOV and longer exposure would be nice.

The first image at:
http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/gallery/photo/galleryComets/

It looks very similar to John's image which is re-assuring :-) Although I
didn't get that thin tail.

Roger.

================================================
Roger Groom rog1[AT]iinet.net.au
http://www.iinet.net.au/~rog1/
* Photography, Graphic Art & Astro Photography
* "Southern Amateur Astronomy" Info Pages.
================================================

Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2004 12:08:42 +1200

Subject:  Latest Q4 images - 13 April 2004
Hi all,

I took a few more images of C/2001 Q4 (NEAT) last night, they and a few other new images can be found at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/20-A-Latest_images-04-04-13.htm

If you want to see all my web-published images of C/2001 Q4 go to...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/20-2Comets-C-2001Q4(NEAT).htm

It seems that the tail is getting stronger in the last few days. One image with a 20cm f4 Vixen Newtonian shows a faint tail extending for about 1.1* to the SSE.

Subject:  Q4's gas tail
Hi all,

I'm not certain, but it seems from images I have taken over the last few nights that C/2001 Q4 (NEAT)s thin gas tail has disappeared (or at least reduced)... See the three comparative images at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/20-2Comets-C-2001Q4(NEAT)-tail_change.htm

On the 10th and 13th of April the thin spike of a tail is seen, but tonight (14th) it is not evident. Can any other cometographers verify this (Terry et al?)???

Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2004 17:49:10 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: Latest Q4 images - 13 April 2004
John,
Excellent images! The color and star sharpness are great!
I tried to calculate your field of view for a 24mm diagonal chip (app
D10 size) and I came up with approximately 1X1.5 degrees. I was using
8" f/4 (FL =800mm). You indicated that the tail was a little over 1
degree. Is that part of the tail not visible in the photo or did I
calculate something wrong, because the tail would represent nearly
the width of the image at the scale I calculated ?

I want to try to image C/2001 Q4 (NEAT) when it arrives here
(Southern California) next month. I am trying to determine the best
FOV for the images. I would like to take one to show some surrounding
sky for perspective and one of just the comet for detail. I will be
using one or all of these combinations CCD (ST10XME or STV), Film
(35mmm Nikon), DSLR (Nikon D1X). Do you have any recommendations?
Thanks, Rick
