Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2004 17:59:38 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
Hi gang,
I want to have a go at imaging C/2001Q4 when it visits Southern
California. I don't have a fixed focal length lens in certain ranges.
I do have:
80-200mm f2.8 EDIF Nikon lens
55mm Macro Nikon Lens (I think f2)
300mm f4 EDIF
Will the 80-200 work (I have seen warnings against zooms, but I
wondered if that applied to these ED fast zooms)?
Should I use a IR cutoff filter?
Thanks, Rick 

Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2004 18:22:43 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
Hi Rick,

Camera lenses generally work best at two stops or more down from
full open. The comet will be big and bright so lens choice will
depend on tail length and how you want to frame the comet. The zoom
will work fine. The IR cut filter is not required.

By the way, is this film, CCD, or digital camera?

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Rick Wiggins"
wrote:
> Hi gang,
> I want to have a go at imaging C/2001Q4 when it visits Southern
> California. I don't have a fixed focal length lens in certain
ranges.
> I do have:
> 80-200mm f2.8 EDIF Nikon lens
> 55mm Macro Nikon Lens (I think f2)
> 300mm f4 EDIF
> Will the 80-200 work (I have seen warnings against zooms, but I
> wondered if that applied to these ED fast zooms)?
> Should I use a IR cutoff filter?
> Thanks, Rick 

Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2004 18:46:21 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
Dennis,
Thanks for the input. I am planning on taking all 3 capabilities.
I will take a film camera for piggy back because I know that I can
capture something this way (this is my backup).
I will take a DSLR for similar reason as above and I can get
immediate feedback (it is easy to swap out with film SLR, but may
suffer from noise).
I will be wanting to try CCD, but I am new and don't want to miss the
comet due to rookie mistake.
I will be traveling to dark sky location, so I will only get 1 or 2
trys.
I don't think I can image form back yard as I am 15 miles due south
of Los Angeles and if we don't have fog (only about 10% of the time),
we have about Mag 3.3 skies.
Thanks for any help and advice,
Rick

Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2004 19:57:23 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: Q4's gas tail
John,

I have wide angle images of Comet Q4 on the evenings of April 13 and
14 for you to have a look at on my webpage. The tail was definitely
quite a bit fainter (especially near the coma) on the 14th, but
notice the very subtle wavy structure all the way to the edge of the
frame. It looks like a disconnection type event to me.

There is only so much the Canon can do in a 17minute exposure so I am
hoping Vello was able to capture this event with his ST8/lens
combo.

Terry 

Date:  Thu, 15 Apr 2004 07:52:42 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
Rick Wiggins wrote:

>Hi gang,
>I want to have a go at imaging C/2001Q4 when it visits Southern
>California. I don't have a fixed focal length lens in certain ranges.
>I do have:
>80-200mm f2.8 EDIF Nikon lens
>55mm Macro Nikon Lens (I think f2)
>300mm f4 EDIF
>Will the 80-200 work (I have seen warnings against zooms, but I
>wondered if that applied to these ED fast zooms)?
>Should I use a IR cutoff filter?
>Thanks, Rick
>
Hi Rick,
I use a Nikon ED 80-200mm zoom (fixed f/2.8) for my images. It's a
superb lens in every way. I think your EDIF is the newer model. Anyway,
I find that it produces great images even at f/2.8 and doesn't need an
IR blocker. I used to use a Sigma 100-300mm zoom at f/4 and there is no
comparison. The Nikon is better by an order of magnitude (10x , not 2.5x ;-)
Regards,
Vello 

Date:  Wed, 14 Apr 2004 22:00:49 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
Vello,
You are correct about that lens.It seems to be one of the best lenses
that Nikon has ever made. My images with that lens are superb. I will
take you recommendation and try that lens.
Thanks, Rick

Date:  Thu, 15 Apr 2004 08:05:53 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Q4's gas tail
terryjlovejoy wrote:

>John,
>
>I have wide angle images of Comet Q4 on the evenings of April 13 and
>14 for you to have a look at on my webpage. The tail was definitely
>quite a bit fainter (especially near the coma) on the 14th, but
>notice the very subtle wavy structure all the way to the edge of the
>frame. It looks like a disconnection type event to me.
>
>There is only so much the Canon can do in a 17minute exposure so I am
>hoping Vello was able to capture this event with his ST8/lens
>combo.
>
John & Terry,
Unfortunately I didn't get any images last night, but I do have some
from the 12th and 13th. There was a noticeable change between those
nights. The thin ion tail is less well defined on the 13th. Curiously,
while I was selecting images to stack, I saw quite a bit of variation
from image to image, but I put it down to noise. Since I have many 30sec
images from the 13th spread over about 1.5 hours, I might try to combine
them into 10min stacks to see if I can detect any changes...
Regards,
Vello 

Date:  Thu, 15 Apr 2004 10:29:39 +1200
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Q4's gas tail
Hi Rick,

I guesstimated Q4's tail length as 1.1* by comparing the image to GUIDE 8. The FOV is about 1.5* x 1*. In regards to what equipment to use, the advice from Terry and Vello (great images guys!) sounds good. I think that travelling to a dark sky is a must if you want to capture the faint, extended tail (wider-angle lens needed - e.g. 10* - 30*+(?). If you just want the coma/nucleus, stay at home and zoom in with a longer focal length - it is nice and bright. Getting brighter too...

Hi Terry,

thanks for the shots - which are great! Yes, it seems from yours also that the thin gas spike tail broadens out and becomes wavey and more subtle. Cheers. The next two months should be interesting comet-wise.

Cheers

John

John,

I have wide angle images (with the 300D so I am not OT!) of Comet Q4
From: "terryjlovejoy"
Date: 2004/04/15 Thu AM 07:57:23 GMT+12:00
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: Q4's gas tail

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 15 Apr 2004 01:09:15 -0000
From:  djhanson100 
Subject:  Re: Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
Hi Rick,

It sounds like you have some nice gear for comet imaging. I've been
studying a lot of comet images from the spaceweather.com archives,
the APML archives and other sites. My favorite photos always
involve capturing the entire comet from coma to tail, good detail
and a dark background with many stars. These type of shots
generally all require film with a Schmidt Camera or a fast 200-300mm
telephoto. So next month, weather providing, I plan to piggyback my
Nikon F/Nikkor 300mm f/2.8 to my C11. I'm thinking of using either
Kodak E200 or Elite II film, perhaps bracketing 5-15 minute
exposures and may also try stepping down on a few shots... I also
may take some shots with my Nikkor 200mm f/4, 135mm f/3.5 and 50mm
f/1.4. But from my Ikeya Zhang experience, it seemed that even the
200mm f/4 wasn't fast enough to capture the detail I would have
liked. That was my rationale, good or bad, for spending some dough
on the monster 300mm f/2.8 (used of course!). And I've been
following Q4 ever since Ikeya Zhang--even if it mirrors that comet
in brightness and size--I'd be plenty happy. Either way I'm looking
forward to early May for sure.

Some of my favorite comet shots include those of the members here as
well as those by Michael Jager and Gerald Rhemann
(http://www.astrostudio.at/).

Clear skies to you,

--DJ

> 55mm Macro Nikon Lens (I think f2)
> 300mm f4 EDIF
> Will the 80-200 work (I have seen warnings against zooms, but I
> wondered if that applied to these ED fast zooms)?
> Should I use a IR cutoff filter?
> Thanks, Rick 

Date:  Fri, 16 Apr 2004 13:19:44 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
Rick,

By the second week of May I believe the tail of Q4 will extend about
20 degrees photographically. My last image from April 14, shows
about 7 degrees, keeping in mind the comet is getting closer to the
sun and will be more than 2 times closer to the earth in May. You
will want than 55mm lens handy I would think!

Terry

Date:  Fri, 16 Apr 2004 21:06:44 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: Lens for capturing  a  Wide field C/2001Q4
On my webpage you will see 2 images side by side, on the right hand
one you can see a faint wavy tail extend to the top of the frame,
this frame is 7.2 degrees high. On the original un-cropped image I
can trace at least 7 degrees and maybe more. I start to run into
gradient problems trying coax more contrast out the image and will
see if I can get out into a truly dark sky soon!

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

It has been cloudy/rainy since April 15 with more rain predicted for
the next week :(.

Terry 

Date:  Sat, 17 Apr 2004 11:54:40 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Q4 April 17 - Tail 10+ degrees!
An unexpected break in the weather allowed me to get about 30 minutes
exposure with the 300D tonight + 100mm Macro lens. I also opened up
the lens to its full apeture of f2.8. The result was over 10 degrees
of recorded tail (keeping in mind I don't live at a dark site).

I have uploaded the image to me normal web address below.

Terry Lovejoy
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm 

Date:  Sat, 17 Apr 2004 22:36:20 +1000

Great image Terry! It was clear here tonight as well so I decided to go
to a dark sky to view it instead of imaging. I was really impressed to
see a 3 degree tail in 20x80s. Only a week ago I was struggling to get
that length using stacked CCD images!
Keep up the good work.

Date:  Sat, 17 Apr 2004 15:32:41 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Q4 April 17 - Tail 10+ degrees!
Hi Terry,

Great image -- keep `em coming. We Northern Hemisphere folks are
envious.

The high-end camera lenses do not seem to suffer as much when used
wide open on a digital camera as they do when coupled to an IR-
sensitive CCD. My StarlightXpress MX716 covers 420 nm to 1060 nm so
I have to stop down at least two stops to tame the chromatic
aberration.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Sat, 17 Apr 2004 20:12:56 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  T7 - April 17
Conditions were very cloudy this morning, but I was lucky to get a
break in the cloud during twilight that revealed T7. I hurriedly
moved my telescope out to an area that had a clear view of the comet,
hoping my approximate polar alighnment was good enough and made 4 x
30 second exposures. You will also note my neighbours roof and TV
antenna...

Terry
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

soon after I get some sleep, but this quicky demonstrates several
interesting features...

From:  terryjlovejoy

My first observation of T7 this morning was the tail pointing out
from behind a cloud like a search light beam! A very impressive
comet with a small bright coma and relatively intense tail (not as
intense as 2002 V1 was after perihelion but bright none-the-less).

T7 is definitely a more impressive comet than Q4 visually

Superb image Vello...

Thanks Terry. I've updated the page again with the finished product. I
decided to use a cropped hi-res image as there were so many little knots
and filamentary structures, it would have been a shame to resample.
Your colour image shows the anti-tail nicely. I hope you get a some more
clear skies this week as the color images add another dimension. The
blue twilight sky really reminds me of what it's like to be outside
viewing. B&W is ok, but it lacks something.
Cheers,
Vello

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 18 Apr 2004 15:15:51 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 NEAT image. April 17th 2004
Hello all,

C/2001 Q4 NEAT image. Taken on April 17th at 12:28 UT.
10x30 second exposures through a 135mm Hannimex lens at f/5.6 piggybacked on
a C11. Field of View 2x2.5 degrees. Note the short broad dust tail and the
long thin ion tail. Coma size is 12 arcminutes in diameter which translates
to 350,000kms across. Note galaxy NGC 1313 at top right of field.

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Sun, 18 Apr 2004 16:49:53 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2001 Q4 NEAT image. April 17th 2004

>long thin ion tail. Coma size is 12 arcminutes in diameter which translates

It's also quite homogeneous now. No sign of that structure that was
apparent a few days ago. What sort of camera are you using?
Cheers,
Vello

Date:  Sun, 18 Apr 2004 17:54:05 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2002 T7
The images of the comets are just great. I am interested in T7
especially. Vello the detail of your T7 is amazing and I was
wondering if you are anyone had perhaps put your attention to a
closer view of the head area for some faint detail. Of couse it is
only a thought but this comet appears to be under great stress as if
if were being torn in different ways. The comets visible to you in
the south and what could be coming for those in the north has me
looking for new ways to mount more cameras on an already loaded up
mount. Thanks to all. Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 18 Apr 2004 13:49:39 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet C/2004 F4 (Bradfield) in SOHO LASCO C3
If you have not taken a look at the newly discovered
comet Bradfield passing by the sun in the SOHO images,
you are indeed missing a rare site.

http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov/data/realtime/c3/512/latest.gif

The comet tail is warped around the sun and the
streamers in the tail are very detailed in the SOHO
LASCO C3 instrument.

I am looking at the 04/18/2004 1854 image.
http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov/data/realtime/javagif/gifs_tiny/20040418_1854_c3.gif

Fantastic!!! It is out of this world.

If you open this page:

http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov/data/realtime/realtime-c3.html

you can see all the recent images for a quick eyeball
comparison.

The spikes in the head are due to the infamous ccd
camera blooming phenomenon and because of this, it is
estimated that the comet is estimated to be at
magnitude -2. That is based upon several other bright
comets tat passed thoug perihelion while in view on
SOHO. Mercury does this when it passes across the
field of view.

Venus is currently at mag -3
Jupiter is currently at mag -2.3
Saturn is currently at mag +0.8

Compare that.

Comet C/2004 F4 (Bradfield) is currently about halfway
between the moon and sun, and about 4 degrees from the sun.

=====
Charles Bell
Vicksburg, Mississippi USA
32 15' 56" N 90 51' 20" W
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/

Date:  Mon, 19 Apr 2004 20:59:35 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  New Q4 and T7 Images - April 19
Just a quick note to say I have uploaded 2 new images of Comets
C/2001 Q4 (NEAT) and C/2002 T7 (LINEAR) to my web page (URL below).
Both of these were taken with the Canon 300D and Takahashi E160.
Note that transparency was quite bad due to high humidity with T7
being covered by variable thin cloud during imaging.

Date:  Mon, 19 Apr 2004 21:03:12 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  BIG COMET VAPORIZES IN A DISTANT STAR
FYI
BIG COMET VAPORIZES IN A DISTANT STAR

Apr 19, 2004 - Astronomers from Penn State University have spotted a large
comet crashing into a distant star 3,200 light-years away. They used the
9.2-metre Hobby-Eberly Telescope at the McDonald Observatory in Texas to observe star
LkHalpha 234, which is 6 times the mass of the Sun, but only 100,000 years
old. They observed the star several times, and during one observation the light
from the star changed as if it was obscured by cometary material. They were
able to calculate that a 100 km comet must have vaporized near the star to
create this effect.

http://www.universetoday.com/am/publish/big_comet_vaporizes_star.html

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA
FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) ;(http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm);
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com; State of Kansas- Solar System
Ambassador - JPL (Jet Propulsion Lab);
7 total solar eclipses and counting 

Date:  Mon, 19 Apr 2004 20:30:07 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] BIG COMET VAPORIZES IN A DISTANT STAR
This subject is really off-topic for this group.....but:
I have some very serious reservations about accepting such an idea based on "....the light from the star change[ing] as if it were obscured by cometary material...."

The vaporization of a 100km [gasp!] comet at a distance of 3,200 light years would hardly be enough to obscure starlight to the point that it could be measured here on earth. I suppose that if our present Comet Bradfield likewise "vaporizes" next week, there will be zealous observers monitoring the obscuration of our own sun as seen from LkHalpha234.

Just the words "....large comet crashing...." into a star should send red flags out to anyone who reads this material. I for one would be most interested in being witness to our sun being "crashed" by a comet or any other body.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatory
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mt.)
http://www.arksky.org/

From: KCStarguy@aol.com

Subject: [Comet-Images] BIG COMET VAPORIZES IN A DISTANT STAR

FYI
BIG COMET VAPORIZES IN A DISTANT STAR

Apr 19, 2004 - Astronomers from Penn State University have spotted a large
comet crashing into a distant star 3,200 light-years away. They used the
9.2-metre Hobby-Eberly Telescope at the McDonald Observatory in Texas to observe star
LkHalpha 234, which is 6 times the mass of the Sun, but only 100,000 years
old. They observed the star several times, and during one observation the light
from the star changed as if it was obscured by cometary material. They were
able to calculate that a 100 km comet must have vaporized near the star to
create this effect.

http://www.universetoday.com/am/publish/big_comet_vaporizes_star.html

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2004 18:17:00 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New Q4 and T7 Images - April 19
terryjlovejoy wrote:

>Just a quick note to say I have uploaded 2 new images of Comets
>C/2001 Q4 (NEAT) and C/2002 T7 (LINEAR) to my web page (URL below).
>Both of these were taken with the Canon 300D and Takahashi E160.
>Note that transparency was quite bad due to high humidity with T7
>being covered by variable thin cloud during imaging.
>
>Terry
>http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm
>
Beautiful images Terry. I don't know if this is a processing artifact
but T7 looks quite blue compared to Q4, which is more greenish.
Coincidentally perhaps, T7 looks strikingly blue to me through 20x80s.
OTOH, Q4 doesn't seem to be bright enough for me to discern any colour.
Perhaps it's just that it is less condensed and has has a larger coma,
but your camera seems to have picked the difference too...
Cheers,
Vello 

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2004 23:38:42 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 NEAT images April 20th 2004
Hello all,
Please find following updates to my website:

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

1. C/2001 Q4 NEAT CCD image, April 20th 2004 at 10:40UT
30x30second exposures taken through a Celestron C11+Starlight Express MX7c
camera. Flat fielded and gauss equalised to draw out details around the
nucleus.

2. Same photo with the Larsen-Sekania filter applied. This enhances the jets
and shells around the nucleus.

3. C/2001 Q4 NEAT wide field image taken on April 20th at 11:05 UT.
30x30 second exposures through a 135mm Hannimex lens at f/5.6+Starlight
Express MX7c imager piggybacked on a C11. Field of View 1.8x1.5 degrees. The
comet currently appears edge-on to the Earth.

Cheers,
Michael 

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2004 09:39:37 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2001 Q4 NEAT images April 20th 2004

Clay

Dr. P. Clay Sherrod

Express MX7c imager piggybacked on a C11. Field of View 1.8x1.5 degrees. The
comet currently appears edge-on to the Earth.

Cheers,

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2004 21:56:28 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  T7 - April 20.79 - Reply to Vello
Hi guys,

Somewhat better conditions this morning, still a fair amount of water
vapour in the air but I had no trouble seeing the comet naked eye,
even the tail was just visible to the naked eye. Anyway I have
uploaded an image to my webpage using the Canon 300D + 100mm lens.
Next time I will compose the comet better on the frame, as the actual
extent of the tail was more than I had expected (Id say there is
closer to 8-10 degrees of tail).

Interesting note every so often I find an image gets corrupted on the
CF card, this happened this morning when I lost one of my
subexposures.

Vello - Colour balance is something I am still coming to grips with.
I have started to calibrate on stars of spectral type G2 or near, the
image yesterday was perhaps slightly too blue (but this mornings T7
effort should be close). Q4 has definitely got more green (stronger
C2 emmission?).

Terry
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm 

Date:  Wed, 21 Apr 2004 08:31:25 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2001 Q4 NEAT images April 20th 2004
Michael Mattiazzo wrote:

>Hello all,
>Please find following updates to my website:
>
>http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/
>
Michael, Terry and Gianluca,
All amazing images! Hi-scale, low-scale, colour. Great stuff.
Now, if only this damn fog would clear... We've been having glorious
blue-sky autumn days and fog at night :-(
Cheers,
Vello 

Date:  Tue, 20 Apr 2004 23:48:04 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  FYI-Please Read
To The Members.
I am always in contact with different publications around the world
to make them aware of the work being done here by all members. If or
when contacted, I direct anyone interested to the author of the image
in question. Any approval of publication is totally up to and the
responsibly of the author as these are your images. I do think that
by simply bringing the attention of the different publications to the
COMET-IMAGES board, it will benefit the members to get the credit
they deserve for there work.
Thanks Mike H. 

Date:  Wed, 21 Apr 2004 00:41:41 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  congrat Terry and Matt T7 and Q4
Terry and Matt
Congrats. The images are magnificent. I am looking forward to trying to see
our two celestial visitors in a few days from the Northern Hemisphere from the
Arizona and Kansas.
Q4 seems to have a greenish tinge and a very fluffy looking tail . T7 have a
long filmy, sinous tail and appeared with more of a bluish tinge. Is that
correct? Again what caused the greenish tinge and the bluish tinge?

Terry thanks also for communicating the ISO 400 film and other specs about
your camera , exposure etc. Very helpful if we want to try in the near future.

Are there any prognotistications for trying to image with digital cameras? I
hope to use my dimage 7i minolta which has a 10x lens (goes to about 200 mm).
(I was successful using a minolta slr for Hale-Bopp but I hope to do better
with the digital).

Matt about "gauss equalised" do you mean the "gaussian blur " with
photoshop. Please elaborate on the procedure you used as I know little a bit about it.

Matt- can you explain about the Larsen-Sekania filter (what kind is this?)
and how does it work to make that nice photo comparison on your site.

The extra notes and information at
http://www.yp-connect.net/%7Emmatti/
about observing and photographing are nicely done and should be helpful to
anyone who wished to observe this comets now and in the near future from the
Northern Hemisphere or the Southern Hemisphere.

Thanks once again
Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA

***

Terry
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

Message: 5
Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 23:38:42 +0930
From: "Michael Mattiazzo"
Subject: C/2001 Q4 NEAT images April 20th 2004

Hello all,
Please find following updates to my website:

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

1. C/2001 Q4 NEAT CCD image, April 20th 2004 at 10:40UT
30x30second exposures taken through a Celestron C11+Starlight Express MX7c
camera. Flat fielded and gauss equalised to draw out details around the
nucleus.

2. Same photo with the Larsen-Sekania filter applied. This enhances the jets
and shells around the nucleus.

3. C/2001 Q4 NEAT wide field image taken on April 20th at 11:05 UT.
30x30 second exposures through a 135mm Hannimex lens at f/5.6+Starlight
Express MX7c imager piggybacked on a C11. Field of View 1.8x1.5 degrees. The
comet currently appears edge-on to the Earth.

Cheers,
Michael

>> 

Date:  Wed, 21 Apr 2004 05:14:20 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 NEAT images April 20th 2004
Yes - its a real pain. My 14" dewed up by 8pm :-( 35% Humidity at
Sunset and 85% 2 hours later. I was imaging newly discovered C/2004
H1 and had to stop and use the hair dryer 4 times (and I use a dew
heater on its 30 watt setting). This never used to be a problem on
my 10". At magnitude 18.9 I did just get it although it wasn't
pretty.....

I was going to try for Q4 last night but my el cheapo Konus 80mm
Refractor has insufficient back focus for my camera - so much for
their claim to use it as a camera lense! I found an additional 1"
spacer so may have more luck tonight.

Cheers

David Higgins
E14
Canberra, Australia
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Vello Tabur wrote:

Date:  Wed, 21 Apr 2004 16:06:41 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Dew Prevention was Re: C/2001 Q4 NEAT
Hi David,

The larger SCTs tend to dew up worse than the smaller ones. There
is not enough heat flow from the circumference of the corrector into
the center.

A long (2 or 3 x diameter) dew shield will help immensely by
reducing the solid angle for radiating to the cold sky. I use a
tube made out of cardboard and duct taped together for my C-11. The
inside is painted with flat black spray lacquer. The shield and 30
Watts of resistive heating allows me to image with ground fog
present.

I am looking forward to seeing some images from you  it's been a
while since you've posted you work.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "David Higgins"
wrote:

Date:  Wed, 21 Apr 2004 20:26:48 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: congrat Terry and Matt T7 and Q4
Hi,
Dr. Eric, I think you might want to try some test images in the
general part of the sky and time when you will image the comets. My
guess is that film will beat the P&S digitals and probably most
digital SLRs. CCD will probably beat both. My reasoning is that film
and CCD allow longer exposures, in addition, CCD has higher
sensitivity. I believe that these will capture the faint tail better.
People have been having a lot of success with Canon DSLRs at 5 to 10
min exposures. I am going to be trying the same thing if I can get my
mount tracking in time. I will run test shots first.
Hope this helps.
Rick

Date:  Wed, 21 Apr 2004 21:27:59 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  T7 - April 21.79 UT
Some times luck goes your way. Just before dawn the sky began to
clear and transparency improved dramatically. So much so that I
could see the zodiacal light quite clearly (unusual here) and T7
could be seen with the naked eye complete with about 3 degrees of
tail. In binoculars about 6 degrees of tail could be seen

Anyway I got a 16 minute exposure (4x4 min) with the 300D and 100mm
Macro lens. The comet also looks as if it just at the onset of a tail
disconnection .

Images are at:
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

Terry 

Date:  Thu, 22 Apr 2004 00:33:32 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Dew Prevention was Re: C/2001 Q4 NEAT
Hi Dennis,

I was without equipment for 3 months waiting for a wedge to arrive
then another 2 weeks for the wedge to clear customs :-(

I'm back but doing faint objects (magnitudes 17 to 20) primarily
NEO's and comets. I imaged Q4 through the 14" but it was too bright
even with a 5 second exposure. I'm still trying to get my
piggybacked scopes (4" SCT and 80mm Konus Refractor) up and running.

Still in test phase. MaxIm CCD and my MX716 just no longer wish to
work together when guiding so I'm no longer automated :-( so I am
back to around 5-10 objects a night.

Cheers

David

Date:  Thu, 22 Apr 2004 05:07:01 -0000
From:  djhanson100 
Subject:  Re: congrat Terry and Matt T7 and Q4
IMO the best comet images are taken with Schmidt cameras using film
and not with CCD. Ideal FOV and fast...Some good examples of this
exist in the spaceweather.com photo archives of Ikeya Zhang:

http://www.spaceweather.com/comets/gallery_iz.html

It's also a great source to compare various comet imaging
techniques:)

--DJ

> My guess is that film will beat the P&S digitals and probably most
> digital SLRs. CCD will probably beat both. My reasoning is that
film and CCD allow longer exposures, in addition, CCD has higher
> sensitivity. I believe that these will capture the faint tail
better.

John Drummond

Date:  Thu, 22 Apr 2004 23:01:00 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  T7 mosaic - April 21.8
Here is a mosaic stitched together from two 10 minute images taken in
fog! Where there's a will....
It was taken around the same time as Terry's excellent colour image.
Visually the coma was just barely visible to the naked eye and only 1
degree of tail was visible in 20x80s, in contrast to the pristine
conditions in Brisbane. Hey, isn't it supposed to be raining up there?!
;-)

http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2002t7/2002t7.htm

Cheers,
Vello 

Date:  Thu, 22 Apr 2004 23:09:00 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] congrat Terry and Matt T7 and Q4
Hello Eric,

I neglected to mention that I use Astroart 2 in the image processing.
The Gauss equalization is a histogram function providing very high contrast
to the image.
This allows faint structure to be seen.
The Larsen-Sekania filter is more properly described elsewhere on the net.
It is used to enhance jets and shells around the nucleus.

Regards,
Michael Mattiazzo

> photoshop. Please elaborate on the procedure you used as I know little a
bit about it.

Date:  Thu, 22 Apr 2004 17:58:53 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: congrat Terry and Matt T7 and Q4
DJ,
Schmidt camera is probably very good for this. Why do you think film
would be better? I think film is higher resolution and has better
color response, but I think that sensitivity and reciprocity would
out weigh the resolution and color. I think it really comes down to
how long do you need to capture the wispy tail detail. If that time
is 1 minute, then I agreee that film would win hands down, but as
exposure goes past 1 min on most films, the reciprocity starts
cutting into effective response. I am talking about standard films
such as E-200. I belive that hypered films give fantastic response to
color for these images, based on images that I have seen on HaleBopp.
If you have any more data, please share with us. Maybe someone will
do an apples to apples comparison on these 2 comets.
Happy comet hunting,
Rick
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "djhanson100"
wrote:
> IMO the best comet images are taken with Schmidt cameras using film
> and not with CCD. Ideal FOV and fast...Some good examples of this
> exist in the spaceweather.com photo archives of Ikeya Zhang:
>
> http://www.spaceweather.com/comets/gallery_iz.html
>
> It's also a great source to compare various comet imaging
> techniques:)
>
> --DJ
>
> > My guess is that film will beat the P&S digitals and probably
most
> > digital SLRs. CCD will probably beat both. My reasoning is that
> film and CCD allow longer exposures, in addition, CCD has higher
> > sensitivity. I believe that these will capture the faint tail
> better.

Date:  Thu, 22 Apr 2004 18:50:24 -0000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  Comet F4 Pic
Image of C/2004 F4 by Michael Jaeger taken this morning.
2004 Apr 22, 180mm Apo-Tele f/3.3
70 min prior sunrise, 14 deg elongation
6x4 sec with red filter.

Date:  Fri, 23 Apr 2004 06:35:39 +0930
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  wide field colour images T7 and Q4 19th UT
Hi all
Wellll!!! what a revolution! - dont think there will be a comet imager left
who doesnt own a nice DSLR/CCD before very long! :-) Congrats to the
stunning work that all you guys are doing - god help the unsuspecting comets
that come this way from now on - the days of scant (but excellent) coverage
are long gone. ( i mean, imaging through clouds and fog for goodness sake!!
love it!)

Please find our humble offerings on emulsion from morning of 20th april (19
UT) at

Also we had much foggy nebulosity to photograph through for T7 on the 20th.

Notes on session from dark site - first session after weeks of mostly clouds
-
we were easily able to see, conservatively, .5 deg of bright anti-tail in
8x56 binos (used field of view of binos 6.25* ) on T7 with an easy main tail
of 4 deg. and about a degree of main tail naked eye. We kind of lost it when
we saw T7 for first time, and didnt take many images - due to trying to
drink in the views through varies means - and swinging from one comet to
another :-)) Q4 had about a faint 5* tail in binos. The binocular views
seemed better than our images- strange?
second morning patchy clouds came in at very last minute >:( - but Q4 was
noticebly brighter and had slightly larger coma to naked eye - but couldnt
see much antitail on T7 in binos second morning (wed), but T7 looked
brighter with longer main tail of 6* (B) and still ~1* naked eye tail.

Amazing too how T7 leaps out of the page, figuratively speaking, more and
more (when viewing it) as it climbs every half a degree of elevation - could
be a very serious comet eh

heres hoping for lots of dust production and the comets getting big enough
to make for some interesting colour photographs.

Cheers
Kearn 

Date:  Fri, 23 Apr 2004 03:50:54 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: New Q4 and T7 Images - April 19
Terry,
Are you tracking on a star or on the comet head? What mount are you
using? I am going to attempt taking some images when it comes up here
(California). I will have to drive to get to dark skies, so I will
need to have everything figured out before I get there.
Thanks, Rick

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "terryjlovejoy"
wrote:
> Just a quick note to say I have uploaded 2 new images of Comets
> C/2001 Q4 (NEAT) and C/2002 T7 (LINEAR) to my web page (URL
below).
> Both of these were taken with the Canon 300D and Takahashi E160.
> Note that transparency was quite bad due to high humidity with T7
> being covered by variable thin cloud during imaging.
>
> Terry
> http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

Bradfield, which we captured this morning with CCD and telelens.

Gerald and Michael
www.astrostudio.at 

Date:  Fri, 23 Apr 2004 21:44:38 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Interesting Link
Did I hear somebody say that Schmidt cameras + film are best for
comets?

Looks like the schmidts have some serious competition ->

Have a look at this ST11K + Tak FSQ106 shot:

http://starryscapes.com/tmp/Neat_large.jpg

Terry 

Date:  Fri, 23 Apr 2004 22:14:37 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: New Q4 and T7 Images - April 19
Rick,

I am using a custom mount purchased off a well know local amateur.
It was much cheaper than any commercial mount available :).

I am taking relative short exposures guiding at siderial rate (i.e
tracking stars). The exposures are stacked aligned on the comet.

Regards,
Terry 

Date:  Fri, 23 Apr 2004 22:14:48 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: New Q4 and T7 Images - April 19
Rick,

I am using a custom mount purchased off a well know local amateur.
It was much cheaper than any commercial mount available :).

I am taking relative short exposures guiding at siderial rate (i.e
tracking stars). The exposures are stacked aligned on the comet.

Regards,
Terry 

Date:  Fri, 23 Apr 2004 22:28:40 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: New Q4 and T7 Images - April 19
Terry, Thanks a lot. I think that trying to set my tracking on the
stars is a good starting point for me based on your results and
comments. If I come even close to your results, I will be happy!
Thanks, Rick

some other super comet images with that 8" Schmidt:)

Date:  Sat, 24 Apr 2004 12:10:34 +0200
From:  skorupa@t-online.de
Subject:  correction of photo of comet bradfield 24th april
Hello,

after getting some sleep and a good breakfast I corrected the image on http://www.schweifstern.de/f4-24042004-ws.jpg

The stacked images didn't increased the captured tail lenght. So I took only one 60s image into account.

Thanks
Waldemar

Date:  Sun, 25 Apr 2004 09:32:18 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - 04/25/2004
After weeks of clouds and over 9 inches of rain in the past 4 days, I
did manage to capture 2003 K4 before the fog set in. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/1A81311C372AFE3/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 25 Apr 2004 14:39:30 +0200
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: 25 April F4 and T3.
I too confirm your observation of C/2003 T3 (Tabur). Today C/2004 F4 was
impressive in 7x50 binoculars. Before the start
of astronomical twilight, with the comet's head under the horizon, the
curved 11.5-deg long dust tail protuded up above the Cantabrian
Mountains ridge. As a plus, the dimmer and close C/2003 T3 (Tabur ) was
visually observed through that tail. A sight to remember ...

C/2004 F4 (Bradfield):
2004 Apr. 25.15 UT: m1=3.7, Dia.=2', DC=8, Tail: 11.5 deg. in PA 300
deg,7x50B [ Naked eye: m1=4.0, Tail: 8.5 deg.. Mountain location, very
clear sky. Magnitude estimate corrected for atmospheric extinction with
ICQ winter table. Low
altitude. Beginning of astronomical twilight. ]

C/2002 T7 (LINEAR):
2004 Apr. 25.17 UT: m1=4.4, Dia.=3', DC=7, Tail: 0.2 deg. in PA 255 deg
11x80B. [ Magnitude estimate corrected
for atmospheric extinction. Low altitude. Beginning of nautical twilight
].

C/2003 T3 (Tabur):
2004 Apr. 25.16 UT: m1=9.6, Dia.=2', DC=3, 20 cm SCT (77x). [ Observed
through the tail of the close C/2004 F4 (Bradfield) ].

Best regards,

J. J. Gonzalez - Spain

--------------------------------

Date:  Sun, 25 Apr 2004 11:53:59 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - 04/25/2004
Greetings
I finally was able to capture K4 distinctly on my images 4/21/2004. It is on
my astronomy homepage. Click on the pulldown window latest images and scroll
at the page to #18. I a little surprised how bright it was. Each exposure 60
seconds 1 hour 28 minutes apart using Harvard microobseratory telescope near
Tucson.

Date:  Mon, 26 Apr 2004 06:26:02 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  T7 mosaic - April 25.79
Hi,
Here is a new image of T7 from this morning. The morphology continues to
impress and the overall brightness is increasing. Easily saw 5+ degrees
of tail in 20x80s from my suburban site, although only 1 degree was
visible to the naked eye (with averted vision). The zodiacal light did
interfere with the contrast though...

http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2002t7/2002t7.htm

Cheers,
Vello 

Date:  Mon, 26 Apr 2004 00:23:55 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: T7 mosaic - April 25.79
Vello. That is an amazing image. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 27 Apr 2004 09:57:44 +1200
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  C/2002 T7 - 26 April 2004
Hi all,

managed to drag myself out of bed at 4.30am this morning to photograph Comet 2002 T7 (LINEAR) in the eastern morning sky. I piggybacked the Canon EOS 10D with a 150mm f4.5 lens on it. The two linked photos show the result (note the 'antitail' at 5 oclock). I have overenhanced the second image to bring out the tail. I was battling high cloud and the zodiacal light - and a low (13*) elevation...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-04-04-26.htm

My observation of it is:

2002 T7 (LINEAR) 2004 April 26.71 UT: m1 = ~4.3, Dia.= ~6'.0, DC = 7, Tail = 4* PA 252* 10x50B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [T7 low in pre-dawn eastern sky. Bright with a nice longish tail - at least 4* long. Compact head - easily seen with naked eye. Contended with zodiacal light and some high cloud. Comet's alt is 13* in the ENE.].

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz 

Date:  Mon, 26 Apr 2004 22:22:02 -0000
From:  perryhelion 
Subject:  FYI Bradfield images
Hi all -

There is currently a very nice image of Comet Bradfield on
spaceweather.com taken by Sho Endo, as well as images taken by
several other people. The specific link to Sho's image is at:

http://science.nasa.gov/spaceweather/swpod2004/25apr04/Endo1.jpg

- Mitch

Date:  Tue, 27 Apr 2004 18:50:54 +0200
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  C/2004 F4 (Bradfield ) - Apr 27.14 color image.
C/2004 F4 (Bradfield ) + Eta Andromedae - Apr 27.14 UT.
Original image taken from Cantabrian Mountains, Alto del Castro ( 1717 m
), Leon, Spain.
Nikkor 50 mm f/1.8 lens, 25 s exposure on Fuji Superia 800 color
positive film.

( uploaded to Comet-Images Files folder )

Best regards,

J. J. Gonzalez

Date:  Tue, 27 Apr 2004 23:26:51 +0200
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Corrigendum. C/2004 F4 (Bradfield ) - Apr 27.14 color image.
Corrigendum:

On my previous mail *for* Eta And *read* Beta And , the brightest star
in the field.

Sorry. Obviously, the dimmer Eta And is also in the image. This star was
observed some days before close to C/2004 F4 and with similar magnitude.
After three nights observing the path of the comet in the twilight, the
words " from Eta to Beta And " are almost a label in the sky ...

Best regards,

J. J. Gonzalez

Well with some trees about 1/2 mile away and the Sun showing light on
the horizion, I went ahead and aimed the scope to where T7 was. Not
an award winner, but it was good to see this comet on my chip again.
3x15 sec exp. FOV 74x56 arc-min. I also spent 30 minutes on F4 this
time trying for darker sky and color info. It will take a lot of
computer time to put it together if possible. Thanks, Mike

Date:  Thu, 29 Apr 2004 14:58:46 +0930
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2004 F4 Mosaic - 04272004
I agree Vello! they indeed have a very beautiful stunning classic comet to
enjoy, any southerners jumped on a plane yet?
i find it bizarre that, in that last few years, everytime we get a nice
comet, suddenly some nice thoughtful person finds a nice comet for the
northerners to enjoy! i am referring of course to when C/2000 WM1 had its
break up and jumped to mag. 2.5 at the end of jan 2002, all of a sudden
Ikeya Zhang appeared out of nowhere! (mind you, it had skirted just outside
of some of our widefield images from dec2001, jan 2002 at up to mag 9
prediscovery ;-) )

I was wondering are these the first such occasions that this has happened,
or has it happened before? seems the odds are very stacked against such
co-incidences i would think?. or are they coming in batches now?

I also see reports that some people are seeing Bradfield and T7 naked eye at
same time from some northern latitudes. Can anyone tell me when this has
happened before - where both hemispheres have two naked eye comets available
to them at the same time?

Cheers
Kearn

Date:  Thu, 29 Apr 2004 16:29:30 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comet C/2004 F4-color
I am going to post an image that I've had a tough time with. Many
times I thought about discarding the color info all together. This
is a composit of 4 74x56 arc-min frames. Each of the four is a
combination of 12 subframes RGBLx3 each. I have got this so spread
out in so many files that I have lost track and will probably just
start over. The strange thing is the way the color changes as the
comet faned out. I have not been able to correct this and am
wondering if it is true color. I will also discard the color and
compose a rgbl filtered grayscale mosaic in the future. Thanks, Mike
H.
http://www.fototime.com/F972A60FFA284E3/orig.jpg

Date:  Fri, 30 Apr 2004 13:00:10 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  NEAT mosaic
Here is a 12 panel mosaic of Q4 passing the LMC on April 25. It's a bit
dated now because of the amount of processing effort I had to put in.
I'm still not completely happy with it, but if your turn the contrast
down a bit it looks half decent.

Who said pretty pictures were easy? Each panel of the mosaic is a stack
of 10x30sec images. Each stacked image was then gradient corrected by
overlaying a 64x64 pixel grid and calculating the background intensity
in each cell of the grid. With that value, each cell was corrected to
remove the gradient. Then an astrometric solutuion was calculated for
each panel and they were aligned /stiched into a 6000 x 4000 pixel
mosaic. But (and there' always a but), the panels containing the LMC had
no "empty sky" to calculate/interpolate a background value, so the
gradient could not be removed without removing most of the LMC too. So I
resorted to using other images taken at similar alt/az to calc the
gradient and then corrected the LMC panels with the same grid. This left
some unsightly seams which had to be balanced manually. By this stage I
was just about ready to admit defeat, but I managed to salvage something...

You might be asking why I didn't use a shorter focal length lens in the
first place? Well I have overhead powerlines very close to my
observatory and they would have interfered. Instead I had to wait until
each field cleared the lowest power line and then took the images.

http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2001q4/2001q4.htm

Vello 

Date:  Fri, 30 Apr 2004 04:47:55 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  Re: NEAT mosaic
Well if you were going to that much trouble the least you could have
done was put in some colour filters :-)

As usual Vello - VERY nice image (Its now my desktop image).

Cheers

David

Date:  Sat, 01 May 2004 05:20:41 +0930
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  C/2002 T7 LINEAR - photo tail query
Hi All
I have uploaded a 300K file to the file section of this site.

We have detected what looks like a large split tail (same as Vello Tabur
Picture from same morning) and what seems like quite considerable tails on
T7 for in our photos from morning of april 26th 2004 (26.74 UT). i thought
that they were a strange effect from poor photo lab processing , maybe
chemicals to old or used to much, with a roller wheel track through them.
But the q4 shots are from the same roll and they seem normal enough.

But when we looked closer we are not completely sure as what to make of it.
i havent got time to get them reprocessed at the moment, so i was hoping
some brave soul would have a crack at determining whats tail and whats not.
That would be much appreciated if possible. if the larger tail is real it
goes out of the photo in that case. please contact me off list if you can
help. belatrix@ozemail.com.au

Image is 10 minute exposure on 800 speed film 105mm lens 35mmm camera -
taken through vary thicknesses of thin cloud. cloud obscures fair bit of
image, including tails at end. Comet was at around 15.5 * altitude.

Cheers
Kearn

these possible features -

Date:  Sat, 01 May 2004 12:08:56 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Comet Bradfield tele and observations 4/27,4/28

David and all

I did not have any luck 4/26 but I did this morning 4/27. I camped out on a
ridge West of I-69 on 167 street ( off of 151 st East of Olathe, KS near Kansas
City, USA for those not in KC)

At 4:45 to a little after 5, I could see the comet very low on the horizon,
to the north of the Big Square of Pegasis, while using my binoculars. There
was a bright sparkling nucleus with a hazy shimmering tail streaming faint
above. The tail however looked like a fan shaped while looking in the binoculars
and I could not detect a longer tail streaming above because possibly a few
lights way off in the distance near the horizon.

I wanted to take a digital picture but it was getting too light out and some
of the lights in the distance would make it difficult.

I was hoping to see it before it gets too faint so that I sketch if for the
Comett Award Gold award I am trying to obtain. While I know I could get a photo
later with more powerful telescopes, I would like to still try in the next
few days from Powell Observatory now that I know we can see it that low from
there. But at least I have a sketch now that I can put up on the award site I
made for my Gold award which I am trying to nail down by May or June.

4/28 I headed to Louisbourg observatory (20 minutes south of Kansas City on
4/28) and met up with David Hudgins. He was trying to find the comet with his
MUkatov 5 inch telescope and I with binoculars. It was really windy and it
seemed that the windy was picking up some stuff into the sky so that is was more
difficult to look for the comet then the morning before.

We finally found the comet with his telescope around 4:55. The nucleus was
hazy and the tail streamed out away upward through the length of the eyepiece
view. It was too murky to try with my digital camera. I knew that for the next
few days it would be cloudy and/or rainy so I will have to try again later.

Meanwhile check out the magnificent pictures with APOD (Astronomy Pictures of
the Day-http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/astropix.html) and Spaceweather-
http://spaceweather.com. Excellent.

We did not see T7. I am looking forward to the return of T7 and seeing Q4.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com, dreric1kansas@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA

FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) ;(http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm);
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com; State of Kansas- Solar
>webmaster, Satori Astronomy website

System Ambassador - JPL (Jet Propulsion Lab);
7 total solar eclipses and counting:
webmaster Eric's Black Sun Eclipse website -
>webmaster, Satori Astronomy website
-editor- Black Sun eclipse newsletter
(eclipse/astronomy news) to subscribe send email to
blacksuneclipse-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

**

Date: Tue, 27 Apr 2004 14:15:52 -0500
From: George Allen
Subject: Re: comet bradfield

Living on a dark, country hilltop is great. We got up at 4:40, put on
our robes, staggered out onto the east porch, binocs in hand, and found
Comet Bradfield. Watched it and M31 until the dawn got in the way,
went back to bed happy, back to sleep at 5:15.

George 'n' JoDee
**

quad

Message: 1

Date: Mon, 26 Apr 2004 07:28:28 -0500

From: "Doug Kniffen"

Subject: Comet Bradfield (2004 F4) this morning

Went out just before 4:30am, because I can't check the sky to the east from
inside anymore. There were roughly parallel streaks of clouds drifting in from
the north west.and the apparent point of convergence was unfortunately quite
near the azimuth of the comet. However there were quite a few seemingly cloud
less areas and most of the sky seemed clear. Since the light blocker around the
Not a very good location either due to the closest dusk to dawn (blocked from
view but only150 feet away) being near the azimuth for viewing the comet, and
the slightly foggy morning made that wonderful orange glow extend up past
zenith. The degree of cloudiness increased rapidly during the minutes used to "set
up".

A narrow clear spot between the clouds finally let the comet be seen a few
minutes before 5:00am, though it seemed like the "clear spot" wasn't really all
that clear. Bradfield's head appeared only a few arc minutes across, with very
little coma surrounding a fairly bright (mag. 3) pseudo nucleus. There was
obvious structure seen in the tail of the comet, which appeared to extend a
little less than 5 degrees. The visible tail appeared to be ion alone, not even a
suggestion of dust tail was seen. After a few minutes the clouds again covered
the comet.

While waiting to see if another clear spot crossed the area of the comet,
movement was noticed up in the north western part of the sky. Quickly turning the
20X80's to track the moving bright object it was possible to view nearly an
entire pass of the ISS. Most interesting to notice that during several brief
periods it was possible to determine the orientation of the space station
because one could clearly distinguish between the crew modules and the solar panels.
After this, attention was again given to the comet, but it was not recovered
due to the thin clouds and increasing twilight.

Considering the viewing conditions this morning (light pollution, poor
transparency, and low object altitude) this comet may well have been "naked eye"
from a better (really dark) observing location.

Doug Kniffen 

Date:  Sun, 02 May 2004 03:56:17 +0930
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2002 T7 LINEAR - photo tail query

the processing that caused that line, and i have removed the file from the
site. Need to be awake when doing such things and hitting send - bit sleep
starved of late -

regards
Kearn 

Date:  Sun, 02 May 2004 17:18:51 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  C/2002 T7 - May 1.8
Greetings,
Here is a shot of T7 from this morning. It was a very clear, frosty
morning with the zodiacal light visible from my suburban backyard.
Adding to the spectacle were a few bright eta Aquarids leaving glowing
trains. T7's tail now extends beyond a three frame mosaic, over 10 degrees!
http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2002t7/2002t7.htm

Date:  Sun, 02 May 2004 14:46:57 -0000
From:  deanjacobsen 
Subject:  Fiirst attempt at C/2004 F7 Bradfield - CCD Image
Hi All,

Here's my first attempt at comet imaging. [Hopefully I'll get plenty
more chances in the next few weeks.] ;-)

http://www.astrophoto.net/c2004f4bradfield.html

The details:

SBIG ST-2000 XM
Nikon 50 mm lens at f/2
90 second exposure

Comments and constructive criticism are welcome.

Dean Jacobsen
www.astrophoto.net 

Date:  Sun, 02 May 2004 23:51:26 -0000
From:  deanjacobsen 
Subject:  First attempt at C/2004 F7 Bradfield - animation added.
Hi again,

I've been forging new ground today and learned how to make a .gif
animation using 25 minutes of 60 second images as I was tracking the
comet rising from the horizon. ...a lot of work but fun...

The animation is posted below the previously posted images on the
same page:

http://www.astrophoto.net/c2004f4bradfield.html

Thanks for looking.

Dean Jacobsen
www.astrophoto.net

> Dean Jacobsen
> www.astrophoto.net 

Date:  Sun, 02 May 2004 18:06:34 -0800
From:  Michael Caligiuri 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] First attempt at C/2004 F7 Bradfield - animation added.
Dean -- great animation. Shows so much more variation in light path from the
tail than a static shot. I'm in Carlsbad and didn't realise this comet was
visible. You've motivated me to at least take a look early this week. Thanks
for the posting.

-Mike

Date:  Mon, 03 May 2004 01:46:52 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: C/2002 T7 - May 1.8
Vello,

When I saw your image it looked like the tail goes well beyond the
edge of the frame. Inspired by your mosaic I tried a 2 panel end-end
mosaic with the 300D this morning to get about a 22 degree wide field
of view with the 100mm f2.8 lens, just to see how long the tail
extends. Here is the result:

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/2002T7_may2_2004.htm

The negative

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/2002T7_may2_2004_neg.htm

The details are on the main page, but are:

Comet C/2002 T7 (LINEAR) 2 panel mosaic image May 2.79 UT, 2004. The
tail can be traced 21 degrees (see negative version). 12 minutes of
exposure near head and 20 minutes exposure at tail end using a Canon
EOS 300D at ISO 400 and Canon EF 100mm f2.8 macro.

Best,

Date:  Mon, 03 May 2004 22:30:25 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2002 T7 - May 1.8
terryjlovejoy wrote:

>Vello,
>
>When I saw your image it looked like the tail goes well beyond the
>edge of the frame. Inspired by your mosaic I tried a 2 panel end-end
>mosaic with the 300D this morning to get about a 22 degree wide field
>of view with the 100mm f2.8 lens, just to see how long the tail
>extends.
>

Well done Terry. Yes, it does extend to the edge of the frame, although
the positive image doesn't show it as well as a negative. I thought
three fields should do it, but when I processed the images it just kept
on going :-) I'm a bit surprised to see that you've captured this much
tail though. I had a look at it from a dark site this morning, and while
nice, the tail does fade fairly quickly after the first 5 degrees or so.
It looks like the rest of it is quite low surface brightness; the domain
the long exposure photographs unfortunately...
Cheers,
Vello

Date:  Tue, 04 May 2004 16:30:55 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C2004 F4 Bradfield from 43 N Lat
I imaged F4 Bradfield under difficult conditions on the 3rd of May.
By the time the comet cleared the trees in my yard, its elevation
was 15.5 degrees and it was noticeably light out, being 21 minutes
past twilight. There was a full moon. I did manage to capture a 45
arc minute long tail, limited only by the FOV of my E160 scope and
MX716 camera.

I was fighting sun rise and Mie scattering off of the smog overlying
Chicago, so I could only acquire for 100 seconds before reaching a
background of 29000 ADU (out of 65K) with the MX716. When I do this
again, I will limit the sky background to a much lower value as I
think I was getting some saturation effects.

Positive image, negative image and isophotes at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

I welcome comments from everyone. Thanks for looking.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Tue, 04 May 2004 19:23:16 -0000
From:  deanjacobsen 
Subject:  Re: C2004 F4 Bradfield from 43 N Lat
Excellent image with the E-160 Dennis.

I had planned to try and capture NEAT this weekend with my E-160 and
the SBIG ST-2000XM

Best,

Dean Jacobsen
www.astrophoto.net

Date:  Tue, 04 May 2004 23:43:10 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comet C/2003 T3 - Tabur
Greetings. On the 27th of April I attempted to put T3 & F4 in the
same fov. I recorded the images but was unable to alighn the stars
and so did not complete the mosaic. I wanted to post the images of
C/2003 T3. Listed at mag. 9.7 at the time of this image it was much
fainter than I was expecting. The recent comets have already spoiled
me. The image link is a composit of 7x15 sec exp with a negative
inset. I am now heading out to the observatory for my first look at
Q4. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/76B1A7321B67425/orig.jpg

Through full Moon and very low, dusty skys I did see the comet. No
details tonight and it was just to low to be much more than a bright
spot but that will change over the next few weeks. 10x15 sec images -
4" ref - 74x56 arc-min fov. Thanks, Mike H.

perhaps I had captured an anti-tail, but the image was very noisy
and I was not sure if it was real or an artifact. I will play around
with the processing some more to see what I can bring out. It is
tough imaging it from 43 N Lat under a full moon!

Dennis

Date:  Thu, 06 May 2004 03:49:07 -0000
From:  David Higgins 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 Larsen-Sekanina
Well every time I tried to image Q4 it was just too bright. I put
the little MX615 on the back of my 80mm f/5 Konus POS refracter and
took around 100 0.3sec exposures then median combined them using
track and stack.

Still didn't show much so ran it by the AstroArt 3 Larsen-Sekanina
filter and got some detail to reveal itself - a couple of shells and
a hint of tail as seen here:

http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj/C2001Q4-LS1.jpg
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj/C2001Q4-LS2.jpg

Note that I was imaging at 6"/pixel resolution (seeing was about
4.5"). Latest astrometry put it slightly ahead of predicted
position (around 1.3')

Cheers

David Higgins
E14
Canberra, Australia
http://users.bigpond.com/higginsdj 

Date:  Thu, 06 May 2004 04:31:17 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Q4/T7 Updates May 5, 2004
I have updated my page with new images of T7 (May 5 - mostly during
the full moon and beginning of lunar eclipse) and Q4 (May 3). T7 is
going to be a Q4 beater in a week or so I would say.

I was amazed to get the detail I did in Q4, especially with just
530mm Focal length. If you look carefully there appears to be a trace
of a 3rd hood.

I also took an image May 6 of Q4 with a telephoto lens and was a
little dissappointed to see only a short tail and little trace of the
ion tail that was prominent in April.

There some photos of the lunar eclipse as well.

Terry
http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/southern.htm

Date:  Fri, 07 May 2004 17:05:18 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  F4 Bradfield Antitail
My F4 Bradfield image of 3 May, 2004, shows a 1.5 arc minute
antitail. Juan Lucruz http://www.geocities.com/juan_lacruz/ was the
first to point it out in my original image posting. I have since
reprocessed the image to better illustrate the antitail.

Images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

How common are antitails? This was my first.

I welcome comments from everyone. Thanks for looking.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Fri, 07 May 2004 23:28:09 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Q4 and F4 pictures
I took a 1 minute exposure from Tucson, AZ at 5/5 with the Harvard telescope
I work with. The nice long tail is well highlighted.

Meanwhile Q4, I also took at picture of it last night 5/6 and the brightening
was dramatic now closing in towards its closest point to the sun. The coma
is much wider and now fan shaped. The nucleus was much rounder and bigger.

>From the ground, in Olathe, KS on 5/7 the comet was below A monerocus. Easily
visible with binoculars with the wider tail just south of I-35.

Both of these pictures are on the left of my homepage. More are coming at the
other comet pages.
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/satoriastronomy.htm

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com, dreric1kansas@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA
FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) ;(http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm);
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com; State of Kansas- Solar
>webmaster, Satori Astronomy website

System Ambassador - JPL (Jet Propulsion Lab);
7 total solar eclipses and counting

Date:  Sat, 08 May 2004 19:11:54 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Documenting Images
There have been some requests from other groups for info on FOV for
imaging comets. I'd like to suggest that as courtesy to your image
viewers, you provide a bit of documentation with your image
postings.

Please try to supply as many of the following data as you can:
1. Date and time (UTC)
2. Location
3. Scope focal length and camera used
4. Image FOV
5. Image scale arc seconds per pixel
6. Image orientation  North up and East left is conventional
7. Image acquisition details
8. Image processing details

I know this is a heck of a lot of work the first time you compile
all of the information. But once you have it for just one image, you
can cut and paste and edit the items for successive images and it
goes real fast. Please give it a try. We will all benefit from more
documentation.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm 

Date:  Sun, 09 May 2004 03:48:38 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4-05/09/2004
High thin clouds made imaging tough. This is a 5x30 sec stack with a
fov of 74x56 arc min. N is up. I think now that 30 sec exp's are
too long as the comet is moving on. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/B6FEE64D2D03723/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 09 May 2004 01:57:49 -0700
From:  Eric 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 2004-05-09 San Carlos, California
Had a surprise clear night after a cloudy day. Pulled out the scope for
a piggyback session. Imaged comet at approx. 20 degrees altitude, 14x60
second images at ISO 800, 70mm f/4 (with 24-70 mm f/2.8L), Canon 10D,
median combined:

http://pics.regolith.net/album39/Combined_FilesMED_str2

Same sequence, aligned on coma instead:

http://pics.regolith.net/album39/coma_adpadd

Some glow is apparent in the images due to nearby lights.

Processing was done in ImagesPlus.

Eric 

Date:  Sun, 09 May 2004 08:32:49 -0400
From:  "J. Pierce" 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] C/2001 Q4 2004-05-09 San Carlos, California
Eric,

Very nice image. I like the colors and wide field.

John Pierce
Tidewater Farm Observatory
http://home.comcast.net/~jgpierce

From: Eric [mailto:yh@regolith.net]
Sent: Sunday, May 09, 2004 4:58 AM
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2001 Q4 2004-05-09 San Carlos, California

Had a surprise clear night after a cloudy day. Pulled out the scope for
a piggyback session. Imaged comet at approx. 20 degrees altitude, 14x60
second images at ISO 800, 70mm f/4 (with 24-70 mm f/2.8L), Canon 10D,
median combined:

http://pics.regolith.net/album39/Combined_FilesMED_str2

Same sequence, aligned on coma instead:

http://pics.regolith.net/album39/coma_adpadd

Some glow is apparent in the images due to nearby lights.

Processing was done in ImagesPlus.

Eric

Subject:  Documenting Images
Dennis
I would like to second those thoughts. While I don't mind asking for
someone's information, it is nice to everyone who puts out their nice pictures to
consistently send additional information. I know it takes time but it helps all of
us.
I have placed some information on my email messages and on my webpages but I
need to be consistent with that too.
Digital scale is tough for me though.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com, dreric1kansas@aol.com),

Date: Sat, 08 May 2004 19:11:54 -0000

From: "Dennis Persyk"

Subject: Documenting Images

There have been some requests from other groups for info on FOV for

imaging comets. I'd like to suggest that as courtesy to your image

viewers, you provide a bit of documentation with your image

postings.

Please try to supply as many of the following data as you can:

1. Date and time (UTC)

2. Location

3. Scope focal length and camera used

4. Image FOV

5. Image scale arc seconds per pixel

6. Image orientation – North up and East left is conventional

7. Image acquisition details

8. Image processing details

I know this is a heck of a lot of work the first time you compile

all of the information. But once you have it for just one image, you

can cut and paste and edit the items for successive images and it

goes real fast. Please give it a try. We will all benefit from more

documentation.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net

Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm 

Date:  Sun, 09 May 2004 16:51:15 -0400

Date:  Mon, 10 May 2004 09:32:39 +1200
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Documenting Images
Dennis (and Dr Flescher),

I also agree. These are very valid points. The first thing I look for with a new image is the photographic details - those listed by Dennis below. Sometimes a non-texted image of a comet appears and I wonder if that tail is 2* or 22*...

I have been collecting various images of Q4 and T7 posted on this group in a folder for later parousal and am always stocked when the person puts the details as text on the photo (so they appear when 'saving images'). It takes a minute or two, sure, but can be sped up by creating a Word Document page with a template of photographic details on it and then copying/pasting onto the image - and changing any necessary details (date, scope, ISO, etc).

If text on an image is seen as unsightly perhaps the image can be saved in two personal modes - one with text and one without...

For an example see...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2002t7(linear)-040426-06.jpg
or...
http://tinyurl.com/2368q

(although I should have added processing data)

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Dennis

someone's information, it is nice to everyone who puts out their nice pictures to
consistently send additional information. I know it takes time but it helps all of
us.
I have placed some information on my email messages and on my webpages but I
need to be consistent with that too.
Digital scale is tough for me though.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com,
Date: Sat, 08 May 2004 19:11:54 -0000

From: "Dennis Persyk"

Subject: Documenting Images

There have been some requests from other groups for info on FOV for

imaging comets. I'd like to suggest that as courtesy to your image

viewers, you provide a bit of documentation with your image

postings.

Please try to supply as many of the following data as you can:

1. Date and time (UTC)

2. Location

3. Scope focal length and camera used

4. Image FOV

5. Image scale arc seconds per pixel

6. Image orientation ? North up and East left is conventional

7. Image acquisition details

8. Image processing details

I know this is a heck of a lot of work the first time you compile

all of the information. But once you have it for just one image, you

can cut and paste and edit the items for successive images and it

goes real fast. Please give it a try. We will all benefit from more

documentation.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net

Hampshire, IL

Date:  Sun, 09 May 2004 22:01:25 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: Documenting Images
Dennis,

This is an excellent starting point. Here are my comments would be:

Image Scale per pixel - This should be optional since some people are
using film and/or reducing image scales to enable web viewing.
Provided FOV is given people can get an idea of the scale, however
some indication that the image was reduced should be given.

Image Orientation - It is not uncommon to reorient the FOV to
maximise framing of tail. I think stating of 'PA of up' should
replace this (you should also remember to ensure images haven't been
mirror reversed!).

Image Acquisition details: I assume this would include exposure,
Film/ISO, stacking, binning , etc.

The rest of it looks fine to me.

Terry

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Eric wrote:
> Had a surprise clear night after a cloudy day. Pulled out the
scope for
> a piggyback session. Imaged comet at approx. 20 degrees altitude,
14x60
> second images at ISO 800, 70mm f/4 (with 24-70 mm f/2.8L), Canon
10D,
> median combined:
>
> http://pics.regolith.net/album39/Combined_FilesMED_str2
>
> Same sequence, aligned on coma instead:
>
> http://pics.regolith.net/album39/coma_adpadd
>
> Some glow is apparent in the images due to nearby lights.
>
> Processing was done in ImagesPlus.
>
> Eric 

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2004 04:15:52 +0930
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 NEAT wide field 35mm film 8th May
Hi All
Just loaded up some pretty pictures to our gallery - from may 8th - scroll
down for new pics

http://www.southern-x.org/gallery-q4b.html

Interesting thing from night was, with the slightly moon affected photos
taken later on after this one, say around 8 pm, have more tail and better
definition on tail ( around 9 deg or more) because the Miky way starts to
get washed out and the comet isnt for a while. :-) will scan them at some
stage.

Cheers
Kearn

http://jfcoliac.free.fr/Astro/Comete/comete.htm
No clouds, no wind, no moon

All comments are welcome.
I noticed that my .jpg files are not of good quality but I do not know
how to improve them.
If you know ...

Clear skies to all

Jean-François Coliac
France

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 10 May 2004 22:15:02 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Images of Q4
Hello Jean-François,

You have a very nice web page with excellent documentation of the
images. I like it! And thank you for the bilingual documentation.

Your jpg images exhibit a bit of posterization  the image does not
have enough bit depth for the degree of histogram stretch that was
employed. This usually happens when you stretch an 8-bit jpg too
much. If you do all of the processing in 16-bit FITs and then
convert to jpg you should be able to avoid this effect.

The rotational gradient display is very interesting. Was that
obtained with a Larson-Sekanina filter?

I am looking forward to seeing more images from you.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

>
> Clear skies to all

> Jean-François Coliac

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2004 22:49:47 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  C/2002T7 - May 10.8
I've added another mosaic of T7 from this morning. Despite a 50% sunlit
moon causing some interference a long tail fills the 10 degree field.
The "anti-tail" feature in still visible and continues its rotation
relative to the ion tail as seen from the sequence of images here:
http://users.bigpond.net.au/vtabur/2002t7/2002t7.htm

Given it's current P.A., is it still valid to call it an anti-tail?

Regards,
Vello 

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2004 13:45:07 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Comet Q4 Page

I have added a recent image Q4 gallery at:

http://members.ozemail.com.au/~lovejoyt/2001q4.htm

Note I really went for broke with Q4 on the 10th May (see the black
and white 16x16deg FOV mosaic).

Terry

From:  Dennis Persyk

Still another great image from south of the equator! I admire your

from one image to the next.

Keep the images coming!

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2004 22:16:19 +0200
From:  Jean-François Coliac 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Images of Q4
Hello Dennis,

Thanks for your comments.

The filter I used is in the software PRISM V5 made by french amateur
astronomers.
I do not know if it is the Larson-Sekanina filter because the function I
used is the 'Rotationnal gradient'
I suppose these are the same filter...

Best regards
Jean-François

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2004 22:16:32 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 (Neat) with MX7c
Hi,

I have not been around for a while due to job, weather, family etc.
etc. but tonight I got out and tried my luck with Q4. This comet
really moves fast! Starguide 2000 on the coma really helped, even
with a
135 mm lens (5 min. x 12 in highres.). I hope you like it (first fast
processing).
In my 10 x 42 binocs I could see it well, visually without you really
have to know where to look. I thought the brightness to be something
like a diffuse 4mag.

http://members.aon.at/fandrosc/page_7_9.html

Comments are as always welcome.

Mike 

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2004 23:41:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4-05112004
Through a hole in the clouds I could just see the comet with averted
vision. It is moving fast and for me is a tough comet to image. I
still hold out to use the 4" refractor and stack on the stars without
much movement of the comet. This really restricts the time I can
spend and information I can get. I will post the result of 5x15 sec
exp. N is up and the fov is 74x56 arc-min. Stack in CCdSoftV5 and
finish processing in PS. Imaged 05/11/2004 from Van Buren, AR.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/4A0E3EE75752EEF/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 12 May 2004 01:39:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 - 05/11/2004 - Color info
http://www.fototime.com/2D1EFBB2886952D/orig.jpg

JPG sucks and it is a decent size file (500kb) My first attempt at
color with this comet. Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Tue, 11 May 2004 18:42:34 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Comet NEAT : variations in ion-tail (5/8, 5/9, 5/10)
Hi:

I've been monitoring Q4 since 5/7:

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html

Q4 on 5/10 lost the 2nd ion-tail fork (seen on 5/9):

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp8910.jpg
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/510/28.jpg

If you compare 5/8 & 5/10 images, the main ion-tail "kinked" is there,
whereas on
5/9 the 2nd ion-tail suddenly appeared ("outburst"). 

Date:  Wed, 12 May 2004 05:24:18 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/11 (no more prominent ion-tail)
Q4 on 5/11 does not have the prominent ion-tail as in previous days
(5/8, 5/9, 5/10):

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/511/511.html
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp891011.jpg

You can see that the ion-tail has branched into multiple-rays (so it's
not so concentrated to
make it "prominent"). Dust tail seems to have become more "brushy".

Again, I tried to corroborate the above with my visual observations
(same instruments as
below). All I could see was "fuzz". Best view was in the 10x50
binoculars.

B Yen wrote:

> Q4 on 5/10 lost the "forked" ion-tail (seen on 5/9), back to "kinked"
single ion-tail:
>
> http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp8910.jpg
> http://www.comet-track.com/q4/510/28.jpg
>
> http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html
>
> Visually in Minolta10x50 binoculars I could not discern any *thin*
ion-tail, just some fuzzy
> tail. Couldn't see it in my 5.1" f8 APO (Astrophysics EDT) either,
just fuzz. 

Date:  Wed, 12 May 2004 15:24:31 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Shell on comet C2001Q4
Hi to everybody,

To the address: http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2001Q4_040511.jpg

I have put one image of mine done with a NW 350/1750 ccd ST9 last night,
L=10x10s B=2x20s R-I=2x10sec. On the color I am not sure to 100%, I still have
to calibrate it, I find interesting the elaboration where 5 shell is perceived
very well.

regards

Rolando Ligustri

Date:  Wed, 12 May 2004 23:12:15 +0200
From:  Stéphane Garro 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Images of Q4
Hello,

> I do not know if it is the Larson-Sekanina filter because the function
> I
> used is the 'Rotationnal gradient'
> I suppose these are the same filter...
>
> Best regards
> Jean-François

YES, "gradient rotationnel" is the common name given in french to the
Larson-Sekanina algorithm.

Stephane
(waiting for clear weather to take also images of great C/2001 Q4 ... !)
