Date:  Thu, 13 May 2004 00:35:49 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  comet f4
For those of you in the Northern Hemisphere (and I guess Southern) who are
focusing on comet Q4 and awaiting T7, try giving F4 a turn in the morning sky
again. Eventhough it has greatly dimmed, it has a nice long sinewy tail and
bright nucleus.
Have a look. I have a clear picture on my website and will convert it to RGB
color on the 5/13 and place on website.
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/satoriastronomy.htm
F4 and Q4 are on the left
cheers

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA
FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) ;(http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm);
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com; webmaster, Satori Astronomy website


State of Kansas- Solar System Ambassador - JPL (Jet Propulsion Lab);
7 total solar eclipses and counting 

Date:  Thu, 13 May 2004 05:29:18 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Comets Bradfield and NEAT -- 9 May (UT)
Finally got out to get some shots of Comets Bradfield and NEAT:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2004/0508/index.htm

Thanks to all who have been posting images. I've been very interested
to follow the changes in these dynamic comets via your shots.

Dave Kodama 

Date:  Thu, 13 May 2004 04:17:32 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/12 (prominent ion-tail back, lots of fine-rays)
Q4 on 5/12:

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp89101112.jpg
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/512/512.html

Comments:

- concentrated ion-tail is back, with multiple fine-streamers (in a fan)

- brush-like dust tail seems to be established,
- that skewed tail seems to show more dust (has dust blow-off overcome
the cyan-ish ion blow-off?), & is considerably longer (I measure at
least 1.6 degrees) than from 5/11

B Yen wrote:

> Q4 on 5/11 does not have the prominent ion-tail as in previous days
> (5/8, 5/9, 5/10):
>
> http://www.comet-track.com/q4/511/511.html
> http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp891011.jpg
>
> You can see that the ion-tail has branched into multiple-rays (so it's
>
> not so concentrated to
> make it "prominent"). Dust tail seems to have become more "brushy".
>
> Again, I tried to corroborate the above with my visual observations
> (same instruments as
> below). All I could see was "fuzz". Best view was in the 10x50
> binoculars.
>
> B Yen wrote:
>
> > Q4 on 5/10 lost the "forked" ion-tail (seen on 5/9), back to
> "kinked"
> single ion-tail:
> >
> > http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp8910.jpg
> > http://www.comet-track.com/q4/510/28.jpg
> >
> > http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html
> >
> > Visually in Minolta10x50 binoculars I could not discern any *thin*
> ion-tail, just some fuzzy
> > tail. Couldn't see it in my 5.1" f8 APO (Astrophysics EDT) either,
> just fuzz.
>

Date:  Thu, 13 May 2004 16:03:16 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Comets Bradfield and NEAT -- 9 May (UT)
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "d_kodama" wrote:
> Finally got out to get some shots of Comets Bradfield and NEAT:
>
> http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2004/0508/index.htm
>
> Thanks to all who have been posting images. I've been very
interested
> to follow the changes in these dynamic comets via your shots.

Hi Dave,

A 6x7 vacuum camera! I didn't know they were still in use. You
certainly know how to use it for wide field shots.

What software did you use for annotating the image? I like the way
you combined the image scale with the North/West arrows. Keeps the
beautiful image uncluttered.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

Date:  Thu, 13 May 2004 16:59:53 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Comets Bradfield and NEAT -- 9 May (UT)
Dennis,

Just in case it might have misled anyone, the vacuum is used to hold
the film flat, as opposed to a cold camera in which vacuum is meant to
prevent frost formation. I actually recently acquired a combo 6x9cm
and 4x5" camera too, but I'm not up to speed using it just yet. Soon
however, I'll be looking for a really big comet!

Regarding the annotation, I just used Photoshop to manually create the
labeling on a separate layer and combined it with the image for the
web version.

Dave

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk" wrote:
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "d_kodama" wrote:

Date:  Thu, 13 May 2004 17:28:45 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet Q4 Images and Supplementary Data
I imaged C2001 Q4 NEAT at both 530 mm and 50 mm focal lengths at
0312 UT on 12 May, 2004. In addition to the comet images, I have
included simulated views through the C-11 scope and 7x50
binoculars. The imaging setup is also shown.

http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

I welcome comments from everyone on my web page layout. Thanks for
looking.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Thu, 13 May 2004 20:37:06 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Q4 for Study
For the past few months I have tried to show any comet imaged in two
ways. First to show it as close to what I think natural is whether
it be B&W or color which lately, haven't had much luck with, and also
create a different image of each session which is submited for
study. It is necessary to adjust, sometimes to the extreme, with all
tools aviable to bring out very faint detail. Most will know what
this is, but for those that don't PS and other software is used to do
away with the parts of the comet which hide what lies hidden.
Every image of each comet requires it's own set of adjustments. I'm
posting an image of Q4 taken 5/11/2004 which was submitted that gives
an idea of how the
tail structure just below the bright washed out area of the coma is
really an offset, kinked to the left kind of structure and also shows
a split about 80 or so arc-min down the tail. In this image around
180 arc-min of comet is showing. We are lucky
enough to have skys and a setup that allow photographs with these
kinds of detail and to have them submitted and accepted for study of
the solar wind. Any way there are two links, the
first is a reduced image incase you don't want to spend time loading
and a second which is a full size 950kb for image quality. Even
the full size was reduced before publishing from 1600pix to 1200pix
wide with prop. constrained.

http://www.fototime.com/FC53699DD1DC0D7/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/FC53699DD1DC0D7/orig.jpg

Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Fri, 14 May 2004 20:58:33 -0000
From:  Steve Smith 
Subject:  NEAT on 5/13/04
I've posted an image of NEAT taken last night. Image and imaging
details can be found at:
http://home.att.net/~stevensmith/
Steve

Terry 

Date:  Fri, 14 May 2004 20:53:10 -0400
From:  SabiaJohn@aol.com
Subject:  Animatied gif and Image from May 10,2004
I loaded and Image of C/2001 Q4 Neat from May 10, 2004 UT and a small
animated gif. Both taken with a 9.5 inch (24.13 cm) F/15 Alvan Clark refractor and
CoolPix 995 digital camera.

John D. Sabia

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 15 May 2004 04:53:08 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  2001 Q4 (NEAT) on 5/14: ion-tail disconnection feature
Hi:

On 5/14, my 8" f1.5 Schmidt-Camera photos (hypered TP2415 & E100S) are
showing an ion-tail
disconnection feature ~5 deg away from nucleus. The ion-tail has a
"fork" feature once
again (last seen on 5/9). As on 5/12, the ion-tail has multiple fine
streamers.

The skewed-tail is at least 2 deg (!), & has increased since my last
observations on 5/12.

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/514/514.html

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp111214.jpg

Visually, I thought the comet wasn't as bright as previous nights.
However, the photos revealed a really rich diversity in detail. By far,
the "best looking" photos so far. 

Date:  Sun, 16 May 2004 05:49:16 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Q4 - 05/16/2004 - 0300UT
Much brighter than I have ever seen it. Easly naked eye and what a
tail. The image is a dirty mosaic with each piece covering 74x56 arc-
min. I had more images to add that really showed some strange tail
stuff. This image was reduced from 3000 pix wide to 8oo for
publishing so lots of detail was lost. Thanks Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/FE36C848EFD83AD/orig.jpg

Date:  Sun, 16 May 2004 14:09:35 +0200
From:  Piotr Guzik 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Q4 - 05/16/2004 - 0300UT
Hi Mike,

>Excellent image...but it is T7 isn't it?!!! Not Q4....
>Mike Begbie

This really is Q4... just try to identify stars: the brightest star is gamma Cnc.

Best Regards
Piotr Guzik

P.S. Indeed, excellent image Mike H.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 16 May 2004 14:20:51 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Q4 - 05/16/2004 - 0300UT
Goodmorning. Yes this is Q4. I was taken by surprise at the change
in the comet. I think if given time I could have traced the tail for
many more frames but I wanted to gather some color info which I am
working on now. As for the pinpoint stars, I started tonight over
and took a series of test frames to see how long exposures could be
and how many could be made and stacked over a period of time and
still not screw up the comet. It is important to me to have a real
image in its own backgroung and not cut and paste the comet in some
way. I give up color info in the long run but gain a true image as
much as possible, imo. Remember each to his own with what equiptment
they have. Thanks, Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
> Much brighter than I have ever seen it. Easly naked eye and what a
> tail. The image is a dirty mosaic with each piece covering 74x56
arc-
> min. I had more images to add that really showed some strange tail
> stuff. This image was reduced from 3000 pix wide to 8oo for
> publishing so lots of detail was lost. Thanks Mike H.
>
> http://www.fototime.com/FE36C848EFD83AD/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 16 May 2004 16:49:16 +0200
From:  Mike Begbie 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Q4 - 05/16/2004 - 0300UT
Hi Piotr

Sorry to you and Mike H. I just saw the amazing ion tail! (which is not apparent visually, but T7's is) I notice that Mike Holloway also said that it was the brightest he had seen the comet, but ten hours earlier I got it down at mag. 3.9...could it be that there has been some increase in activity? We'lll see tonight...

Best,

Mike

Date:  Sun, 16 May 2004 12:59:48 -0500
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Q4 - 05/16/2004 - 0300UT
Hi Mike,

That is really an incredible mosaic - excelent job!

I imaged with a 135 mm lens at f/8 with my MX716 and the results were
disappointing. The mosaic technique was obviously superior.

What was the exposure time and binning for the shots? The scope and camera?
And lastly, how do you move the scope to get the proper position for the
next image in the sequence? It sure would help the rest of us that are
trying to take good images if you would share your data with us.

Thanks.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net

Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Mon, 17 May 2004 02:32:28 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Q4-5/16/2004 with color
I deleted the last link as it brought up the wrong image so I am
reposting with I hope the correct image. Mosaic with RGBL of 2.5
minutes each channel. 74x56 arc-min each frame.

Dennis the only way I have found to move from one area to the next
for a mosaic is to revert to focus mode after imaging an area. I
keep a star or stars in the frame and simply move them to where I
need to go next. Time consuming but it works most of the time.
Thanks, Mike

http://www.fototime.com/AFA2E952888CAA4/orig.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 17 May 2004 08:46:01 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz 
Subject:  La Cañada Images C/2001Q4 NEAT & C/2004 F4 Bradfield
I've just uploaded recent images to my site :

http://www.geocities.com/juan_lacruz/Comets/images/C2001Q4_20040515_J8
7.jpg

_J87.jpg

http://www.geocities.com/juan_lacruz/Comets/images/C2004F4_20040514_J8

Juan 

Date:  Mon, 17 May 2004 02:54:25 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/16, disconnection-event & fading magnitude
Mike Begbie wrote:

> Hi Piotr
>
> Sorry to you and Mike H. I just saw the amazing ion tail! (which is
> not apparent visually, but T7's is) I notice that Mike Holloway also
> said that it was the brightest he had seen the comet, but ten hours
> earlier I got it down at mag. 3.9...could it be that there has been
> some increase in activity? We'lll see tonight...

During my last naked-eye observation on 5/14, I thought Q4 was not as
bright as before.

On 5/16, it was most definitely *not as bright* as last week. My photos
with the 8" f1.5 Schmidt-Camera show a disconnection-event (just like on
5/14). The ion-tail has returned to a "single" ion-tail (there is still
a slight "fork"), which differs from 5/14 (a double "fork"). Again,
there are a lot of fine streamers. The skewed tail is still very long
(as was the case on 5/14), ~2 degrees.

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/516/516.html
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp11121416.jpg
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Subject:  Re: Q4 on 5/16, disconnection-event & fading magnitude

The schmidt camera with the TP does a great job,

Johannes
http://panther-observatory.com

Date:  Mon, 17 May 2004 10:56:09 -0000
From:  Johannes Schedler 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 Neat from May 10 and May 11
Due to travelling a little late, but here it is:

http://panther-observatory.com/gallery/comets/doc/Neat_20040510.htm
http://panther-observatory.com/gallery/comets/doc/Neat_20040511.htm

Some changes are to confirm, less pronounced dust tail, more
pronounced blueish ion tail, nice bow waves can be observed on May 11.

Comments appreciated

Johannes
http://panther-observatory.com

c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

----- Original Message -----
From: tricks46
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, May 16, 2004 9:32 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Q4-5/16/2004 with color

I deleted the last link as it brought up the wrong image so I am
reposting with I hope the correct image. Mosaic with RGBL of 2.5
minutes each channel. 74x56 arc-min each frame.

Dennis the only way I have found to move from one area to the next
for a mosaic is to revert to focus mode after imaging an area. I
keep a star or stars in the frame and simply move them to where I
need to go next. Time consuming but it works most of the time.
Thanks, Mike

http://www.fototime.com/AFA2E952888CAA4/orig.jpg

Date:  Tue, 18 May 2004 04:52:20 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/17 (USA, west coast)
On 5/17, the comet was less-active than the day before (5/16):

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/517/517.html
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp1112141617.jpg
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html

I will note that there have been disconnection-events on 3 straight
observation days (5/14,
5/16, 5/17), with the 5/17 having 2 disconnection-events.

I think Q4 is beginning to fade...

Visually in binoculars, the coma seems to be smaller.

Date:  Wed, 19 May 2004 07:08:25 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz

I've re-processed last saturday's image of C/2001 Q4 NEAT to better

Date:  Wed, 19 May 2004 02:30:19 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/18 (USA, west coast)
On 5/18, the comet was similar to previous day (5/17), showing daily
variations in ion-tail structure:

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/518/518.html
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp111214161718.jpg
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html

The ion-tail on 5/18 shows 2 closely spaced disconnection-events, which
looks like a "squiggle" There is an outer *curved fan-like* dust-tail
(very faint), brought out with image-processing. Visually in 10x50
binoculars, you only see the inner "straight" dust tail.

I will note that there have been disconnection-events on 3 straight
observation days (5/14, 5/16, 5/17, 5/18), with the 5/17 having 2
disconnection-events.

Naked eye, I could barely detect the comet (it was easier with averted
vision). Q4 is definitely going down in magnitude. 

Date:  Thu, 20 May 2004 08:44:06 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet 2002 T7's 43 degree tail
Hi all,
just a quick note to state that I took a wide angle image of C/2002 T7 last night (Wed 19.30 May), then fellow cometographer Ian Cooper and I traced the tail for 43 degrees up to Reticulum! The image was a single 3 minute shot @ 1600 ASA on a Canon EOS 10D with a 24mm (x1.6 = 36mm) lens at f3.5 (FOV = 51* x 34*).

Problem is I just changed computers and can't update my website to show the image for a few days - so it has been placed in the CometImages Yahoo group, see..

http://tinyurl.com/2tc7b

Cheers.

John Drummond and Ian Cooper
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Through cloud as well..

Terry

Date:  Thu, 20 May 2004 02:38:29 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/19 (USA, west coast)
On 5/19, the comet was similar to previous days (5/16, 5/17, 5/18),
showing daily
variations in ion-tail structure:

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/519/519.html
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp11to19.jpg
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html

The ion-tail is showing a "squiggle" & is very long (> 6 degrees)
The coma is noticeably smaller than on previous day (5/18).
There is an outer *curved fan-like* dust-tail.

Naked eye, I could barely detect the comet, it decreased in brightness
from previous day (5/18).

Date:  Thu, 20 May 2004 18:20:18 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Q4 as Seen by CCD and Eyeball


I created a C2001 Q4 NEAT mosaic on 17 May at 0215 UT. The mosaic
worked better for me than my previous effort using a 135 mm lens to
capture more of the tail.

I have profound respect for my fellow imagers who create mosaics 
they sure aren't easy! Mike's are especially good. ! I also find
stacking images of just the tail, sans head, very difficult  there
is nothing to register on!

My images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Fri, 21 May 2004 05:54:28 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4-05212004
A 5 part mosaic with each image 75x56 arc-min. Each image is a
combination of 4x40 sec with the 4" and ST2K ccd. N is up. Thanks,
Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/8A06B61ABE1630D/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 21 May 2004 07:28:47 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4-image-05212004
This comet has really improved sence I last imaged it. This is a
stack of 5x30 sec exp with the 4" and ST2K ccd. Bin 1x1 and croped
for publishing(175kb)B&W. N is up and I am not sure of the fov after
crop. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/3D5FF254EC8CF8B/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 21 May 2004 02:51:31 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/20 (USA, west coast)
Subject:
Q4 on 5/19 (USA, west coast)
Date:
Thu, 20 May 2004 02:38:29 -0700
From:
B Yen
Organization:
AI
To:
Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
References:
1 , 2

On 5/20, the comet is clearly diminished from previous days (5/16, 5/17,
5/18, 5/19), the tail in 10x50 binoculars was noticeably less.
Naked eye, I couldn't even detect the comet.

Photos at:

http://www.comet-track.com/q4/520/520.html
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/5cmp11to20.jpg
http://www.comet-track.com/q4/q4.html

Ion-tail is still long (6 deg), but outer portion is much fainter than
previous day (5/19).
The dust-tail.is still *curved fan-like*, but fainter than previous day
(5/19).
The skewed tail is fainter than previous day (5/19).

I think I'm done with Q4.

The skewed tail is a bit "offset" from the comet's head, which is similar
to what happened to Hale-Bopp's dust tail (comparing March to April). I
believe it's a function of viewing geometry..Earth VS Q4's orbital plane. 

Date:  Fri, 21 May 2004 14:47:41 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4-color-05212004
I did a series of rgbl (180kb total) which was have put together for
this comet after seeing what the grayscale had to offer. The fov is
74x56 arc min. Very rich star field with the comet sitting south of
Deneb. This will be one to watch over the next few months for those
in the north. This was taken at 0700UT-5212004. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/9EE179B2E7768EF/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 21 May 2004 21:44:57 +0000
From:  chiomadiberenice 
Subject:  Q4 on 5/19 (Campo dei Fiori Mount , Varese - ITALY)
Hi all ,
a disconnection of ion tail on photo made by a Schmidt Camera C14 of
G.V.Schiaparelli Astronomical Society.

Film TP 6415 Iper and 4 min of exposure (Field of 2,5 on diagonal)

See Files Folder in Comets Images Group : Schiaparelli Observatory

Light pollution and fog but a comet was an naked eye object
(+4.5 magnitude limit near the comet)

Clear Skies

Andrea Aletti

Date:  Sat, 22 May 2004 14:19:54 +0930
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] t7

> Nice shot. What is the magnitude right now?
> Dr.Eric Flescher
Thanks Eric
Been away a couple of days, so can answer you now. I would agree with the
current crop of estimations - in the high 2's .
Unfortunately looks like the end of the (film) imaging campaign from South
Australia for us, at least when moon is really back and the clouds finally
clear - monday.
Worst autumn weather i have seen in usually very sunny SA for many years,
more like unpredictable spring weather (bit of a repeat of the peak of the
great opposition of Mars last year!! which was ruined by weather as well and
then we get great chunks of sunny clear drought weather for months at a time
until the next great thing comes along - typical! ) I mean even Alice
Springs has been cloudy and messed up for months as well - for goodness
sakes!
Cheers
Kearn 

Date:  Sat, 22 May 2004 08:44:11 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  NEAT and Bradfield shot collection
I've gathered together in one place my sporadically shot "collection"
of NEAT and Bradfield photos from the past few weekends:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2004/comets.htm

It has certainly been a challenge trying to get decent shots of these
comets between the moon light, sunset/sunrise, low altitude, fast
motion against the background, etc.

Dave Kodama 

Date:  Sat, 22 May 2004 16:06:16 -0000
From:  Tom Polakis 
Subject:  Comet Images from The Past Month
Hi all,

I have consolidated my five sessions of images of the three bright
comets from the past month into one page.

http://www.pbase.com/polakis/comets2004

They were taken with a digital SLR camera. The lack of red
sensitivity of the digital SLR is apparent, but the camera does well
in exposures of a minute or less.

Tom 

Date:  Sat, 22 May 2004 16:54:53 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4-05/22/2004-0400UT
9 part mosaic. I wish I could post the full (ps) size image. There
are all kinds of little things which I have no idea what they are.
Tried to match up with guide but not much luck with the time spent on
the faint ones. Each frame is 5x40 sec exp and 74x56 arc-min FOV.
Gradients became a problem so I did the best I could. Actually this
comet is just becoming a good object for my equiptment. Thanks, Mike
H.

Images is 200kb @ 1200 pix wide which is less than half the original.
http://www.fototime.com/599F9B0F5DA6F0F/orig.jpg

If you have the speed this is a full size JPG @ 1.3mb 2100 pix wide.
http://www.fototime.com/6018BCC39B636C6/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 22 May 2004 17:42:33 -0000
From:  Chris Hetlage 
Subject:  First Post and First Comet Image (Q4)
Newbie here and my first real attempt at imaging a comet, and at
imaging through my 180mm lens.

This was also the first light for my new ATS Pier. It is very solid
and stable pier. Setup was simple, all one piece construction.
Balancing the pier was a little strange at first but that is
something I can get used to. The 900 mount looks great on it and the
height is much better the my old 54inch pier. You can check out my
Equipment page for a pic.

I got to my clubs dark site (Atlanta) kinda late so I opted not to
do pulse guiding and do my alignments manually later. One of the
first things I had problems with was focusing the 180mm. It has a
very smooth focuser but the critical focus zone is extremely narrow.
I got it as close as I could but it took a while so I decided against
a color shot.

I also took some images with my Digital Rebel through my AP130. That
was fun and I hope to get another opportunity to try NEAT again with
this camera. Unfortunately (and that seems to be the case a lot these
days) I forgot to load ImagesPlus on my new laptop so I had no
automated focusing routine. I opted to slew to Jupiter and focus on
her. Got it close but not close enough so these pics didn't turn out
as good as I hoped.

Anyway, here is the ST10XE shot. It is only 10-1 min images. Doesn't
compare to some of the great images I've seen on this board, but hey
it's my first. No autoguiding. Processed in CCDSoft, reduced,
debloomed, aligned on comet using centroids and combined using an Add
function. Very simple pic but that is all I was looking for this
night.

http://www.hetlage.com/astro.htm

Comments welcome,
Chris Hetlage
http://hetlage.com 

Date:  Sun, 23 May 2004 17:45:42 +0200
From:  skorupa@t-online.de
Subject:  C/2001 Q4-05/22/2004

Jump direct to http://www.schweifstern.de/images-pages/q4/neat-q4-images.htm

Greetings
Waldemar

>
> Greetings
> Waldemar

Alan Cahill
Abbeydale Observatory,
Gloucester U.K.
MPC Code J94
http://www.mountabbeydale.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/

Date:  Tue, 25 May 2004 08:19:46 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re Comet 2002 T7's 43 degree tail
Hi John et el,

I have now created a webpage in response to John's questions below. Please note that the reddish glow was high cloud and the white streaks are aeroplanes... John, this is the best image that I have of the tail (shorter exposures show less of a tail - see webpage), yet having said that, the tail is very evident to all that I show the image to on my laptop... If you carefully follow the extent of tail compared to a star chart then it is evident that the tail is over 40 degrees long and extends into Reticulum. If others have images of this 43* tail please let us know!!!

For the webpage see...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comets-c-2001t7(linear)-43degree-tail.htm

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

John Drummond wrote:
>...Ian Cooper and I traced the tail for 43 degrees up to Reticulum!
>The image was a single 3 minute shot @ 1600 ASA on a Canon EOS 10D
>Problem is I just changed computers and can't update my website to
>show the image for a few days - so it has been placed in the
>CometImages Yahoo group, see..
>

I am beginning to wonder why we have not heard (at least I haven't)
of any confirmatory observations of this long tail from elsewhere, as
I would think it to be considerable news. I'm not sure about what
other readers can see on the image John has posted to the Photos
section but my machine renders the reduced image as of too poor a
quality to honestly reveal much of anything about the mix of apparent
tail and scattered clouds. John, will you be able to post a better
quality image soon?

I note that such an extremely long photographic tail, at a time when
only a relatively short visual one is being reported, is most
unusual. The only comparable instance I can recall is the case of
Comet Tomita-Gerber-Honda in 1964. In that instance, the visual tail
of this 3-4 magnitude comet was generally reported as just several
degrees long but photos by Alan McClure (the premier comet
photographer of the day) showed a strong, 30-degree, narrow, and
highly contorted tail!

Is anyone else in the far south imagining T7 with wide-angle lenses?

John Bortle

(P.S. I attempted this same post several days ago but it did not seem
to show up on the forum. If this is a repeat for the rest of you,
please forgive me.)

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Tue, 25 May 2004 15:13:33 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  CARA Meeting
Dear comet observers,
the next weeks will be crowded by two interesting conferences (IWCA
III and MACE III). Moreover, I would like to inform you about the
next CARA (Cometary Archive for Amateur Astronomer) meeting. It will
be hosted by the Crni Vrh Observatory (Slovenia) on June 19-20, 2004.

The main topic of the venture will be cometary heads photometry and
the potentials of amateur contributions for comet physical studies
(we expect the attendance of some astronomers interested on pro-am
collaborations).

The prelimary program is available at:
http://cara.uai.it/events/events.html

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Observatory, Italy)

Date:  Thu, 27 May 2004 05:53:27 -0000
From:  Chris Hetlage 
Subject:  NEAT Q4 Image - second attempt
This time used the scope. AP130f4.5, ST10XE, LRGB - 45sec each, AP
Smartguided for comet image, LRGB - 45sec each, autoguided for star
field image.

There was a large star in the comet tail that caused some huge
reflections that I had to work out. I've learned a lot on technique
that will help the next time out. I think I'll try a delay in
between each image and use a sigma reject to eliminate the star field
in the comet image. For this image I used a Light combine on the
star field layer.

http://www.hetlage.com/astro.htm

Comments welcome,
Chris
http://hetlage.com

Exposure
Top: L:R:G:B= 3:3:3:3 minutes (3-min sub-exposures);

binned 2x2.

Date:  Wed, 26 May 2004 23:07:59 -0700
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] NEAT Q4 Image - second attempt
Chris Hetlage wrote:

> This time used the scope. AP130f4.5, ST10XE, LRGB - 45sec each, AP
> Smartguided for comet image, LRGB - 45sec each, autoguided for star
> field image.
>
> There was a large star in the comet tail that caused some huge
> reflections that I had to work out. I've learned a lot on technique
> that will help the next time out. I think I'll try a delay in
> between each image and use a sigma reject to eliminate the star field
> in the comet image. For this image I used a Light combine on the
> star field layer.
>
> http://www.hetlage.com/astro.htm
>
> Comments welcome,
> Chris
> http://hetlage.com

"There was a large star in the comet tail that caused some huge
reflections that I had to work out. "

Can you describe in detail what you mean by "I had to work out"?
I see those "reflections" to-the-right of the stars in your image. Is
this what you're referring to in that bright-star (which apparently
doesn't have a "reflection")

"..I think I'll try a delay in
between each image and use a sigma reject to eliminate the star field
in the comet image..."

Are you saying that you want to *remove* the stars in the image? I
remember Roland Christen/Astrophysics doing that to a particular
star-trail in his Ikeya-Zhang image.

"For this image I used a Light combine on the
star field layer."

Are you saying you have a separate layer for just the star-field? How
did you do that?

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 27 May 2004 12:00:33 -0000
From:  grhemann

Gerald and Michael

www.astrostudio.at 

Date:  Thu, 27 May 2004 14:10:21 -0000
From:  Chris Hetlage 
Subject:  Re: NEAT Q4 Image - second attempt
What I did on this image was first to set my mount to guide on the
comet. I used a feature called Smartguide that is built into the AP
software. This gave me good comet data but causes the stars to
trail. I used a sigma combine on the resulting images and this has
the effect of eliminating most of the elongated star trails but keeps
the comet data. Next time I will add a delay in my acquisition
sequence, this will give the effect of dashes in the stars instead of
long trails. I believe this will be easier for the sigma combine
routine to reject more of the star trails. This was done on all the
LRGB images.

The next series was taken to give me a good star field. I set the
mount/camera to autoguide. This resulting image gave me good star
data but a poor comet image. I again used sigma combine. I used
levels in PS to bring up the stars but intentionally kept the comet
image low. The resulting LRGB was an image of just the stars.

The next thing I did was to layer the star image on top of the star-
less comet image. I used a Light blending option in PS. This added
the stars to the comet image. A little curves and the effect is that
you have a cool comet image with round stars.

The bright star you see in the tail was very bright and caused a lot
of problems. I had to use a lot of layering techniques and cloning
to get it to look this good. Unfortunately I only had a limited time
to image the comet so I could not wait for it to pass by this star.
The technique I used can be found on Ron Wodowski's New CCD Astronomy
web page.

Any other techniques would be greatly appreciated as this is very new
to me. A friend of mine, Roth Ritter, taught me this way, I am sure
there are others......

Thanks,
Chris
http://hetlage.com

> Can you describe in detail what you mean by "I had to work out"?
> I see those "reflections" to-the-right of the stars in your image.
Is
> this what you're referring to in that bright-star (which apparently
> doesn't have a "reflection")
>
> "..I think I'll try a delay in
> between each image and use a sigma reject to eliminate the star
field
> in the comet image..."
>
> Are you saying that you want to *remove* the stars in the image? I
> remember Roland Christen/Astrophysics doing that to a particular
> star-trail in his Ikeya-Zhang image.
>
> "For this image I used a Light combine on the
> star field layer."
>
> Are you saying you have a separate layer for just the star-field?
How
> did you do that?
>

group.

File : /Remanzacco Observatory/C2001Q4_250504_sos.jpg
Uploaded by : gvnn64
Description : cometary morphology with different narrowband filters

You can access this file at the URL

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Remanzacco%20Observatory/C2001Q4_250504_sos.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit

gvnn64 

Date:  Thu, 27 May 2004 21:27:26 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Hello,
I was asked off-list by several people to add some explanations
about the meaning of the image listed below. Well, may be that also
others in this group will be interested on it...

Essentially the picture shows how different narrowband filters are
capable to isolate the emission of molecular species (and dust) at
discrete wavelenghts. This tecnique is normally used by professional
astronomers to calculate the fluxes/chemical abundances in cometary
comae. For us amateurs, the main problem with narrowband
interference filters is due to the fact that they cut a large amount
of light, so we can normally use them only on bright targets (but
the diffusion of back-illuminated CCDs has the potentials to change
this situation).

For this particular image, I think that's interesting to see at
first the three upper panels: they show how in the 390nm filter
(strong CN emission line) and in the 515nm filter (strong C2
emission band) the coma has a nearly round aspect, while in the
647nm filter (where we see almost no gas contribution but mainly the
dust continuum) the shape is very different (parabolic shape). This
is a well known effect: the gas component in the coma is normally
distributed more simmetrically than the dust, and it's capable to
travel for longer distances.

The two panels below show some details in the very beginning of the
tail: the 620nm filter (noticeable H2O+ emission lines) is capable
to increase the details of the ion tail forming streamers, that are
not visible in the 647nm filter where the broad dust tail overwhelms
the ionic contribution.

Normally in order to obtain the "pure footprint" of each chemical
component, is necessary to substract from the given element/molecule
narrowband filter the nearest continuum emission. This is needed to
purge them from the dust continuum (present with different
intensities along all the visible spectra). This isn't an easy
operation, and it requires some practice. I didn't make this
operation yet, however the contribution of the dust continuum for
the CN and C2 filters is very small compared to that of the emission
lines themselves. But this becames mandatory if one would like to
calculate the actual fluxes originated by the cometary chemicals,
but this stage is one step further for me. For now my main
interested was to evidence some interesting morphological features
in this comet. The adoption of narrowband interference filters was
strongly encouraged by some professionals operating within the CARA
collaboration (http://cara.uai.it/): the ambitous target is to be
able to extract cometary
fluxes data also with amateurs means. Let's see if it will work...
Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Observatory, Italy)

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2002 T7-Again
T7 has, for the third time, come into my view although nothing to
write home about. This image which is a stack of 10x40 sec exposures
from 5/29/2004. The image is croped down from the original 74x56 arc-

a good comet. Mike
Small- http://www.fototime.com/DDEA3C9B561D048/standard.jpg

250kb- http://www.fototime.com/DDEA3C9B561D048/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 29 May 2004 10:31:53 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  T7 photographed
Greetings

I photographed T7 from my Amadoo (near Tucson) Harvard 6 inch telescope on
May 28th. I was surprised I got it 8:57 as I did not think it would be dark
enough. I forgot in the southwest sky it is darker at that time. Nice nucleus and
a faint thin longer tail . Taken 1 minute exposure.
I have the rgb pics of T7 from 5/29 and will have a color picture up on my
website today along with Q4. Q4 still has a nice wide fan shaped tail. They are
a nice contrast.
I also caught comet K4 which seems to have brightened and it was prominent in
two pictures 1 hour apart.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
Olathe, KS. USA
FGU astronomy consultant, Harvard U.-
Member, ASKC (Astronomical Society of Kansas City), Comet Observers Award
Moderator, Astronomical League.
(http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html) ;(http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/cometaward.htm);
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com; webmaster, Satori Astronomy website 


Date:  Sat, 29 May 2004 20:20:23 +0200
From:  Piotr Guzik 
Subject:  Amazing image
http://fg-kometen.de/pix/2004F4/2004F4_3_24042004.htm

Did You see that image on Comet Section of Germany page made by Frank Niebling?? It's really amazing!!!
Bradfield has two tails both about 13-14 degree long. LINEAR has also at least 5 degree long tail.
Moreover it seems to me that also comet Tabur is faintly visible at the edge of bradfields tail...

Best Regards
Piotrek Guzik

Date:  Sun, 30 May 2004 23:06:48 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  135mm Q4
Hi,

tonight I tried C/2001 Q4 (NEAT) with my 135mm lens at f/3.5 and MX7c
for 10 x 5 min. (highres. selfguide on a star). This is my first
processing - I have to try to lower the noise some more without
loosing the faint parts from the tails. I hope you like it; comments
always welcome.

Mike

http://members.aon.at/fandrosc/page_7_10.html 

Date:  Sun, 30 May 2004 22:51:49 -0400
From:  Hattonjasonp@aol.com
Subject:  C/2003-K4 image 30th May 2004
Hi Everyone,
I imaged Comet C/2003-K4 (LINEAR) last night using my C9.25 &
SAC-8. Here is a link to the images;

http://members.aol.com/_ht_a/hattonjasonp/planets/C2003K4-30May04.jpg

And here are the same images in negative with slightly stretched contrast to
bring out faint detail;

http://members.aol.com/_ht_a/hattonjasonp/planets/C2003K4-30May04.jpg

North is roughly to the right (I didn't orientated my camera logically when I
took the images... :-)

Despite moonlight the comet was nice visually in the scope at medium
power appearing as a faint smudge, slightly elongated.

Best wishes & clear skies,

Jason

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 31 May 2004 05:09:34 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2002 T7-05/31/2004
After an afternoon of tornados, large hail and 80+ mph winds the skys
cleared with a cold front. Managed T7 again with ok results. Still
showing a wave tail as much as I could bring out. Also put a
negative to help. Image was 74x56 arc-min with a small crop around
the edge. 14x40 sec exp with the 4". Gaps between stars or sets of
images was for refocus with temp droping 25 degrees. Thanks, Mike
Small File
http://www.fototime.com/52112BD6A420066/standard.jpg
full
http://www.fototime.com/52112BD6A420066/orig.jpg

Small file-negative
http://www.fototime.com/905AB2348DC5F96/standard.jpg
full
http://www.fototime.com/905AB2348DC5F96/orig.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 31 May 2004 17:36:07 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4-05312004
A couple of images. FOV 74x56 arc-min. The grayscale is a stack of
10x40 sec images. the color is a RGB of 3x40 sec each with a lum
layer of 5x40 sec each. N is up. Thanks, Mike

http://www.fototime.com/47975D33DA998BD/standard.jpg

Date:  Tue, 01 Jun 2004 07:57:18 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet 2004 H6 (SWAN) image
Hi all,

got up between moonset and sunrise this morning to image Comet 2004 H6 (SWAN). As I waited for it to rise I also shot NGC 253 - the large galaxy in Sculptor. Got a image of Comet SWAN - and then had cloud intereference!!! Aren't particularly impressed with either image but thought I'd post then anyhow - tis always good to see what new comets are looking like...

For a link see...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-04-06-01.htm

Cheers.

John Drummond

Farm Hakos is a very dark site near Windhoek/Namibia/SW-Africa. 1800 m over the sealevel and near the Gamsberg. You can find more information of this place at:
http://www.ias-observatory.org/

Date:  Mon, 07 Jun 2004 22:12:30 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Image Orientation of C/2003 K4 LINEAR and Movie
I imaged C/2003 K4 LINEAR on 7 June at 0534 UT. C-11 scope at f/5
and MX716 CCD camera. A small movie is included on my New Image
Page linked below to illustrate the relative motion of the comet.

On my web page linked below, I illustrate how I achieve proper image
orientation of a comet relative to the star field using a
planetarium program. The images were acquired with a CCD but the
technique is applicable to all imaging modalities.

It is considered good practice to present one's images with a North
up/East left orientation. I had a really hard time doing this at
first and have gradually learned how. I image with different scopes
so I have to contend with rotation and mirroring of the image, along
with occasional rotation.

I hope you find this useful. It is on the New Images Page so it will
be gone in a week or so.

Images, movie and orientation images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

I also illustrate how I achieve proper image orientation of the
comet relative to the star field using a planetarium program. I hope
you find this useful. It is on the New Images Page so it will be
gone in a week or so.

Images, movie and orientation images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Sat, 12 Jun 2004 10:40:39 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet Q4 and T7 images - for a talk
Hi all,

I have been asked to give two seperate talks on the recent bright comets (2001 Q4 and 2002 T7) - one at New Zealand's Royal Astronomical Societies conference (2-4 July - http://www.rasnz.org.nz/ ). I have been downlading all the wonderful images of these comets over the last few months and was wondering if anyone objected to me using them in the talks (full credit will be given for images used of course). I hope to have a NZ (and Australian) flavour with the images, but need some photos from other parts of this planet to fill in the gaps (especially now that Q4 has gone north).

I was thinking that if anyone OBJECTS to me using their image(s) please contact me offline at the email address below and I won't use your images...

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 12 Jun 2004 15:02:26 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comets C/2003 K4 - C/2001 Q4 - C/2002 T7
Worked on the color info for all three. Pleased with all but
especially T7 and K4. All images from 06/11/2004. North is up. All
were taken with the 4" and ST2K ccd with CFW8. RGBL combine. Thanks,
Mike H.
C/2003 K4
http://www.fototime.com/02164D164BD97C5/orig.jpg
C/2001 Q4
http://www.fototime.com/A666F54C28DA134/orig.jpg

Date:  Tue, 15 Jun 2004 23:19:36 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - How Many Tails?
I have viewed the images from 06/11/2004 and knew there was more.
Having put together all images which total 24x45 sec exp, we now have
a better idea of what this comet is doing at well over 2au from the
Sun. There is a short dust tail at the 7 o'clock position and two
tails showing at 6 and 5 pm. I give this with the image being
positioned with north up The kinked longer tail covers a at least
25 arc-min as the image is 56 arc-min tall. Rough, I know but this
shows what might be an exciting comet to watch over the next couple
of months considering what is out there as we know it now. Thanks,
Mike H.

Small file

http://www.fototime.com/A2D12F4BDA11AF2/standard.jpg

Full size - original

http://www.fototime.com/A2D12F4BDA11AF2/orig.jpg

Date:  Wed, 16 Jun 2004 22:57:30 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Latest images - 16th June 2004
Great photo's John,

Note that T7 has a short sunward spike or "antitail".
This feature should remain prominent as we cross the orbital plane of T7
around Jun 26th.

cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

Date:  Wed, 16 Jun 2004 14:42:25 -0000
From:  grhemann 
Subject:  color image k4

Date:  Sun, 20 Jun 2004 23:04:00 +0200
From:  "H.Luethen" 
Subject:  Recording comets using a video camera
Hi
Back from Namibia I needed some time to stack all these images. I had a
Mintron Camera equipped with 50 and 135mm lenses to record comets 2001 Q4
and 2002 T7. The video was recorded through the analog port of a camcorder.
Since the camera stacks 128 half frames on board, 20 minutes of video
consist of roughly 500 images. These were (after flat field correction)
stacked using Fitswork.
You can view the images on
http://home.tiscali.de/astrohardy/namibia/namibia_2004.htm

Have fun
Hartwig

Hartwig Lthen

priv: Behnstr. 13, D-22767 Hamburg
Germany. Tel. 040-3800551

lab: Institut fuer Allgemeine Botanik,
Ohnhorststr. 18, D-22609 Hamburg
Tel. (+49)(0)40-42816337
Fax (+49)(0)40-42816254
email h.luthen@botanik.uni-hamburg.de 

Date:  Mon, 21 Jun 2004 22:46:49 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet 2002 T7 (LINEAR) tonight
Hi all,

decided to image Comet T7 tonight (yet again) and lo and behold, when I checked the test shot it had a mag 10 galaxy sitting next to it! Have updated my website with two images, one with stacked images and thus trailed stars (due to tracking/allignment on the moving comet) and one single image (no star movement).

Check out:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comets-c-2001t7(linear).htm

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 22 Jun 2004 18:11:26 -0000
From:  jonesgerainth 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - disconnection event?
Hi,

Has anyone imaged the ion tail of C/2003 K4 in the last day or two?
Observing from Table Mountain Observatory in Wrightwood, CA last
night, there appeared to be a disconnection event visible in the ion
tail in unflatfielded images. At ~0700 UT on April 22, the feature was
approximately 9 arcminutes south of the nucleus.

As the phase angle is low, there is a good chance of being able to
follow this feature for some days, as the line of sight is quite close
to the ion tail axis. If anyone obtained images recently, or plans to
do so in the coming days, please get in touch. We'd like to trace the
time of appearance of this feature, and measure its velocity down the
tail.

See http://encke.jpl.nasa.gov/Request.html
for details of why we're interested in tracing ion tail features.

Images of C/2001 Q4 and C/2002 T7 also continue to be very welcome.
Many thanks,
Geraint Jones
Jet Propulsion Laboratory 

Date:  Wed, 23 Jun 2004 20:09:34 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - 06232004
Mounted the camera on the 10" F6.3 for the night. This is a 3x30 sec
stack with the fov of 24x20arc-min and N is up. Time was 0340UT.
Not hard to find this comet. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/0392B8035746EB1/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/0392B8035746EB1/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 24 Jun 2004 08:11:39 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Last night's images - 23 June 2004
Hi all,

had a cold but beaut night here in Gisborne, NZ last night. Imaged comet T7, the Trifid, NGC 6337 - a real cool celestial 'smoke ring', and NGC 3293 in Carina - I didn't realise it had nebuloisty before...

Check out...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-04-06-23.htm

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand

Date:  Thu, 24 Jun 2004 04:22:38 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comet C/2003 K4 - C/2001 Q4
Two comets imaged tonight (06242004 - 0310UT). Q4 is showing a large
tail disconnect and covers the entire 74x56 arc-min frame. K4 is
also looking good yet a bit strange in appearence. Hard for me to
tell which way it wants to go. It also sits in a 74x56 arc-min frame
with N up on both images. Each is a combination of 5x45 sec. exp. I
beleive I can fill another full image with the tail of Q4 when I get
time. Thanks, Mike H.
C/2003 K4
http://www.fototime.com/9E9105993B8FC4C/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/9E9105993B8FC4C/orig.jpg
C/2001 Q4
http://www.fototime.com/42DD848E06703EC/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/42DD848E06703EC/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 24 Jun 2004 15:37:41 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comets from 6/24/2004
After publishing at home last night having looked at the images on
my computer at work there was hardly any detail showing. A problem
I come across a lot. These are the same images, inverted and
republished to better show what is there. Like the last post all
info is the same for both comets. Thanks, Mike H.
C/2003 K4
http://www.fototime.com/0367B7D8A8D86B6/standard.jpg

Date:  Thu, 24 Jun 2004 22:58:40 -0000
From:  Tom Polakis 
Subject:  Re: Last night's images - 23 June 2004
John,

Nice images of C/2002 T7. When I use averted vision on my monitor, I
see a faint anti-tail. Have you tried pushing the contrast (or even
equalizing the histogram) to bring out more detail in the anti-tail?

Tom

false color to show detail. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 07 Jul 2004 00:05:25 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2003 G1 LINEAR Faint Little Comet
With everyone imaging very bright Q4 NEAT these days, I opted for a
much dimmer comet: C/2003 G1 LINEAR at magnitude 17.0 per Seiichi
Yoshida, http://www.aerith.net/comet/weekly/current.html

The image is a stack of one 5 minute and one 3 minute unguided
frames taken with the C-11 at f/5 and MX716 camera. I later looked
up the relative motion and found it was only 0.004 arc seconds per
minute. I could have taken 5 hour's worth of images, aligned on the
stars, and not blurred the comet! A movie of this one would be very
boring!

Now that I have a goto mount, I can just Recal on a nearby star, key
in the faint comet's coordinates, and be assured that it is in the
FOV of the camera. Yea!

Image and planetarium chart at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Wed, 07 Jul 2004 18:39:28 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: C/2003 G1 LINEAR Faint Little Comet
At a distance of 5.8 AU that is a good catch. Doesn't look like
that comet will be back any time soon.
Dennis if you or anyone gets a chance I would like to put in a
request. I am interested in C/2003 T4. This one sits at about
4.5AU (15.5mag?)at present but might be one to watch in the next
year. I am at the present limited to my 4" after storm damage has
made my 10" non-usable for imaging. Mike 

Date:  Wed, 07 Jul 2004 20:27:39 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2003 G1 LINEAR Faint Little Comet
Hi Mike,

I don't think I'll be able to image C/2003 T4 LINEAR from my
northern Illinois site. At darkness, it is only 24.8 degrees above
the horizon and sinking.

Sorry to hear about the storm damage. That reminds me that I should
up the coverage on the observatory in my homeowner's policy. Added
insurance on outside structures and contents is really cheap.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Sun, 11 Jul 2004 04:26:15 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4-Image-07112004
Comet has continued to improve and now shows a good tail disconnect
event. Strong spikes or streaks from the south side of comet. Image
is 74x56 arc-min. with N up. 300 seconds exposure with a 4" and ST2K
CCD. Thanks, Mike H.
(two file sizes with the first the smaller.)

Comet Q4 has decreased quite a bit in the last couple of weeks.
Still shows two tails but the length is much less. This is a 420
sec. image with N up. 74x56 arc-min with the 4". Thanks, Mike H

http://www.fototime.com/E8186F9ADB71005/standard.jpg

Date:  Sun, 11 Jul 2004 05:16:15 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 T4-Image-07112004
At 4.51 AU from Earth this was a tough comet for a 4" scope. This
image is a 420sec exp and the comet sits next to a dim star. I have
inverted the image and did not apply any flatts. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/D79F0B9DDCDAB63/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/D79F0B9DDCDAB63/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 11 Jul 2004 22:11:33 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C2003 K4 as seen by CCD and Eyeball
I imaged comet C2003 K4 LINEAR the other night and produced a short
movie illustrating its relative motion of 2.9 arc seconds per minute
against a star field in Bootes.

On my new Images Page I also provide some tips on correlating a
camera image to a planetarium program to determine proper
orientation.

Finally, I have included a simulated eyepiece view to show you what
I saw through the eyepiece of the C-11 scope while I was imaging
through the E160.

I hope you will find a visit to my New Images page both educational
and interesting.

Images, eyepiece view, short movie and planetarium chart at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Mon, 12 Jul 2004 19:33:36 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  C/2002 T7 LINEAR + antitail CCD image Jun 27
Hello all,

Sorry about the tardiness, I've posted an image of C/2002 T7 LINEAR, CCD
image on Jun 27.39UT.
10x10 second exposures. FOV 13'x19'. Note the prominent sunward dust tail or
"antitail" pointing towards the bottom of the frame. This appears to be a
"baby" version of the great comet Arend-Roland in 1957 (not that I was alive
to see it ;))

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Tue, 13 Jul 2004 17:36:43 -0000
From:  grhemann 
Subject:  Taildevelopement of C/2003 LINEAR K4
We placed a Schmidt-picture- combination of comet LINEAR K4 to our
webpage, which documents the taildevelopement within two days.

Michael and Gerald
www.astrostudio.at 

Date:  Thu, 15 Jul 2004 20:02:27 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 - 07/15/2004 - Color
Greetings! Decent imaging for a while last night. Was able to put a
RGBL together which shows the comet still showing nice color. Three
small galaxies at bottom center are Magnitude 12.5 to 15. L=9x60 -
r=2x60 - g=2x60 - b=2x60. Noise was a problem but made the best of
it. The second file is fairly large with the color info added.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/626ACAB81B703D0/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/626ACAB81B703D0/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 15 Jul 2004 21:29:38 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - 07/15/2004 - color
The second comet before calling it a night. RGB=1x60 Each -
Lum=2x60.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/EDF509E3892F7BE/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/EDF509E3892F7BE/orig.jpg

Date:  Sun, 18 Jul 2004 14:58:07 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  New images
Hi List,

I have updated the image gallery of the german comet section.

Look at http://www.fg-kometen.de/bildere.htm

for new images of 2001Q4, 2003K4,2004K3,48P/Johnson, 42P/Neujmin 3, 2003T3 ,
29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1,C/2003 T3 Tabur,C/2004 H6 SWAN and C/2004
HC18 LINEAR.

Thanks to Michael Jaeger and Gerald Rhemann for these latest images.

Don't hesitate to report errors accessing files of the comet section to me.
With every reported error I can improve the image gallery.

Date:  Sun, 18 Jul 2004 15:53:24 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: New images
Hi Stefan,

I am having a hard time identifying 48P/Johnson in gallery. The
first image has both vertical and horizontal guide lines that seem
to converge to nothing. The second image has one line but I don't
recognize anything above or below it. Do other group members see a
comet on these frames?

The nomenclature 8" f/300 is also confusing to me  perhaps you
could explain.

Clear skies,

Date:  Sun, 18 Jul 2004 09:40:37 -0700
From:  Gary Spiers 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New images
Hi Dennis,

Both pictures have two guidelines? By comparing the region of the
included Palomar images with the guideline area I could persuade myself
that perhaps there is something in the photographs that is not in the
Palomar images but it is highly subjective given the variation between
the images and the Palomar images. What would have been useful is a box
on the image outlining the region in the Palomar image.

I presumed the 8" f/300 nomenclature represented the effective focal
length after accounting for whatever extra optical elements had been
included.

Date:  Sun, 18 Jul 2004 21:56:58 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New images

Hi Dennis,

both images have guide lines. Sometimes directly within the image.

The nomenclature says Schmidtcamera 8" f/300. I have edited this and
I can see it with my Mozilla browser.

Michael uses normally a Celestron 8-inch Schmidtcamera with 300 mm focal
length.

Please drop me a mail if you could see the complete text and you have
found the guidelines and the comet :-)

Stefan 

Date:  Sun, 18 Jul 2004 20:05:53 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: New images
Hi Stefan,

My confusion arises from non-standard nomenclature: Generally f/
denotes focal ratio and fl denotes focal length. An f/300 scope is
clearly not a Schmidt camera!

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Mon, 19 Jul 2004 17:30:28 +0200
From:  stefan_beck@cometchaser.de
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New images
Hi Dennis,

> My confusion arises from non-standard nomenclature:  Generally f/
> denotes focal ratio and fl denotes focal length.  An f/300 scope is
> clearly not a Schmidt camera!

You are right. I will make this clearer next time.
I thought it is clear while writing Schmidtcamera in the description.

Take care,

Stefan 

Date:  Wed, 21 Jul 2004 22:15:58 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - mosaic - 07212004
Greetings. Put together a two-part mosaic from the 21st. Each frame
is 300 sec. There is also a negative. The image shows about 130 arc-
min of tail. Two files for each image and I hope the faint stuff
shows up. Thanks, Mike H.
grayscale

Date:  Fri, 23 Jul 2004 11:53:29 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  C/2003K4 Linear widefield
Hi,

last night I made an image of K4 with my MX7c CCD and a 135 mm camera
lens. I wanted to do a close up with my C8 but then the clouds rolled
in again. This summer has been terrible here so far.

hoping you like it -

Mike

Date:  Fri, 23 Jul 2004 14:08:34 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Very nice mosaic.  k4
Eric. I don't know if the tail has grown in the past week or if my
seeing was just better at the time of these images. I would suspect
it has increased but the weather has been so bad for months around
here it would be hard to say only being able to get out once every
week or two. Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 29 Jul 2004 08:18:54 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: Comet 2003 G1 LINEAR ?
> I tried to image comet 2003 G1 LINEAR last week and couldn't find it
> up to 18mag. Did anybody imaged it during the last 2 weeks ?

Hello Stefan,
I upload an image of C/2003 G1 (LINEAR) obtained on July 19.0, 2004
in the "Photos" area of this mailing-list's homepage. it seems that
the comet is faintly visible in my frame. On the POSS-R plate for
that coordinates, there is nothing in that position, so I think I
really catched the comet.
Ciao,
Giovanni 

Date:  Sun, 01 Aug 2004 16:03:13 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  K4 & Gradients from a Blue Moon
I didn't see any hint of blue just light polution. Image of C/2003
K4. N is up and the fov is 74x56 arc-min. 5x60 sec exp with the 4"
at F5.3 Hope the sky improves as the Moon goes away. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/5DEA40C0BFC8518/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/5DEA40C0BFC8518/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 02 Aug 2004 16:49:18 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: K4 & Q4 - 8/2/2004
Hello Dennis. These images were taken just before Moonrise. About 1
hour of dark last night. I had something come up before the info
could be posted. Each of these comet images is a 10x60 sec exp. the
approx time was 0300UT 08022004. 74x56 arc-min 4" @F5.3 - 530mm. N
is up. Temp in the dome was 38cel so cooling & noise was a problem
along with rivers of sweat. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 03 Aug 2004 04:11:43 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2004 H6-Image - 08/03/2004
I don't think there is much but a little bit of dust left. I found
no kind of central point. The tail almost seems to be as much as 25
arc-min long if it is a tail. Moon interference has kept my image to
5x60 sec exp but still reminds me of 2002 06 after it fell apart.
Some with bigger scopes might image this one in the next few days as
it rises just after dark in the East for northern skys.
Mike H

http://www.fototime.com/E50497052FECA4E/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/E50497052FECA4E/orig.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 03 Aug 2004 04:26:05 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 H6-Image - 08/03/2004
Hi Mike,

I see H6 is supposed to be mag 8.8 according to SkyMap Pro, but it
looks like it is dimmer. It transits by me at 1 am and the moon
will be interfering then. I hope to get back to comet imaging as
soon as the moon gets out of the way.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

Subject:  C/2003 T4 - animation-08042004
I was having a bit of a hard time finding this comet so I took 3x60
sec images twice one hour apart. Very faint. The image is approx.
26 arc-min across. 4" @5.3 - 530mm. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 04 Aug 2004 05:37:27 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - 2 x mosaic - 08042004
Big change in the tail from 24 hours ago. Was able to detect tail
for over 120 arc-min. each frame consist of 5x60 sec exp. 0252UT -
08042004 - 4" refractor @ F5.3 & ST2K ccd. Small & large of the
image and a negative. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Sat, 07 Aug 2004 11:08:40 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS:V-040806
Hi all,

observed C/2004 H6 (SWAN) last night...

CometObs -

C/2004 H6 (SWAN)
2004 August 06 .53 UT: m1 = ~11.0, Dia.= ~2'.5, DC = 1, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x)... John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [20 day old moonlight interference - difficult to make a magnitude estimate. 2004 H6 is now extremely nebulous and diffuse - no nucleus evident. Images I took reveals a tail of about 12' in a PA of 154*. 58* alt in the N. Stellar LM =14.5 (scope)].

ICQ -

Aug 06 .53, ~11.0, ~2'.5, (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 41cm Reflector).

JPL (NASA) -

C/2004 H6 (SWAN)
2004 Aug 06 .53 UT: m1=~11.0, Dia.=~2'.5, DC=1/9, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x)... John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [20 day old moonlight interference - difficult to make a magnitude estimate. 2004 H6 is now extremely nebulous and diffuse - no nucleus evident. Images I took reveals a tail of about 12' in a PA of 154*. 58* alt in the N. Stellar LM =14.5 (scope)].

Images of H6 last night can be seen at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2004h6-swan-040806-5cf-text.jpg

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  New images of 6 comets
Hi List,

I have uploaded new images from comets 2003 T3 Tabur, 2003 T4 Linear,
2004 HC18 LINEAR, 42P Neujmin 3, 2003 K4 LINEAR and 2001 Q4 NEAT
to the image gallery of the german comet section (http://www.fg-kometen.de)
All images are taken by Michael Jaeger and Gerald Rhemann.

Date:  Fri, 13 Aug 2004 04:22:07 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  2003 K4-08132004-Image
Beautiful night and comet. 2 x mosaic with the tail starting off
strong and then spreading quickly. Images taken at 0300UT with each
of the two images containing 5x60 sec exp. The camera was rotated so
N is not exactly up but to the left of top center. Thanks, Mike H.
Fairly big files with two sizes of each.

http://www.fototime.com/0A0DE20B485A336/standard.jpg

>
> C/2001 HT50 LINEAR-NEAT 15/08/2004:
> http://astrosurf.com/paulobg/dso/C2001HT50LINEARNEATc50.jpg
>
> Best regards
> Paulo 

Date:  Tue, 17 Aug 2004 04:28:39 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4-08172004
3x60 sec exp - 4" - 74x56 arc-min - n is left of top - 0230UT
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/75C84D6CA1B44CD/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/75C84D6CA1B44CD/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 18 Aug 2004 01:15:48 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  2 x Mosaic - 2003 K4 - 08172004
Looks like with the new Moon over and some stormy weather coming this
could be the end of the brighter images of this comet. It is getting
pretty low in the evenig sky so I am posting this image and leaving
it at the full size of about 550kb. Looks like someone needs to find
me another bright comet. I hope those in the southern skys will pick
up this comet when they can and keep us posted with images. Thanks,
Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/70DD343D5F5C870/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 19 Aug 2004 03:25:04 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 & NGC 4036
>From 08/19/2004 this is a 5x60 sec exp. 74x56 arc-min FOV with the
4" F5.3 refractor. NGC 4036 sits east(left) of the comet and NGC
4041 above and to the left of it. Both galaxies are 11+ magnitude.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/7B6B71449629A4D/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/7B6B71449629A4D/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 21 Aug 2004 16:43:28 -0700
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet article
Hi all,

I'm writing an article for the Royal Astronomical Society of New Zealand's ( http://www.rasnz.org.nz/ ) journal 'Southern Stars' on comets Q4 and T7. The slant is that I'm using mainly New Zealand and some Australian cometphotos. However I need an image of Hale Bopp with a display of both the gas and dust tails to illustrate a point. Does anyone have a 'great' image that I could use?

Also I want to use one of Johannes Schedlers (Panther Observatory) images. I have sent him an email asking if I may use it, however I've received no reply at this stage (I presume I reached him). Johannes, if you read this could you please reply to the email address below?

Also I wanted to use the great image of Comet Bradfield, T7, and M31 by Mr Niebling. Could he also possibly allow me to use it by contacting me?

I'm afraid I'm under a bit of a deadline pressure and need to submit the artcile within the next five days...

Thanks to all.

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

> I'm writing an article for the Royal Astronomical Society of New Zealand's (
http://www.rasnz.org.nz/ ) journal 'Southern Stars' on comets Q4 and T7. The
slant is that I'm using mainly New Zealand and some Australian cometphotos.
However I need an image of Hale Bopp with a display of both the gas and dust
tails to illustrate a point. Does anyone have a 'great' image that I could use?

Hi John
We have a lot of images of the comets that you point out in our site
(www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete), if you point out authors and association
you can use very well her.

regards

Rolando Ligustri
===============================
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete

Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet article

Hi all,

I'm writing an article for the Royal Astronomical Society of New Zealand's (
http://www.rasnz.org.nz/ ) journal 'Southern Stars' on comets Q4 and T7. The
slant is that I'm using mainly New Zealand and some Australian cometphotos.
However I need an image of Hale Bopp with a display of both the gas and dust
tails to illustrate a point. Does anyone have a 'great' image that I could
use?

Also I want to use one of Johannes Schedlers (Panther Observatory) images. I
have sent him an email asking if I may use it, however I've received no
reply at this stage (I presume I reached him). Johannes, if you read this
could you please reply to the email address below?

Also I wanted to use the great image of Comet Bradfield, T7, and M31 by Mr
Niebling. Could he also possibly allow me to use it by contacting me?

I'm afraid I'm under a bit of a deadline pressure and need to submit the
artcile within the next five days...

Thanks to all.

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand

Date:  Sun, 22 Aug 2004 00:31:13 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 T4-08192004
It appears this comet has now started to show a central point and
distinct neblulosity Hard to get a good view with the 4" but
compaired to the past month I think it has brightened. This is a
5x60 sec image with N up. I croped the original image. Looking
forward to this comet next year. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/FEEF26AAFC5180B/orig.jpg

Hi Mike,

After seeing your T4, I was going to image it tonight. Then I
noticed that it would only be 21 degrees above the horizon at
transit! That's too low for me at mag 14.3.

Thanks for sharing.

I noted that it will be tracking near M81 in the next couple of
nights.

image of 2004 PT42 a recently discovered amor asteroid.

Date:  Mon, 23 Aug 2004 17:12:28 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  C/2003K4(Linear)
Hi,

on the 15th of Aug. I imaged K4 with my 300mm tele and SXV-H9 CCD-
camera. FOV is about 0.9°. The galaxy NGC 5172 is also well visible
on the upper left of the comet.

Mike

http://members.aon.at/fandrosc/page_7_14.html 

Date:  Tue, 24 Aug 2004 03:34:46 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 T4 & Friends
I had high hopes this comet would burst into a 2 magnitude giant-----
Well not really, but I was hoping for a little bit more in the
present position. Just to the right of M81, it sits in a really good
place. This is a mosaic or 5 images containing 60 total minutes of
exposure. Final image taken 08-24-2004 at 0245UT. This file is
350kb but needs to be to even see the comet. I used the 4"
refractor. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/F14047BDBCB124E/orig.jpg

Date:  Tue, 24 Aug 2004 23:45:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  T4 & M81
This is some different info from 08242004. It is 11x60 Lum and 3x60
each RGB with the color info discarded (20 min total). I combined
with an average combine and then used another program to smooth the
image. Then it was inverted, enlarged, croped and saved from a RGB
TIF to a grayscale JPG. I hope it shows on your monitors. Thanks,
Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/8FD15812B846967/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 26 Aug 2004 08:06:58 -0700
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: Comet article
Hi all,

Once again thanks to everyone - the images were amazing!

Cheers

John D

Hi all,

I'm writing an article for the Royal Astronomical Society of New Zealand's ( http://www.rasnz.org.nz/ ) journal 'Southern Stars' on comets Q4 and T7. The slant is that I'm using mainly New Zealand and some Australian cometphotos. However I need an image of Hale Bopp with a display of both the gas and dust tails to illustrate a point. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 27 Aug 2004 17:09:04 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Wide Field View with C/2003 T4
I worked on imaging the area that this comet would cross starting
8/17/2004. I had hoped for a bit more comet but. This is made up
of over 100-60 second images. I have saved it as a JPG and also
listed a few of the objects and there magnitudes according to
Guide8. It was fun matching the faint objects but blending all the
images from different nights was tough. This file is almost 1mb and
the bad weather only allowed the comet to be placed 3 times.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/A19578BD01A766A/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 27 Aug 2004 19:26:42 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Wide Field View with C/2003 T4
Hi Mike,

That is a very interesting mosaic. I'd like to try something like
that some time but I have a hard time joining the sections of images
together. It gets especially hard when I image on different nights
and the camera is rotated differently. Then I have to rotate as
well as translate images.

What software did you use and how did you handle rotation?

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46"
wrote:
> I worked on imaging the area that this comet would cross starting
> 8/17/2004. I had hoped for a bit more comet but. This is made up
> of over 100-60 second images. I have saved it as a JPG and also
> listed a few of the objects and there magnitudes according to
> Guide8. It was fun matching the faint objects but blending all
the images from different nights was tough. This file is almost
1mb and the bad weather only allowed the comet to be placed 3
times. Thanks, Mike H.
>
> http://www.fototime.com/A19578BD01A766A/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 27 Aug 2004 23:21:34 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Wide Field View with C/2003 T4
Hello Dennis. I took images for about 3 weeks before the final set
was taken on 8/24/2004. If I had not had Photoshop7, I could not
have done this. A big problem was turning the information of about
5x60 seconds for each frame into a single image which showed the same
magnitude of all objects. Some frames required 20 or 30x60 sec. exp
like the M81 and M82 images. Gradients were a big problem with all
frames being no more than 25 or 30 deg. off the horizion over a three
(?) week period. It took hours of working with each set of exposures
to create a single frame and then adding it to each aditional frame
next to it. Once I thought I had a match and looked at the entire
mosaic I basicly had to start over for the benefit of the entire
image. I came to a point where my own self judgment became to tough
to handle so I then showed it to all. I also took all the color info
for each frame but gave up on that a long time ago. I am pleased to
be able to use a 4" refractor and acheve an almost 18th magnitude
then load Guide 8 which then gives me an exact sky map to compare to
and list any or almost any object. I am sorry the comet did not show
better but if I don't look ahead with my imaging, I will fall behind
with such excellent imagers of comets on this board. I hope this is
a credit to all who post here as in the whole world, there are only a
hand full of us who image the comet. Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"

Date:  Sat, 28 Aug 2004 16:18:01 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet Q4 amongst 6 Galaxies
On Aug 22 at 0305 UT, C/2001 Q4 NEAT was nestled amongst 6 galaxies
near the Big Dipper.

Takahashi E160 f/3.3 astrograph, AP1200GTO, and MX716 camera. 26 x
minutes.

I have posted a simulated eyepiece view as well as a planetarium
program screen shot to illustrate the position of the comet in
relation to the surrounding galaxies.

Images at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Gerald Rhemann
Linzerstraße 372/1/6
A-1140 Vienna/Austria

Date:  Sun, 29 Aug 2004 21:14:54 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2004 Q2
If the present track doesn't change which I am sure it will a little,
this comet will sit 15 deg S/W of Rigel in Orion on Dec. 11th, new
moon. On Jan 13 it will pass over the top of M45, the Pleiades. A
winter to look forward to for imaging. Mike H.
