Date:  Wed, 01 Sep 2004 15:39:27 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: 2004 Q1 and Q2 images
Hi Michael,

Thanks for sharing the images  impressive considering the moonlight
pollution we have now. You also have a nice web layout.

I note that you image with your C-11 at f/3.3. I have the Meade 3.3
FR and when I install it after the JMI focuser, I have severe coma.
The fastest I can image at with the C-11 is about f/5 using an Optec
FR. Could you describe your setup? I'd love to image at /f3.3.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Mattiazzo"
wrote:
> Hello All,
> Find images of 2004 Q1 and Q2 on my website at:
>
> http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/
>
> I had full moon and light pollution to contend with.
> Hopefully better images to follow over the coming weeks.
>
> Cheers,
> Michael 

Date:  Wed, 01 Sep 2004 18:01:49 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet Magnitudes
I just learned from the Comets ML group that the comet magnitudes
as given in planetarium programs are subject to large errors. As I
understand it, the errors can occur even with the most recent
ephemeredes because the data from the Harvard.edu site concerns
itself only with astrometry, and not photometry. Many comets do not
follow the expected light curve, and thus the calculated magnitude
can differ greatly from the actual.

I experienced this difference first hand on Aug 23, 2004, when I
tried to image C/2004 H6 SWAN. Sky Map Pro 10 lists the magnitude at
10.4 When I tried to image the comet, there was nothing there! I
thought my goto mount had gotten lost or something.

Then, I come to learn that on Aug. 23, the magnitude of H6 was of
the order of 17.8 (nuclear magnitude) as given on
http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/lists/LastCometObs.html

I believe the magnitude difference of 7.3 explains why there was no
comet in my image.

Now I understand why at times I have failed to image a comet that
seemed to be bright enough for my equipment and skies. It is
because the comet was, in fact, much dimmer than my planetarium
programs calculated.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Q4 Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm 

Date:  Thu, 02 Sep 2004 23:45:12 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 2004 Q1 and Q2 images
Hi Dennis,

My setup
Telescope: Celestron Nexstar 11GPS
Camera: Starlight Express MX7c CCD, one shot colour 752x582 pixels.
resolution of 1.9" per pixel at f/3.3 with C11 setup.
The original image scale is 25' wide but I crop the image down to 15-20' to
remove the vignetting.

cheers,
Michael

Date:  Fri, 03 Sep 2004 03:53:19 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - 09032004
Comet is low in the Western muck but wanted to see what I could.
This is a 8x60 sec. The image is about 74x56 arc-min and the comet
still would have covered it easy West to East (left) with North up.
I turned it negative. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/16AF693899818B3/orig.jpg

Subject:  Comet Maachholz - latest images
Hi all,

just a note to say that I've taken two new images (Thurs, Fri nights) of Comet 2004 Q2 (Machholz). They can be found at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2004q2(machholz)-040903-10cf-1min@1600asa-text.jpg

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2004q2(maccholz)-040902-9cf-2min@800asa-text.jpg

I didn't do an observation but it 'seemed' to be slightly brighter in the eyepiece tonight than last night (perhaps the lessoning moon?).

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'

Date:  Sat, 04 Sep 2004 18:38:43 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] John nice image
Hi Dr Eric,

yes, you will be able to see Comet Machholz. In Jan 2005 it may be mag 5ish and be at a declination of about +20. It will be at an elongation of about 128*.

To see info, daily positions, images, etc of this comet visit...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comets-c-2004q2(maccholz).htm

or

http://tinyurl.com/5v9xn

Thanks Mike for doing the Tiny URLs.

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sat, 04 Sep 2004 10:34:00 +0200
From:  "H.Luethen" 
Subject:  check your 2002 T7 photos for prediscovery images of C/Machholz

Inspired by Vello's mail to comet-ml I thought about more pre-discovery
images of
2004 Q2, and looked where it was located in Mid May 2004. I think a number
of
folks who were at the southern hemisphere for observing 2002 T7 might have
captured comet Machholz, too. On May 14 and 15, for instance, was just 12
degrees
from T7. On May 15 it was actually pretty much inside comet 2002 T7's
ail.

I looked on my own Mintron photos, but unfortunately the 2004 Q2 position
was just outside the field of view of my 50mm lens. There were a number of
folks using 100mm lenses on a 300D camera or something like this and made
mosaiks to cover much of the 2002 T7 tail.

They should really look for prediscovery images of the comet, which is
predicted to have been 14 mag. Maybe some images turn up !

Hartwig 

Date:  Sun, 05 Sep 2004 10:24:46 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Prediscovery images of C/Machholz from May 15th
Hi list,

I have been informed that Michael Jaeger and Gerald Rhemann imaged comet
2004 Q2 Machholz in May during their stay in Namibia imaging Linear 2002
T7 and Neat 2001 Q4.

Have a look to http://www.fg-kometen.de/bildere.htm

--

Stefan Beck

http://www.cometchaser.de
"Astrophotography with small telescopes"

http://www.cometchaser.de/d_index.html
"Astrophotography with small telescopes auf Deutsch"

http://www.geocities.com/stefan_beck_xyz/os2/os2home.htm
"Informationen zu OS/2, warum OS/2 ?"

You need a real OS ? Take OS/2

Date:  Tue, 07 Sep 2004 20:24:42 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  2 comet images - 09072004
Two comets, C/2003 K4 and C/2001 Q4. Each is a 6x60 combine with N
up. K4 is very low and Q4 is still a nice comet to image. The
galaxy above Q4 is UGC 7941 at magnitude 15. All images with the 4"
at F5.3. Thanks, Mike Holloway

C/2003K4

http://www.fototime.com/F675C474509C5D3/orig.jpg

C/2001Q4

http://www.fototime.com/5CFB6F3EFC4A9E0/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 10 Sep 2004 07:48:57 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS:V - new ASAS comet - plus image
Hi all,

observed the new (ASAS) comet this morning. It was easy to see visually through the 16". An observation and a link to images are below...

CometObs -

C/2004 ?? (New)
2004 September 09 .69 UT: m1 = 9.8, Dia.= 2'.5, DC = 4, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [New comet easily seen. Large, 'bright', coma of medium compactness - without a central condensation. Reminds me of a planetary nebula. No tail visually - or photographically. 37* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.6 (scope)].

ICQ -

Sept 09 .69, 9.8, 2'.5, John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand, 41ck L.

JPL (NASA) -

2004 Sept 09 .69 UT: m1=9.8, Dia.=2'.5, DC= 4/9, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [New comet easily seen. Large, 'bright', coma of medium compactness - without a central condensation. Reminds me of a planetary nebula. No tail visually - or photographically. 37* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.6 (scope)].

An image of this comet can be seen at (due to technical difficulties the link to the larger image and 15 minute positional images isn't working at the moment - will work on it)

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sun, 12 Sep 2004 09:52:06 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  I caught Machholz
> Date: Sat, 11 Sep 2004 15:50:39 -0000
>    From: "tricks46"
> Subject: Machholz in Color
>
> http://www.fototime.com/C4BC892084826FC/orig.jpg
> 09-11-2004Thanks, Mike H
>
Nice shot. I caught comet Machholz in B&W ccd image last night at 4:33
arizona time. I was surprised to see it however on the left side of my image .
That leads me to believe that my coordinates with starry night pro program are
off as it should have been near the center.
In any case, I noticed the comet on the left side because of the small fan
shaped tail like the pic you have so thanks.
I will try to put the pics and others in the coming week. I am still looking
for Tucker Q1.

Date:  Thu, 16 Sep 2004 06:07:29 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS:V - C/2004 R2 (ASIS), plus an image
Hi all,

have just observed and imaged C/2004 R2 (ASIS). I agree with Stuart Rae, the comet is getting brighter and more condensed...

CometObs -

C/2004 R2 (ASIS)

2004 September 15.69 UT: m1 = 8.5, Dia.= 3'.0, DC = 5, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [R2 is brighter than my last observation (9.8 on Sept 9). The coma has a more pronounced central condensation also. No tail visually. 32* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.5 (scope)].

ICQ -

Sept 15.69, 8.5, 3'.0, (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 41cm L).

JPL (NASA) -

2004 September 15.69 UT: m1=8.5, Dia.=3'.0, DC=5/9, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [R2 is brighter than my last observation (9.8 on Sept 9). The coma has a more pronounced central condensation also. No tail visually. 32* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.5 (scope)].

I took a series of images with my 3" f5 refractor (which were stacked) as I observed R2 through the 16", it can be seen at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2004r2(asis)-040915-6cf-1min@800asa-8cm-dl-f5-text.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/4y6lk

My other images of R2 can be seen at...

http://tinyurl.com/6z5rs

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Thu, 16 Sep 2004 11:23:27 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  New images of  2004Q1, 2004Q2, 65P, 29P, 32P/Comas-Sola, 119P/Parker-Hartley, 78P, 2001HT50-LINEAR-NEAT
Hi list,

I have updated the image gallery of the german comet section.

Look at http://www.fg-kometen.de/bildere.htm

for new images of 2004Q1 Tucker , 2004Q2 Machholz, 65P/Gunn,
29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1, 119P/Parker-Hartley, 32P/Comas-Sola,
78P/Gehrels 2, C/2001 HT50 LINEAR.

Thanks to Michael Jaeger and Gerald Rhemann for these latest images.

Don't hesitate to report errors accessing files of the comet section to me.
With every reported error I can improve the image gallery.

Comments are always welcome.

Stefan Beck

Subject:  C/2004 R2 (ASIS) tail development
Hi all,

or

Date:  Sun, 19 Sep 2004 22:19:59 +0100
From:  Paulo Bénard Guedes 
Subject:  29P and 78p
Hi:

Managed to image both comets yesterday, and 29P has had a big change in
magnitude, for comparasion I post links of both comets imaged in the 28th of
August, both images were made with the same setup but sky conditions were
worst in Saturday's pic with some high clouds and a lot of turbulence and
humidity:

Comet 29P Schwassmann-Wachmann:
http://astrosurf.com/paulobg/dso/29PSchwassmannWachmannd18092004.jpg

29P in 28/08/2004
http://astrosurf.com/paulobg/dso/29pschwassmannwachmann.jpg

Comet 78P Gehrels
http://astrosurf.com/paulobg/dso/78PGehrelsd19092004.jpg

78P in 21/08:
http://astrosurf.com/paulobg/dso/78pgehrels.jpg

Best Regards
Paulo

Hi all
Seeing its quite? belatedly processed another of the pics of Q4 from night
of 25th april 2004 - this one has less star trailing but was last shot of
night of Q4 so closer to horizon - so has some subvisual cloud causing a red
light fog I think

Large self indulgent files beware! third and 4th ones down

Date:  Wed, 22 Sep 2004 02:54:40 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  2 Comets - 09/22/2004 - 0200UT
C/2003 T4 & C/2001 Q4. Each image is 74x56 arc-min with N up. 5x60
sec exp. Q4 is showing more tail than I was expecting and was a
pleasant surprise. Thanks, Mike H.

C/2001 Q4
http://www.fototime.com/1299942DCD3D99A/standard.jpg

Date:  Wed, 22 Sep 2004 16:59:37 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS: V - 2004 Sept 21 - and images
Hi all,

observed the following comets this morning, and imaged Q2 and R2. Of note are that I could visually detect tails in both comets C/2004 Q2 (Machholz) and C/2004 R2 (ASAS)...

CometObs -

C/2004 Q1 (Tucker) 2004 September 21.63 UT: m1 = 11.8, Dia.= 1'6, DC = 5, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Q1 appears as a faintish smudge with some central condensation. 37* alt in the N. Stellar LM =15.4 (scope)].

C/2004 Q2 (Machholz) 2004 September 21.65 UT: m1 = 10.2, Dia.= 2'.5, DC = 6, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Q2 appears as a nice, bright coma with much central condensation. Faint tail also visible (~3' in PA of ~260d). Images I took reveals a tail of about 7' in a PA of 250*. 45* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.6 (scope)].

C/2004 R2 (ASAS) 2004 September 21.69 UT: m1 = 8.2, Dia.= 3'.0, DC = 5, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [R2 easily seen. The coma has a nice central condensation. Fiant tail visible (~10' of PA 30d). 23* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.0 (scope)].

ICQ -

C/2004 Q1 (Tucker)
Sept 21.63, 11.8, 1'6, (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 41cm L).

C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)
Sept 21.65, 10.2, 2'.5, (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 41cm L).

C/2004 R2 (ASAS)
Sept 21.69, 8.2, 3'.0, (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 41cm L).

JPL (NASA) -

C/2004 Q1 (Tucker)
2004 September 21.63 UT: m1=11.8, Dia.=1'6, DC = 5/9, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Q1 appears as a faintish smudge with some central condensation. 37* alt in the N. Stellar LM =15.4 (scope)].

C/2004 Q2 (Machholz) 2004 September 21.65 UT: m1=10.2, Dia.=2'.5, DC = 6/9, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Q2 appears as a nice, bright coma with much central condensation. Faint tail also visible (~3' in PA of ~260d). Images I took reveals a tail of about 7' in a PA of 250*. 45* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.6 (scope)].

C/2004 R2 (ASAS) 2004 September 21.69 UT: m1=8.2, Dia.= 3'.0, DC = 5/9, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [R2 easily seen. The coma has a nice central condensation. Fiant tail visible (~10' of PA 30d). 23* alt in the E. Stellar LM =15.0 (scope)].

Images can be seen at: (please note, the dates should be September 21 - not 22!!!)

C/Machholz -

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2004q2(machholz)-040922-6cf-1min@800asa-text.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/63wx3

C/ASAS -

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2004r2(asas)-040922-6cf-1min@800asa-text.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/3s6kj

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sun, 03 Oct 2004 03:16:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 T4 - 10/03/2004 - 0215UT

Not far from Q4 is another small comet. I worked the image a bit to
show a bit more detail. Like Q4 this is a 5x60 sec stack. I took
the images with a 2x2 bin. The FOV was 74x56 arc-min to start with
and the image was 800 pixels wide. I then resized it to 1000 pix
wide and inverted with a crop to about 40 arc-min wide. Thanks, Mike
H.

http://www.fototime.com/1FE5D9AFF417958/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/1FE5D9AFF417958/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 03 Oct 2004 09:01:48 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2003 T4 - 10/03/2004 - 0215UT
Excellent image as usual and developing into a fine comet; Mike: what are your orientations on this image?

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatory
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
http://www.arksky.org/

and is certified Virus and Spam-free

From: tricks46

Sent: Saturday, October 02, 2004 10:16 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2003 T4 - 10/03/2004 - 0215UT

Not far from Q4 is another small comet. I worked the image a bit to
show a bit more detail. Like Q4 this is a 5x60 sec stack. I took
the images with a 2x2 bin. The FOV was 74x56 arc-min to start with
and the image was 800 pixels wide. I then resized it to 1000 pix
wide and inverted with a crop to about 40 arc-min wide. Thanks, Mike
H.

Date:  Sun, 03 Oct 2004 17:37:56 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: C/2003 T4 - 10/03/2004 - 0215UT

My orentation is not perfectly N up and E to the left but it is
close. I didn't have new flats so I left the mount as is for last
nights session. The brighter star a little above and just to the
right of the comet is GSC 4168 605 at magnitude 10.83. The upper of
the two bright stars on the right of the image is GSC 4161 323 at
magnitude 9.08. Thanks, Mike

Date:  Sun, 03 Oct 2004 17:54:46 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Q4?

Hello Eric. My post contained the comet, date and time. I will in
the future state the comet name a little clearer in the text. It is
C/2001 Q4 (NEAT)from 10/03/2004 - 0200UT. It is a good target still
sitting in the area of Ursa Major just after dark. The cordinates I
used at the time of the imaging was RA 14-21-44 DC +67-55-02.

The comet is listed at Magnitude 9.2. Above and to the right is a
double looking set of stars GSC 4403 1132 at magnitude 11.34 and GSC
4403 1118 at magnitude 10.77. Below and to the right of the comet is
GSC 4403-1103 at magnitude 7.31 and next to it on it's right is GSC
4403 1097 1 at magnitude 11.. The orentation of the image is basicly
N-up and E to the left. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 05 Oct 2004 17:41:03 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2001 Q4 - 10/03/2004 - 0200UT

Hi Mike,

I was just considering imaging Q4 tonight so I referred to your
image. You might consider a more aggressive histogram stretch as it
looks a bit dark on my monitor. I stretched the image and brought
out a tail that extends for half the image height, which must be
around 15 arc minutes. I hope the tail is still there tonight!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm,
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward.htm> or
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

Date:  Thu, 07 Oct 2004 16:22:54 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet C/2001 Q4 NEAT

Comet C/2001Q4 NEAT has now sprouted a 27 arc-minute long tail.

I have a new web page illustrating the comet, its orbit and
isophotes.

Images and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Equipment: Takahashi E160 f/3.3 astrograph, AP1200GTO, and SXV-H9
camera. Image 28 x 2 minutes, unguided, binned 2x2. To bring out
more of the tail, I probably should have binned 3x3 or maybe even
4x4. Resolution is not important in this application.

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Thu, 07 Oct 2004 18:31:37 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Comet C/2001 Q4 NEAT
> Comet C/2001Q4 NEAT has now sprouted a 27 arc-minute long tail.
>
> I have a new web page illustrating the comet, its orbit and
> isophotes.

Hello Dennis,
nice shot, indeed. It seems to me that the coma is somehow elongated. Have you tried to elaborate the image with a rotational-gradient algorithm (like Larson-Sekanina)?
Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Obs, Italy)

____________________________________________________________
Libero ADSL: navighi gratis a 1.2 Mega, senza canone e costi di attivazione.
Abbonati subito su http://www.libero.it 

Date:  Thu, 07 Oct 2004 17:01:19 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Comet C/2001 Q4 NEAT

Hello Giovanni,

I noticed the possible elongation of the coma but I was not sure if
perhaps it was an artifact due to the influence of a nearby star. I
have not yet learned how to apply the very powerful Larson-Sekanina
algorithm which I have in AstroArt 3.0. I would be very grateful if
you could process my images and make the determination as to the
coma shape. I can send you them in any format and file size.

Thanks for the feedback.

Clear skies,

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gvnn64\@l...\.it"

> > isophotes.
>

> Cheers,
> Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Obs, Italy)

Date:  Thu, 07 Oct 2004 23:49:47 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comet C/2001 Q4-From 05 to 10

Greetings. Weather permitting I have imaged this comet as often as I
could. I went back and put together 14 images covering 05/04 thru
10/03/2004. The changing perspective we have helps me to understand
which way the tail(s)point. It is interesting to me to see one tail
grow while the other is reduced in size according to perspective in
some cases. I would think that the tail less visible behind the head
at this time will appear to the west of the comet center in the near
future as we orbit around. I hope the comet maintains a good
brightness in the future so I can increase this collection. I hope
this looks better on your screen than it does on aol. There are two
file sizes below so you can select which suits you. Thanks, Mike H.
future.

Small File 250kb

http://www.fototime.com/9CAAFEA1806A4C3/orig.jpg

Full Size

http://www.fototime.com/ACDEDD0DE8A4393/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 08 Oct 2004 03:13:50 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2001 Q4 NEAT

Correction: My web page images were labeled 6 Sept and should have
been labeled 6 Oct. I apologize for any possible confusion. I have
corrected the errors.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Sat, 09 Oct 2004 02:43:48 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 K4 - 04 to 09/2004

The fall rains have arrived and imaging is slow. Gives me a chance
to put together another brief history of another comet. This covers
from April 2004 to September 2004. Once again I hope this look
better on your screen than it does on mine (aol) which destroys these
kinds of published images. This is why I usually post a small and
large file as it seems to help. Cheers! Mike H.

small file 180kb

http://www.fototime.com/393A997F0185064/orig.jpg

large file 800kb

http://www.fototime.com/57B1F5ECDF31087/orig.jpg

Date:  Sun, 10 Oct 2004 18:12:59 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  comet images Oct 8-9 2004
Hello All,

Please find an update on my website, images of comets taken on Oct 8-9th:

2004 Q2 Machholz: Note the ion and dust tails.
2004 Q1 Tucker: rendesvous with galaxy NGC 681
29P SW1 in outburst again
79P Gehrels
2004 T1 LINEAR-NEAT new periodic comet.

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

Cheers,
Michael

Date:  Sun, 10 Oct 2004 15:46:53 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet images Oct 8-9 2004
> 29P SW1 in outburst again
>
> http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

> Michael

Hi Michael, Beautiful images really!
Particularly I find very interesting the image that reproduces the new 29P outburst.

Would someone in this list know me to explain how come a comet that is distant 5-6 UAs from the Sun continues to have these visible periodic outbursts every year (that precedent has happened ago less than one month)?

regards

Rolando

Date:  Tue, 12 Oct 2004 22:24:56 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet images Oct 8-9 2004
Hi Rolando,

29P has been very active over the past couple of years at least.
My guess is that there is a fresh CO2 rich area exposed on the surface that
rotates into sunlight periodically.
Perhaps you should ask this question to the comet group.

regards,
Michael

Date:  Tue, 19 Oct 2004 20:36:30 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  3 Comets From 10/19/2004

Imaged 3 comets after dark. C/2003 T4, C/2004 Q1 & C/2001 Q4. All
images are a 4x60 sec exposures. 74x56 arc-min FOV. 4" refractor @
F5.3 and ST2000XM CCD. Small and large files are linked except for
the Q4 negative which I reduced in size. I also image the area where
C/2004 S1 is located and have not been able to find it with blinking,
stacking or any thing else I tried. Thanks, Mike H.
C/2003 T4
http://fototime.com/80CC8532C5ACE09/standard.jpg
http://fototime.com/80CC8532C5ACE09/orig.jpg

C/2004 Q1
http://fototime.com/DCB547AF7F4BB84/standard.jpg
http://fototime.com/DCB547AF7F4BB84/orig.jpg

C/2001 Q4
http://fototime.com/5188A5C3B534657/standard.jpg
http://fototime.com/5188A5C3B534657/orig.jpg

C/2001 Q4 - Negative
http://fototime.com/2F4E2367A060BD6/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 20 Oct 2004 15:27:46 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS/V and image of C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)
Hi all,

observed C/2004 Q2 (Machholz) this morning...

CometObs -

C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)

2004 October 19.63 UT: m1 = 8.1, Dia.= 6'.0, DC = 5, Tail = 12' PA 265, 20cm f4 Reflect (26x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Q2 lookingsizeable and bright. Large coma with definate nucleus. Fan shaped tail easily seen in the 41cm (12' in PA of ~265d). 56* alt in the E. Stellar LM =13.2 (scope)].

ICQ -

C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)

October 19.63, 8.1, 6'.0, (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 20cm f4 Reflect).

JPL (NASA) -

C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)

2004 October 19.63 UT: m1=8.1, Dia.=6'.0, DC=5/9, Tail=12' PA 265, 20cm f4 Reflect (26x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Q2 lookingsizeable and bright. Large coma with definate nucleus. Fan shaped tail easily seen in the 41cm (12' in PA of ~265d). 56* alt in the E. Stellar LM =13.2 (scope)].

Images of this comet can be seen at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2004q2-machholz-041019-7cf-90sec@1600asa-text.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/4ayle

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 21 Oct 2004 14:52:59 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images


Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /Two excellent sites for imaging
Uploaded by : obsessionowner
Description : Webcam Autoguiding Software and Guide Port Interface Products

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Two%20excellent%20sites%20for%20imaging

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

obsessionowner 

Date:  Thu, 21 Oct 2004 18:49:15 -0000
From:  T 
Subject:  Comets 78P and C/2004 Q1

Hello with all,

I am new on the list, I espere to be able to improve my techniques!
my last images are: 78P and C/2004 Q1 Tucker. I cannot thus write
in English I use a translator.Excuse me for the errors.
the images are on my Internet site here:

http://napac.free.fr/dernieres_images.htm

S.Takbou 

Date:  Thu, 21 Oct 2004 19:21:15 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Comets 78P and C/2004 Q1

You have a very interesting and informative web site.

I am also interested in imaging 78P when the moon subsides. What
scope, camera and acquisition time did you use? Also, how dark are
your skies? My visual limiting magnitude varies from about 2.5 to
4.0.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Thu, 21 Oct 2004 20:19:39 -0000
From:  T 
Subject:  Material used

hello with all
I use Schmidt cassegrain of 203 mm with a reducer 6,3 and one camera
Sbig ST7. The visual magnitude limits is 5.0. Luminous pollution is
trés significant because I live in a city.
S.Takbou

http://napac.free.fr

Observatoire de l'abbaye
Nord : 50°52'48"
Est : 02°28'18"
Altitude: 16 m

Code UAI : A11
S.Takbou 

Date:  Fri, 22 Oct 2004 01:24:02 +0200
From:  Stéphane Garro 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 3 Comets From 10/19/2004
Hello Mike,

Le mardi, 19 oct 2004, à 22:36 Europe/Paris, tricks46 a écrit :
> the Q4 negative which I reduced in size. I also image the area where
> C/2004 S1 is located and have not been able to find it with blinking,
> stacking or any thing else I tried. Thanks, Mike H.

This comet is very diffuse and due to its rapid apparent motion hard to
detect.
I also failed to catch it at the F/6,3 focus of a C11 with a ST7 camera
in binning 2x2 (2"/pixel, 9s exposures), but it appears on single
images taken with the same configuration and binning 3x3 (3"/pixel and
12s exposure) as a "ghost" comet, ie very faint surfacic magnitude and
almost transparent... Nice in blink.
I haven't made the compositage yet.

Did you try to make a compositage after substracting the stars of the
field ?

Nice observations to everybody, Stephane 

Date:  Fri, 22 Oct 2004 13:52:57 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 3 Comets From 10/19/2004

I am loading the animation I have been looking at to try and find
this comet. The information at the time this was taken is the
Position according to Guide8. It is only a 6 minute gap but as fast
as the comet is moving I should see movement.
21 31 29
+22 00 30
18 Oct 2004
19:47 or 00:47UT
fov 54x76 arc-min
N is up - E is left
I have added a small arrow showing a star and according to the chart
the comet would have been located below the arrow a few arc-min.
Each image is a 60 sec exp and I was having a rough time with frost
around the edge of the chip with weather temps rising 45 deg in
24hrs. and humidity way up. Maybe I just missed it I don't know.
Mike

http://www.fototime.com/2B028B44BFCAFBF/orig.gif

http://www.fototime.com/2B028B44BFCAFBF/orig.gif 

Date:  Fri, 22 Oct 2004 17:16:25 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: 3 Comets From 10/19/2004

Hi Mike,

I don't see anything. Guide 8 tells you what the relative motion is
(More Info) and for S1 it is 7 arc minutes /hour = 7 arc seconds per
minute. So it should smear of 42 arc seconds length on your image.
It isn't there. You do have some hot pixels that come and go and
offer false motion artifacts elsewhere in the image.

There is some software called Astrometrica that is perfect for
finding dim comets. I have not figured out how to use it but someday
I might. But honestly, I'd rather be able to see the comet in my
image instead of having some software package tell me it's there!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

info was given but the faint nature of so many stacks for this comet,

Hopefully someone will point out the comet or what I did wrong.
Cheers! Mike

Date:  Fri, 22 Oct 2004 23:41:35 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: 3 Comets From 10/19/2004

Hi Mike,

I agree that 15 mag should be within your reach. I think we have
both discovered that comets that we should be able to image
sometimes just don't turn out. In particular, if you can't see the
comet in each frame, there is no way to visually stack on the head,
so many exposures don't help. That's where you need Astrometrica
which calculates where the comet should be and stacks according to
the orbital parameters.

I find that I can easily loose a magnitude or more of delectability
if the sky transparency is not good or if the comet is low and
oriented towards the Chicago area.

Clear skies,

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46"

Date:  Mon, 25 Oct 2004 10:49:15 +0200
From:  stefan_beck@cometchaser.de
Subject:  Anybody tried Comet ASAS 2004 R2 recently ?
Hi list,

I tried to get comet ASAS 2004 R2 on 24th. Oct. around 18.00 UT after it
has arrived on the Northern Hemisphere.

Unfortunately I couldn't get it. I imaged stars as faint as 16.5 mag but
no comet.

I could image NEAT 2001Q4 with a faint tail all with strong moonlight.

Does anybody got it ?

Stefan 

Date:  Mon, 25 Oct 2004 13:41:58 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  C/2001 Q4 (NEAT) antitail?
Hello,
about C/2001 Q4 (NEAT): it's worth to notice how on October 23 there was the crossing of the orbital plane of this comet by Earth. According Luigi Pansecchi (CARA-Italian Comet Section) the conditions for the detection of a possible anti-tail will last for several days further. If anyone of you have images spanning from Oct.21 to Oct.27, please notify it.
Regards,
Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Obs, CARA)

____________________________________________________________
Libero ADSL: navighi gratis a 1.2 Mega, senza canone e costi di attivazione.
Abbonati subito su http://www.libero.it 

Date:  Mon, 25 Oct 2004 15:35:28 -0001

Hello Stefan,

> has arrived on the Northern Hemisphere.
>
> Unfortunately I couldn't get it. I imaged stars as faint as 16.5 mag but
> no comet.

22.10., both times without success.

Bernd

Bernd Brinkmann

Date:  Mon, 25 Oct 2004 15:28:52 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Anybody tried Comet ASAS 2004 R2 recently ?

Hi Stefan,

What was the comet's elevation and angular separation from the moon
when you tried on the 24th?

Seiichi Yoshida
http://www.aerith.net/comet/weekly/current.html
says m1=14.4. If the nucleus is not a point source but rather an
extended source, then it seems possible that you could image 16.5
magnitude stars and still miss the comet. Perhaps others can better
explain the discrepancy.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Mon, 01 Nov 2004 11:37:26 +0100
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  New images
Hi list,

I have uploaded images from comets 62P/Tsuchinshan, 69P/Taylor, C/2001
Q4 NEAT (showing the antitail), C/2003T4 LINEAR, 129P/Shoemaker-Levy,
C/2003 WT42 LINEAR, C/2004 U1 LINEAR.

Have a look at www.fg-kometen.de/bildere.htm.

I have also updated my personal webpage with the image of C/2001 Q4 NEAT
taken on 24. Oct. 2004 showing the antitail.

Comments are always welcome.
--

Stefan Beck

http://www.cometchaser.de
"Astrophotography with small telescopes"

http://www.cometchaser.de/d_index.html
"Astrophotography with small telescopes auf Deutsch"

"Informationen zu OS/2, warum OS/2 ?"

Date:  Sat, 06 Nov 2004 05:45:49 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2004 Q1-11062004

A new mount is giving me fits. Managed to finally put one comet on
the chip after weeks of rain and rebuilding the mount and pedestal.
This is a 90 sec image of comet Q1 with a 54x76 arc-min fov using the
4" refractor @ 5.3 and ccd. Lots of work and a sharp learning curve
left before this setup works for imaging. comets. Mike H.

http://fototime.com/CC0CC485D294932/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/CC0CC485D294932/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 06 Nov 2004 16:34:06 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 Q1-11062004

Hi Mike,

What is the new mount? When I switched from my trusty LX-90 goto
fork mount to an AP1200QMD with mechanical setting circles I
couldn't find any of my targets. I installed digital setting
circles but they only got me to within about 20 arc minutes, so I
still had problems. Now I have a goto GEM and I can find things
again. Good luck with the new mount.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46"
wrote:
>
> A new mount is giving me fits. Managed to finally put one comet
on the chip after weeks of rain and rebuilding the mount and
pedestal.
> This is a 90 sec image of comet Q1 with a 54x76 arc-min fov using
the 4" refractor @ 5.3 and ccd. Lots of work and a sharp learning
curve left before this setup works for imaging. comets. Mike H.
>
> http://fototime.com/CC0CC485D294932/standard.jpg
>
> http://fototime.com/CC0CC485D294932/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 06 Nov 2004 21:38:40 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 Q1-11062004

Hello Dennis. I am moving the FSQ106 off the back of the 10" LX200
Meade and placing it on a permanent mount with a losmandy GM-8 and
Gemini GO-TO under the dome. I am so trained to use the fork mount
that the GM is just a bit different. You know what they say, you
can't teach an old dog new tricks----well you can it just takes
longer. Mike

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
wrote:
>
> Hi Mike,
>
> What is the new mount? When I switched from my trusty LX-90 goto
> fork mount to an AP1200QMD with mechanical setting circles I
> couldn't find any of my targets. I installed digital setting
> circles but they only got me to within about 20 arc minutes, so I
> still had problems. Now I have a goto GEM and I can find things
> again. Good luck with the new mount.
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net

Date:  Sun, 07 Nov 2004 17:24:21 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Q1 & Q2 - 11072004

Working on images and adjusting the mount between images last night
under bad seeing conditions with high thin clouds. Still managed to
put two comets on the chip. I like C/2004 Q1 as it sits overhead at
dark but C/2004 Q2 is , IMO, going to be a really nice comet already
showing faint tails one of which continues off the frame. The 56x74
arc-min FOV will not be close to covering this comet before long.
Light polution in the South, hight thin clouds and A Moon rise all
degrade this image of Q2. The images are 180 seconds each and the
orentation is N up, I think. The fork mount always had N up the GM
is not so straight forward. Posted a small and original size file
for each with a Negative for each. Thanks, Mike H.

C/2004 Q1
http://fototime.com/FE6647E5E6D36F0/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/FE6647E5E6D36F0/orig.jpg

Negative
http://fototime.com/77E9FB275C51B8B/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/77E9FB275C51B8B/orig.jpg

C/2004 Q2
http://fototime.com/3992F8D5EF0DC1F/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/3992F8D5EF0DC1F/orig.jpg

Negative
http://fototime.com/CE27EA95165AD99/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/CE27EA95165AD99/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 07 Nov 2004 20:12:15 -0000
From:  Paulo Bénard Guedes 
Subject:  78P Gehrels
Hi:

Below you can view an image of Comet 78P Gehrels taken yesterday night.
http://astrosurf.com/paulobg/dso/78PGehrelsd06112004.jpg

I've measured with Astrometrica it's position and magnitude and got 12.9
Nuclear, on Setember I got 13.9 N so I guess it really is brigtning. If you
wish to see some results of astrometry and an image of the 19/09/2004 to
compare please visit:

http://astrosurf.com/paulobg/78pg.htm

Anyway, yesterday I got the following results with 2 images taken some 3
hours apart:

TIME UT: 06/11/2004 22H38M42S RA: 03 18 24.49 DEC: +14 26 58.5
Magnitude: 13.9N

e

TIME UT: 07/11/2004 01H15M02S RA: 03 18 21.07 DEC: +14 26 13.0
Magnitude: 13.9N

Best Regards
Paulo 

Date:  Tue, 09 Nov 2004 16:47:48 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet C/2004 Q1 Tucker

I have a new web page illustrating the comet, its orbit, eyepiece
view and a short movie of its 1.8 arc minute journey through
Andromeda. Don't miss the movie (rated G)!

Images (modem-friendly) at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Equipment: Takahashi E160 f/3.3 astrograph, AP1200GTO, and MX716
camera.

The hardest part was equalizing the background of all those frames
for the movie. Is there a batch process available with any of the
image processing software to handle that?

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Sun, 14 Nov 2004 00:24:21 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  For All Members of Comet Images.

Greetings. Please let me say that the Comet-Images board does not
apply to "pretty images" only. This board was created at a time
when the comet-ml board was being overun with post and images which
did not apply to the issue of the discussion of comets. I talked to
Maik and we agree that each issue has it's place. Discussion, images
and observations. Please be assured that the comet-images board is a
place for individual's images and sketches. This includes all images
from all individuals. Here we do not judge good or bad. Past
experience shows that all images are of value, sometimes more than
you know. We only ask that you explain the processing of the images
so that the value of each image can be applied if needed. I have
noticed images being loaded to the photo and file section which go
unposted therefore unoticed. Please post a note or link for these so
the members can take advantage of your work. If we all work
together, all comet boards will function appropriately especially
with brighter comets in the future. Thanks, Mike Holloway

Date:  Sat, 20 Nov 2004 13:00:21 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  A Comet Turns On
FYI
A Comet Turns On (see below) info from Sky and Telescope email news.
So what actually do they call this object- a comet or an asteroid?

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
member, ASKC-Astronomical Society of Kansas City,
Olathe, KS. USA,
JPL / NASA Solar System Ambassador, Kansas:
Comets Award Coordinator, Astronomical League,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm,
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward.htm> or
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com
****
A Comet Turns On

What began as the routine discovery of a near-Earth asteroid on October
10th took on a curious and dramatic twist a month later when the new find
suddenly developed a narrow tail. Franco Mallia, Gianluca Masi, and Roger
Wilcox first spotted the pencil-thin appendage in CCD images they'd taken
on November 11th with a 0.36-meter reflector at Las Campanas Observatory,
Chile. The tail independently turned up in CCD frames taken less than a
day later by Juan Lacruz in La Canada, Spain. No one yet knows what caused
the tail to form (two other asteroids-turned-comets,
107P/Wilson-Harrington and 133P/Elst-Pizarro, have been discovered in
recent decades). But observers are certain it wasn't there when Rob
McNaught first recorded the asteroid, designated 2004 TU12, using a
0.5-meter Schmidt telescope at Australia's Siding Spring Observatory. A
preliminary orbit issued by the Minor Planet Center puts Comet Siding
Spring (now bearing the official comet designation P/2004 TU12) between
the orbits of Earth and Mars, near the perihelion of a looping,
5.3-year-long track. At 14th magnitude, it's too faint to be seen visually
in small telescopes.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Mon, 22 Nov 2004 01:25:13 -0000
From:  michael_caligiuri 
Subject:  New Image of  C/2004 Q2

I've been away from the group for a few months, but with the bright
Northern comets such as Machholz now in range, I thought I'd take the
opportunity to post an image I took last weekend from our dark
desert site east of San Diego. This is a 40-minute image of Comet
Machholz using an SXV-H9c camera and an 80mm Stellarvue refractor.
Other details are with the image at:

http://psych102-143.ucsd.edu/~Mike/machholz.html

Comments welcome.

-Mike

Date:  Mon, 22 Nov 2004 16:00:08 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Comet image stacking experiment

Along with my previously posted image of C/2004 Q2 (Machholz), I took
two additional images right after it. Here I've hand-stacked the
other two in an attempt to bring out more of the tails, but I don't
know if it really does much and is worth the effort. Since these are
film images, it takes a considerable effort to hand-stack the images
due to the possibility of non-linear warping of the film during
imaging and/or scanning, expecially over the area of a medium format
image. In fact, the resulting stack here is far from perfect even
though it is a crop of the original frames.

Stack:
Single:

Let me know what you think anything is really gained out of a film
stack. Thanks.

Dave 

Date:  Mon, 22 Nov 2004 16:59:09 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Comet image stacking experiment

Dave. It does show more of the fainter portions of the tail.
Did you tried stacking two or three images on the stars and see what
the comet movement looks like? Mike

In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "d_kodama" wrote:
>
> Along with my previously posted image of C/2004 Q2 (Machholz), I

> two additional images right after it. Here I've hand-stacked the
> other two in an attempt to bring out more of the tails, but I don't
> know if it really does much and is worth the effort. Since these
are

images

> stack. Thanks.

Date:  Mon, 22 Nov 2004 17:25:10 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Comet image stacking experiment

Mike,

The comet was moving very slowly. It's near the point where the
orbital track loops back on itself from our viewpoint. It's not
obvious, but each individual shot of 45 minutes is actually tracked on
the comet although the stars look like they have barely trailed.

As far as film images are concerned, the stacking will only be
possible when a comet is positioned well away from the horizon. Most
comets are too close to the horizon for a sequence of shots and are
buried in the twilight glow gradient which causes havoc in combining
shots.

Dave

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Dave. It does show more of the fainter portions of the tail.
> Did you tried stacking two or three images on the stars and see what
> the comet movement looks like? Mike

or rained or there was the fog!!! Last week we have had three beautiful night with a lot
of wind, this has chased away the clouds, but worsened the seeing.

as for the comets of the last years.

However to make images I also have my apo 114/600 that with the ccd SXVH9 allows me to
have a field of 51'x39; I am thinking about purchasing a SXV M25, what do you think of it?

Date:  Mon, 22 Nov 2004 11:54:57 -0800
From:  "Michael P. Caligiuri, Ph.D." 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: comet images

Hello Rolando. On the SXV M25 is developing a strong positive
impression. The only limitation is that sensitivity may be reduced because
of the color format of the chip. This is one problem I have with the H9c -
the luminance in 25% as sensitive as the monochrome camera. I wonder if I
had used the H9 monochrome to take this image, would the tail have been
more distinct. I would wait to see if Starlight comes up with a monochrome
version of the camera.

Looking forward to seeing your images -- when the skies clear.

-Mike

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 22 Nov 2004 11:57:51 -0800
From:  "Michael P. Caligiuri, Ph.D." 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New Image of  C/2004 Q2
Rolando - processing of images from color CCD cameras can be more
challenging and the sensitivity is reduced relative to monochrome; however,
in the field, there is no need to play around with filters, refocusing, or
loosing data because of changing conditions. I prefer to keep thinks
simple in the field and work a little harder when at home processing the
data. Thanks for your comments.

-Mike

At 07:54 PM 11/22/2004 +0100, you wrote:
> > I've been away from the group for a few months, but with the bright

http://www.tip.net.au/~vello/2004q2/041122b.jpg

Cheers,
Vello 

Date:  Tue, 23 Nov 2004 06:53:58 -0800
From:  "Michael P. Caligiuri, Ph.D." 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)
Burkhard: Thanks for posting such as nice image. The colors from your
DSLR match very closely with my image from a single shot color CCD
camera (see previous post). I am always looking for DSLR images to
validate my color processing -- Thanks !

-Mike C.

Date:  Thu, 25 Nov 2004 17:53:39 +1300
From:  John_Drummond 
Subject:  Comet article contributors
Hi all,

this is ancient history, but some of you may recall that I wrote an article on Comets LINEAR (2001 Q4) and NEAT's (2002 T7) close aspiration earlier this year (for The Royal Astronomical Society of New Zealand's 'Southern Stars' journal (Volume 43, No. 3 - 2004 September)) and asked for some people to contribute images. Well, the journal came out about two months ago and I have recently sent complimentary copies to those folk whose images featured in the article - namely Terry Lovejoy, Frank and Karin Niebling, Gerald Rhemann, and Vello Tabur. For the others who did submit images and they weren't included, I am so sorry that they were not published but my hands were tied by the space/cost constraints of the editor.

My sincere thanks to all who submitted photos...

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 26 Nov 2004 23:23:21 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  comet Machholz color pic
Greetings all

I took this color picture with the RGB pics with the Harvard scope I use.
Comet Machholz if between 6-7 magnitude and possibly is expected to go to mag 4
later in Dec. It is looking bright with a nice nucleus and faint coma but no
tail. It is light yellow-green-white.
My pic is at
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward3.htm
On my main web page and others, I have pics of Ikeya Zhang, F4, Q4 and many
others.
There are several other nice comets in the sky currently. If you are
interested in gaining the Silver award by the Astronomy League that I created, please
contact me and I will send you additional information. You need to be a member
of the AL or a astro society linked to the AL to gain the awards.
Silver award winners (need 12 comets( get our real cool comet award pin
and a signed certificate of Hale-Bopp. There is a Gold award too.

With all the comets lately since 2001, I think many of you would be well on
the way to earning a comet award.
It is a lot of fun to hunt comets and capture them on your CCD, camera or
illustrate them. Looking forward to hearing from you all.

MOre information about the award etc are below.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
member, ASKC-Astronomical Society of Kansas City,
Olathe, KS. USA,
JPL / NASA Solar System Ambassador, Kansas:
Comets Award Coordinator, Astronomical League,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm,
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward.htm> or
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 28 Nov 2004 01:49:57 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  3 comets from 11/28/2004

Bright Moon on the rise but clear skys for the first time in weeks.
All images are 5x40 sec exp. with a fov of 74x56 arc-min. 4"
refractor and ST2K ccd.
C/2004 Q1

http://www.fototime.com/5B08208E7D45C95/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/5B08208E7D45C95/orig.jpg

C/2001 Q4

http://www.fototime.com/BEA3B422ADEDFCB/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/BEA3B422ADEDFCB/orig.jpg

C/2003 T4

http://www.fototime.com/14EE44923E8D9F5/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/14EE44923E8D9F5/orig.jpg

Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 28 Nov 2004 03:47:38 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Spiral-like structure in C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)
Hello all
in spite of the bright moonlight, few hours ago we imaged C/2004 Q2 (Machholz) with a Cousins I filter. There is clear evidence of an arch-like strucure emerging from the central condensation in PA 330 deg, and extending at least 10 arcmin toward west, north-west, in a spiral-like feature. The image is available in the Photos area of this mailing-list homepage, in the folder Remanzacco Observatory.
Kind regards,
Giovanni Sostero and Antonio Lepardo
Remanzacco Observatory, Italy

____________________________________________________________
Libero ADSL: navighi gratis a 1.2 Mega, senza canone e costi di attivazione.
Abbonati subito su http://www.libero.it 

Date:  Sun, 28 Nov 2004 14:09:51 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  62P/Tsuchinshan?
I have imaged what I think is comet 62P/Tsuchinshan. It is quite faint but I
show it moving across the starry background stars in Leo a couple of nights
ago. It seems to be in the place that I have checked with Starry Nigh Pro but I
can't quite figure it out the stars next to it although I am pretty sure that
is it.

Can anyone check the 2 pictures and confirm the objects moving as
62P/Tsuchinshan
? The link is at
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward3.htm

Also I have color pic I took of comet Machholz. I have other links to my
pages of comets as well with some other ones as color going back to 2001 and
before. I am still work on page 2-3 and getting them better prepared.
Also anyone else is welcome to find out more about the AL comet awards at my
links below and try for the awards. ? let me know

Date:  Sun, 28 Nov 2004 14:14:23 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Q2 - Machholz
Excellent image Mike....the comet is so very low in the south now that you did an excellent job; we posted an unprocessed (astrometric) image on the ASO website ( www.arksky.org ) to show a comparison of the large coma with the very well defined nucleus of this comet from last night as well; it gives a sense of the development of the core of the comet in relation to the extended coma cloud....

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatory
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

Date:  Sun, 28 Nov 2004 21:15:07 -0000
From:  Juan Lacruz 
Subject:  Re: A Comet Turns On (and off)

It woke up to show us the beautiful tail at the precisse time of
perihelion passage coincident with the crossing of the ecliptic
(nodes). After a few days it's sleeping again.

I would call this one a dormant comet. It is now officialy 162P, for
the IAU it's then a comet.

Excuse me if I didn't post here any image at the moment of the
discovery, I was busy with too many posts back and forth to comets-
ml, to the mpc and cbat, and the Spanish list of comet observers.

Pictures and assorted miscellaneus info at my site :

http://www.astrosurf.com/juan_lacruz

See the news or the discovery section, I hope you enjoy it.
Best greetings.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, KCStarguy@a... wrote:
> FYI
> A Comet Turns On (see below) info from Sky and Telescope email news.
> So what actually do they call this object- a comet or an asteroid?
>
> Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@a...),
> member, ASKC-Astronomical Society of Kansas City,
> Olathe, KS. USA,
> JPL / NASA Solar System Ambassador, Kansas:
> Comets Award Coordinator, Astronomical League,
> http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html,
> http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm,
> http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward.htm> or
> (send messages to the network at )
CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
> Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email
to :
> CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com
> ****
> A Comet Turns On
>
> What began as the routine discovery of a near-Earth asteroid on
October
> 10th took on a curious and dramatic twist a month later when the
new find
> suddenly developed a narrow tail. Franco Mallia, Gianluca Masi, and
Roger
> Wilcox first spotted the pencil-thin appendage in CCD images they'd
taken
> on November 11th with a 0.36-meter reflector at Las Campanas
Observatory,
> Chile. The tail independently turned up in CCD frames taken less
than a
> day later by Juan Lacruz in La Canada, Spain. No one yet knows what
caused
> the tail to form (two other asteroids-turned-comets,
> 107P/Wilson-Harrington and 133P/Elst-Pizarro, have been discovered
in
> recent decades). But observers are certain it wasn't there when Rob
> McNaught first recorded the asteroid, designated 2004 TU12, using a
> 0.5-meter Schmidt telescope at Australia's Siding Spring
Observatory. A
> preliminary orbit issued by the Minor Planet Center puts Comet
Siding
> Spring (now bearing the official comet designation P/2004 TU12)
between
> the orbits of Earth and Mars, near the perihelion of a looping,
> 5.3-year-long track. At 14th magnitude, it's too faint to be seen
visually
> in small telescopes.
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 30 Nov 2004 14:30:53 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  C/2004 Q2 - Megrez, ST7 - My take at this comet

G'day all,

I only learned of this comet a few days ago (not quite sure how I
missed it coming, such is life). So tonight I took a shot at imaging
it. I'm quite happy with the results, although it's a shame I can't
shorten the focal length more to get more of the tail in the FOV.

Two images with details at:
http://members.iinet.net.au/~rog1/astro/gallery/photo/galleryComets/

Roger.
================================================
Roger Groom roger[AT]RogerGroom.com
http://www.RogerGroom.com/
* Astronomy, Photography & Astro Photography
* "Southern Amateur Astronomy" Info Pages.
================================================

Date:  Tue, 30 Nov 2004 23:15:55 -0000
From:  Roger 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 Q2 - Megrez, ST7 - My take at this comet

Thanks Mike. I found it interesting the difference in detail between
the two exposures (which total the same time but integration length
being different). I thought I'd leave both there as a comparison, as
a learner with CCD I've often wished I could see comparisons like
that.

And for those who noticed I spelt the comet name wrong, it's now
fixed... sorry about that.

Roger.

Roger Groom roger[AT]RogerGroom.com
http://www.RogerGroom.com/
* Astronomy, Photography & Astro Photography

Date:  Wed, 01 Dec 2004 17:34:56 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: Comet image stacking experiment

Dave these look pretty good to me.You did a good job on the tail.
Rick

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "d_kodama" wrote:
>
> Along with my previously posted image of C/2004 Q2 (Machholz), I
took
> two additional images right after it. Here I've hand-stacked the
> other two in an attempt to bring out more of the tails, but I don't
> know if it really does much and is worth the effort. Since these
are
> film images, it takes a considerable effort to hand-stack the images
> due to the possibility of non-linear warping of the film during
> imaging and/or scanning, expecially over the area of a medium format
> image. In fact, the resulting stack here is far from perfect even
> though it is a crop of the original frames.
>
> Stack:
> Single:
>
> Let me know what you think anything is really gained out of a film
> stack. Thanks.
>
> Dave 

Date:  Thu, 02 Dec 2004 02:04:11 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comets T3 & Q1-12022004

Just got these off the chip. Still a lot of moisture in the air but
no Moon yet. C/2003 T4 is slowly growing it's tail and C/2004 Q1 is
nice and straight up at dark. Both images are 74x56 arc-min in fov
and contain 5x40 sec exp. 4" and ST2KXM ccd. time was 0111ut
12022004. Thanks, Mike H.

C/2003 T4
http://www.fototime.com/72A03820EEF2A47/orig.jpg

C/2004 Q1
http://www.fototime.com/52F8623A7E15478/orig.jpg

Hello,

a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /Mike Begbie/2004Q2_301104_mjb_pos_telbino.jpg
Uploaded by : mjbcomets
Description : Binocular and telescopic sketches of 2004 Q2 Machholz November 30th 2004

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Mike%20Begbie/2004Q2_301104_mjb_pos_telbino.jpg

http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Date:  Thu, 02 Dec 2004 21:33:22 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Comets T3 & Q1-12022004

Giovanni. The image is a composit of 5x40 second exp. The third of
five was logged with ccdops at 00:35:59 - 12/02/2004. I used the 4"
FSQ refractor at F5.3 - 530mm. The correct orentation would be N to
the left of the image and E down. I have the tail at 5.522' with a
PA of 351.6 deg. The camera is an ST2000XM and when used on the FSQ
gives a FOV of 74x56 arc-min. I have rotated the image and loaded it
at the link http://www.fototime.com/1104E2D2840B86E/orig.jpg for
viewing. The original files are FITS and as always I will provide
them to anyone who would like them. Hope this helps, Mike H.

Date:  Fri, 03 Dec 2004 06:53:20 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2004 Q2 - 12032004

Better put your Sunglasses on. This comet sits pretty low in the S/E
sky south of the Orion Neb in the worst sky for me. The comet has
made progress for sure. This is one of the three ways I have
combined the images to try and tone down the brighter portions
without losing tail structure. I will post more as time allows. FOV
74x56 arc min N is up. 3x120 sec exp. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/67CCFA10A16969A/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 03 Dec 2004 13:12:54 -0000
From:  gvnn64

small monster-scope.
Cheers,
Giovanni

post was an Add. All processed the same. Also a link to a color.
thank, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/BD83792EF0D04DC/orig.jpg
Average
http://fototime.com/EC4E1CEA7B4B2B2/orig.jpg

Date:  Tue, 07 Dec 2004 12:35:23 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  C/2004Q2 through narrowband filters
Hello all,
yesterday night we imaged C/2004Q2 (Machholz) trhough narrowband filters centered at 513.5nm (C2 emission) and 645nm (dust continuum). I post the final result in the "photo" section of this m-l homepage, within the "Remanzacco Observatory" folder.

It's interesting to notice how the comet head morphology changes as seen with different filters: the C2 emissions (cleaned from dust contaminations) shows a very extended coma, with a relatively small gradient, while the dust coma is oriented differently and its gradient is very steep.

To be noticed also a nice spiral-like feature emanating from the central condensation, not visible in the C2 emission. In the latter there is some structure, but the signal is very weak.

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Observatory, Italy)

____________________________________________________________

Date:  Wed, 08 Dec 2004 16:52:06 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Comet Machholz inner coma
Hello all,
I upload in the "Photos" section (Remanzacco Observatory folder) a composit image about C/2004Q2 (Machholz) obtained on Dec. 6 and 7 from our observatyory. The panels show the evolution of the inner part of the coma as seen through a narrowband interference filter centered on the dust continuum (645nm, FWHM 10nm).

The structures are evidenced:
1) subtracting from the original image a model of the coma (obtained with the canonical 1/r power law); what is left are brighhtness dishomogeneouties of the coma (active areas)
2) subtracting from the original image a frame of the coma, obtained averaging the ADUs along the cometocentric radius

These two algorithms, developed by Martino Nicolini (Italian Comet Section, CARA) has demonstrated to be less invasive than the standard Larson-Sekanina radial filtering. They preserve the photometric properties of the original image and, moreover, they are less sensitives to the production of artefatcs.

In this instance, it's possible to see a kind of spiral structure emanating from the central condensation of the comet. A fountain-like feature is seen in the solar direction. The same structures are not seen in the C2 narrowband filter (centered @513.5nm, FWHM 10nm), so they are likely due (mainly) to dust. Blinking the images, there is evidence of a counterclockwise rotation/expansion of the spiral feature.

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Observatory, Italy)

____________________________________________________________
Libero ADSL: 3 mesi gratis e navighi a 1.2 Mega, senza costi di attivazione.
Abbonati subito su http://www.libero.it

Date:  Wed, 08 Dec 2004 21:14:00 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Q2-A Feather look

In books and drawings of comets through history I have always been
amazed at the amout of detail the artist drew. Chinese drawings
especially. The thing I never really saw was a comparson to any
comets I have seen. The fine detail just behind the brighter parts
being depicted some looking like feathers . Look at this image of
Machholz. Back up, squint your eyes or adjust your monitor to see
what this image shows before the tail trailing splits into. It is
very faint but I am pretty sure the feather look is here. Of course
I might be nuts!.. Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/C326EE885A6E465/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 08 Dec 2004 23:32:33 +0200
From:  Mike Begbie 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Q2-A Feather look
No Mike

You are not nuts...I'm copying to astrosketch here. The value of visual observations cannot be disregarded even in this modern electronic age...The human eye is an amazing tool over a massive range. Fantastic image, well done! I have had six nights of rain...going Cold turkey on this comet now! Keep up the good work, and sketchers get out there...heads up, this is a GOODIE!

Regards

Mike Begbie

Yes they do, but I needed to train the mount for small errors so I
just figured why waste sky time. If anyone is interested, I hooked
the ST2KXM to a 135mm nikon lense and took 2x180 second images.
You are correct, the addictive part is there. To have images
without star movement is nice but I cannot allow the ease to overcome
the detail which I am after. Thanks for the reminder. Mike H. 

Date:  Sat, 11 Dec 2004 11:40:36 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  how to get started earning the AL comet awards
Amateurs astronomers who are members of the Astronomical League (either a
member or are members through another society in the US or abroad) are welcome
to earn a Silver and Gold award Comet Observers Awared certificate for their
observations and data recorded concerning comets.

To get started with the comet award
photograph with camera or CCD or illustrate or a combination of those
record data about each comet
(see sample page and print out at <
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm>)

(1) Silver award (you get the our cool AL comet award pin and the silver
certificate with Hale-Bopp comet which makes a nice certicate to frame). You need
to gain 12 comets. 2 can be gained before Jan 2001. The rest for the silver
need to be after 2001.

(2) You can illustrate the comets (there are sketch models on the comet award
page), or use CCD or camera pictures or mix and match . Images can be placed
on a CD, website or mix and match. You can do these with binoculars, big
scopes, naked eye or mix and match.

(3) Once you are ready for the award (have 12 comets) put the list down on
the comet page and send to me.

Dr. Eric Flescher ( kcstarguy@aol.com),
15016 W150th St., Olathe, KS 66062 (913-780-5902-home)

(4) the Gold award requires 18 comets beyond the silver 12. OF these 2 can be
before 2001.

(5) Illustrations and sample pics of my silver observations are on my page
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward.htm

(6) Also for the benefit of anyone, I have a email comet newsletter that goes
out usually ever two weeks or so. This contains the latest comet news,
observations by others from all over the world. There is also constantly updates of
new sites where you can see comet start charts, comet finding information much
with the internet links.
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

If you have any questions, feel free to email me.
Happy comet observering and hunting

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
member, ASKC-Astronomical Society of Kansas City,
Olathe, KS. USA,
JPL / NASA Solar System Ambassador, Kansas:
Comets Award Coordinator, Astronomical League,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm,
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward.htm> or
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

Date:  Sun, 12 Dec 2004 16:52:56 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2004 Q2 - 12122004

An image from early this morning UT. Info is on the picture. Has
any one noticed this comet not being at the cordinates. According to
Guide 8 and compairing it with my image (linked below), this comet is
about 13.5 arc-min S/E of where it should be.
The reason I ask is Steve Cox contact me last night and after a
year or so of not being on his scope he is now going to image faint
comets again. His 12" and ccd have a small fov and he was having a
problem placing the comet on the chip. Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/7316D81F9F7A2FE/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 12 Dec 2004 18:11:58 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
> Giovanni. Good work. How do you like the DSLR? Also did you notice
> a decline in the brightness of the tail which is pointing to the N.
> If so could this be due to position of the comet and will the dust
> tail become more prominant for the next few days as we view it? Mike

Thanks Mike. Well, the DSLR are nice for this kind of images: they have large chips, and you obtain the color image with only one shot. The drawback is that they are not cooled, so normally you are forced to stack a large amount of frames in order to reduce the noise. I also found that if you don't have a large computer RAM (mine is 256Mb "only"), it will take a long time for the image processing: I took the original frames in raw format, and transforming them into FIT (for treatment with Astroart), pumped they size to 32Mb. So I spent almost whole this Sunday afternoon just to substract the darks and combine them into an average final image. It's likely that Santa will be asked for some more RAM by the udersigned...

About the tail brightness decline: I think that this is due to, at least, a couple of reasons: i) some vignetting of the telephoto lens, ii) a real decline in the tail brightness.
The dust tail development: during next weeks we have the perihelium passage and the phase angle of comet Machholz should increase, so it's likely that we will see a nice development of the dust tail. Also the ion tail, already impressive, should became more prominent. Prepare your wide field lens...
Cheers,
Giovanni

____________________________________________________________
Libero ADSL: 3 mesi gratis e navighi a 1.2 Mega, senza costi di attivazione.
Abbonati subito su http://www.libero.it

Description : Narrow field Machholz

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Remanzacco%20Observatory/CC004Q2_11dec04_Sos_Mk69.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

gvnn64 

Date:  Sun, 12 Dec 2004 20:22:54 -0000
From:  twade35 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 Q2 - 12122004

> Has any one noticed this comet not being at the cordinates.
> According to Guide 8 and compairing it with my image (linked
> below), this comet is about 13.5 arc-min S/E of where it should be.

I don't have Guide 8; however, the following link is the latest
coordinates for the comet:

http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/2004Q2/2004Q2.html

I'm not sure if these are more accurate or not.

Wade

Date:  Mon, 13 Dec 2004 12:47:16 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Dec 12 - C/2004 Q2 & C/2003 K4

I have uploaded some recent images of C/2004 Q2 and 2003 K4 (and its
passage by Eta Carinae) to my web gallery at:

http://www.pbase.com/terrylovejoy/recent

Note the length of tail on Q2 (remember the field of view is about 12-
13 degrees high).

Terry

Date:  Mon, 13 Dec 2004 12:31:59 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet C2004Q2 Machholz 12122004-0627UT
Comet C2004Q2 Machholz 12122004 0627UT

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/C2004Q2-12122004-0627UT-f10-9x30sec-Bin3x3.JPG
or
http://makeashorterlink.com/?Q1B33240A

12" Meade 200LX-GPS f/10
ST-2000 XCM
9 x 30 sec
binned 3x3

Image flipped for comparison with STScI Digitized Sky
Survey image:
http://stdatu.stsci.edu/cgi-bin/dss_search?v=poss2ukstu&r=4+35+35&d=-20+05+11&e=J2000&h=15.0&w=15.0&f=gif&c=none&fov=NONE&v3=

or
http://makeashorterlink.com/?M6A32240A

What is nice about this comet is that it is so bright
you can easily see it in your finder scope!

This is my first comet image.

=====
Charles Bell
Vicksburg, Mississippi USA
32 15' 56" N 90 51' 20" W
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/ 

Date:  Mon, 13 Dec 2004 21:53:13 -0000

this is your your first picture, you could be in for the long haul.
Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 15 Dec 2004 09:42:36 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C/2004-Q2 Machholz 12152004-0739UT
C/2004-Q2 Machholz 12152004-0739UT

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/C2004Q2-Machholz-12152004-0739UT.JPG

MiniBorg 60 f/5.4
ST-2000 XCM
Mounted on Meade 12" 200LX-GPS

6 x 90 secs
Binned 1x1
FOV = 124 arc min x 93 arc min

32 15' 59"N, 90 51' 22"W
Vicksburg, Mississippi
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com

=====
Charles Bell
Vicksburg, Mississippi USA
32 15' 56" N 90 51' 20" W
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/ 

Date:  Wed, 15 Dec 2004 20:09:30 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  First light at the Campocatino Austral Observatory: C/2004 Q2 movie
Dear All,
I'm pleased to introduce the first light images of the Campocatino Austral
Observatory (CAO) telescope, a 0.5-f/3 fully robotic instrument that our team
has recently installed in Chile, not-too-far from San Pedro de Atacama, under
one the best skies in the world.

It is hosted at the SPACE (www.spaceobs.com) facility and its current setup
provides a 1-square-degree FOV, suited for NEO searches from the south and for
wide field imaging. The OTA, mounted on a Software Bisque's Paramount ME, is
equipped with an Apogee AP8p CCD camera. Its MPC code is I10.

These nights Gianluca Masi, Franco Mallia (Campo Catino Observatory, Italy) and
Alain Maury (Gene Shomeaker Observatory and SPACE owner, Chile) had the first
light with this telescope, choosing as target the comet C/2004 Q2 (Machholz).
This nice object was imaged more than 260 times over ~3.5 hours, to make both a
movie and a still image. In the former, we have been able to beautifully record
the evolution of the ion tail, so it is worth to check.

The images are visible here:
http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/c2004q2c2004r2.html

Please note that the official page will be this one:
http://www.campocatinobservatory.org/c2004q2c2004r2oac.html
as soon as I will have fixed some server problems.

In the latter site we will also present our instrument in more details (at the
moment, only a short description in Italian is available).

Thank you for your attention and clear skies,

Gianluca Masi
on the behalf of Campocatino Astronomical Observatory

--
*********************************************************************
* Gianluca Masi "Two things fill the soul *
* Via Madonna de Loco, 47 with awe and reverence [...]: *
* 03023 Ceccano (FR) the starry sky above me and *
* ITALY the moral law within me" *
* e-mail: gianluca@bellatrixobservatory.org *
* Bellatrix Astronomical Observatory I. Kant *
* web: http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org *
* Minor Planet Center Obs. Code: 470 - Ceccano *
* Center for Backyard Astrophysics - Italy *
* VSNET Collaboration Team member *
* CCD-astrometry-photometry@yahoogroups.com mailing-list moderator *
********************************************************************** 

Date:  Wed, 15 Dec 2004 20:42:35 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2004 Q2-12152004-When A work Goes Bad.

The sky was at a premium of 8 of 10 for me. This comet still sits in
the light poluted sky to my S/E but sence I can't move it I try to
correct the bad gradients other problems which are caused. This
image is a mosaic of 5 images each containing 5x60 sec subframes.
The comet is moving faster and to gain detail in the tail I selected
this number of exp. I thought everything was going good untill I
transfered the files to my processing computer and after realized I
completly missed a part of the sky. I did't spend more time on it
except to turn it negative and go for tail. Look at the jumbled mess
at about 2 deg. out (comet covers a little over 3 deg in this
image). I don't know if this was a disruption which is traveling
down the tail or if this is just what happens at this distance.
There does seem to be some straighter streamers behind this but I
don't know. I reduced the image by 2/3s. 4" FSQ & ST2KXM CCD

Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/204541944904832/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 15 Dec 2004 21:00:31 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 Q2-12152004-When A work Goes Bad.

Here is the same image at 1600 pix tall and 650kb but much clearer.
http://fototime.com/CDB11D1CDD2C6F2/orig.jpg

Hello,

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 16 Dec 2004 09:13:53 -0800
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Macholz on "12/14" & "12/15" from Hungry Valley, CA (USA)
I went out on evenings of 12/14 & 12/15 (photographed the comet in the
adjacent morning):

http://www.comet-track.com/macholz/macholz.html

I believe my shot on "12/14", taken @3:00am PST on 12/15 (corresponds to
~11:00UT 12/15) is roughly the same time-frame of Gerald Rhemann's shot
on 12/15 20.xx UT(See post below). His was taken slightly later, about
8 hrs later.

Note how the tail had changed 24 hrs later, from my locality (see above
website). The ion tail on "12/14" had multiple ion-streamers, in a
fan-like appearance. (Mike Hollaway mentioned the Chinese
interpretation as "broom"). 24 hrs later, on "12/15", the ion-tail
returned to a straight "dagger-like" form.

Very interesting.. The ion tail is showing some very dynamic behavior,
temporal (day to day) variation.

Gerald Rhemann wrote:

> Hi all again!
>
> This is one of our results from yesterday evening:
>
> ttp://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/aufnahme.php?a_id=334&page=1&kategorie=&k_id=39

> A gif-animation will follow as soon as possible!

> Gerald and Michael

Date:  Thu, 16 Dec 2004 09:18:22 -0800
From:  B Yen 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Macholz on "12/14" & "12/15" from Hungry Valley, CA (USA)
Here are the 2 comparison images from 12/15 20.xx UT (mine from Hungry
Valley, CA) & 15.12.2004 UT 20h00m (G. Rhemann from Austria):

http://www.comet-track.com/macholz/1214/31zoomproc.jpg
http://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/aufnahme.php?a_id=334&page=1&kategorie=&k_id=39

They look similar. Mine is shot with TP2415 @300mm FL (8" f1.5 Schmidt
Camera), G. Rhemann's is with longer FL (530mm fluorite refractor)..more
image scale than mine.

From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Wide shot of Comet Machholz (12/13)

This is a bit noisy, but here's a wide shot of Comet Machholz from
Monday evening. I thought it might be useful to someone to see the
extent and brightness of the tail relative to some familiar objects.
