Date:  Fri, 17 Dec 2004 05:49:03 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  My first comet image, Machholz!

I am posting an image of Comet Machholz. This is my fist comet
image. It was taken with an STL11k, FSQ 106, STV guider, and AP1200
mount. It was taken from Lockwood Valley, CA at approximately 11 PM.
http://home.earthlink.net/~rickwiggins/
I was imaging several other targets better suited to this OTA and
camera, but stopped between targets to have a go at the comet.
Exposures are one set of LRGB at 210 Secs. each and binned 3x3. More
exposure would really have helped, but I thought this was all the
time I could risk and not smear the comet too much. Comments and
critique encouraged.
Enjoy, Rick 

Date:  Fri, 17 Dec 2004 16:49:24 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Wide shot of Comet Machholz (12/13)

WOW Dave! When you said wide field---you meant wide field. What is
that green spot at the top right side? I didn't look to see if
there were anyother comets in the area. Mike H

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "d_kodama" wrote:
>
> This is a bit noisy, but here's a wide shot of Comet Machholz from
> Monday evening. I thought it might be useful to someone to see the
> extent and brightness of the tail relative to some familiar
objects.
>
> http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2004/1213a/5.htm
>
> Dave 

Date:  Fri, 17 Dec 2004 10:54:46 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Wide shot of Comet Machholz (12/13)

Clay

Date:  Fri, 17 Dec 2004 17:46:15 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Wide shot of Comet Machholz (12/13)

Mike,

Sorry about that green spot. That's the very edge of the film frame
and with this camera body, I sometimes get an odd reflection or two at
a few spots along the edge. I need to go back in there and crop it out.

Dave

It was a good night, but only on a relative scale for my location.
That yellow area at the bottom of the frame is the sky glow from San
Diego. Sadly, the professionals on nearby Palomar Mountain aren't
much better off...

Dave

From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Machholz Animation Again
Hi Mike!

Try it with our animation from Dec. 15:
http://www.astrostudio.at/common/anim/machholz.gif
If you have any problem with your browser to see a liquid movement please
move your mouse to the picture and click the right key and choose
charactaristics.

Gerald and Michael

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 10:12:47 +0100
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  Movements in the tails of Machholz
Hi all!

If you like to see movements in the tails of Machholz on Dec. 15, taken within 1 hour look at our animation (~900kb)
http://www.astrostudio.at/common/anim/machholz.gif

If you have any problem with your browser to see a liquid movement please
move your mouse to the picture and click the right key and choose
charactaristics.

Gerald and Michael

have a lot more detail in your raw images than this shows. DId you
track on the stars, or did you make this image from 2 sets of data
(one tracked on the comet and one tracked on the stars)?
Thanks, Rick

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 17:18:38 -0000
From:  grmok1 
Subject:  Re: New Image: Comet Machholz

Thanks, Rick,

I shoot from very light polluted skies, and while I could have
brought out a bit more of the tail, it would be at the expense of
added noise.

I shot 1x bin, 1 minute unguided, and tracked on the comets head. I
then stacked them, and yes, removed the tracked stars and replaced
them with a single one minute image taken from the last set.

I was trying a straight RGB, and there was just not enough data, so
I just made a luminence from the combined RGB, and then added the
RGB to it. Next time I'll just do a straight 1x L and should get a
bit more of the comet's tail.

Regards,
Gerald Miller

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Rick Wiggins"

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 17:41:19 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Q2 Machholz with a 1 Degree Tail

Our currently brightest comet has undergone significant changes in
the past week. I have captured a 1 degree long tail in my mosaic at

http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Finder chart and simulated eyepiece view is also provided  please
take a look.

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 11:21:09 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C2004Q2-Machholz-12182004-0716UT-6x60sec
C/2004-Q2 Machholz 12182004 0716UT
5x60sec aligned on comet head
Binned 2x2
minimal processing
ST2000 XCM CCD + Mini Borg60

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/C2004Q2-Machholz-12182004-0716UT-6x60sec.jpg

or

http://makeashorterlink.com/?H47225F0A

Tail appears much broader than several days ago.

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/C2004Q2-Machholz-12152004-0739UT.JPG
or
http://makeashorterlink.com/?S69212F0A

=====
Charles Bell
Vicksburg, Mississippi USA
32 15' 56" N 90 51' 20" W
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/ 

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 15:58:45 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  magnificent  shots
Dennis and all
The shots are magnificent. The whisp tail is very nice as well.
Machholz is a welcome surprise after the little disappointment regarding T7
and Q4 that did not rise to expectations.
I am still trying to make the comet stand out more with the tail and not make
more noise with the stars. I have tried levels, comparing/contrast etc.
Any suggestions?

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com),
member, ASKC-Astronomical Society of Kansas City,
Olathe, KS. USA,
JPL / NASA Solar System Ambassador, Kansas:
Comets Award Coordinator, Astronomical League,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/obsclub.html,
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm,
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/cometaward.htm> or
(send messages to the network at ) CometObserversAwardAL@yahoogroups.com;
Subscribe to have your name on the listserve by sending email to :
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 22:08:15 +0100
From:  waldemar skorupa 
Subject:  machholz DSLR images of 14th december
Hello,

I like the activity on the list. More and more images of this nice comet are
shared... thanks!

Norbert and me imaged comet Machholz on 14th December with Canon DSLRs. We
have a lot of problems getting the faint tail out of the surrounding
townlights.
Visit www.schweifstern.de to see the shots.

Greetings
Waldemar 

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 22:35:03 +0100

I think it might not only be the camera, but I also have a very nice and
dark rural sky, and there was no moon......

Mike

Date:  Sat, 18 Dec 2004 23:32:51 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Q2 - Dec 16.52 UT

My latest image of Q2 on December 16.52:

http://www.pbase.com/terrylovejoy/image/37557246

This one I have been struggling with a little trying to fix what I
though were 'light pollution gradients' and 'poor flat field'
calibration. It turns out this field may contain a very faint
dark/reflection nebula complex (note the broad dark lane up the
centre of the image) so I have presented the image 'as-is'. Although
conditions were very hazy with thin high cloud at times, I did have
the luxury of the comet at the zenith!

Terry 

Date:  Sun, 19 Dec 2004 01:05:51 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Comet C2004Q2, disconection of ion tail
To the address: http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2004Q2_135_041218.jpg

I have inserted an image of this evening where a great is seen disconection of the ion
tail. obb135mm f3,5 ccd SXVH9 10x150sec

Regards

Rolando Ligustri
===============================
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete

Date:  Sun, 19 Dec 2004 15:38:12 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images


Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /Remanzacco Observatory/9P_19dec04_sos.jpg
Uploaded by : gvnn64
Description : Comet 9P/Tempel

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Remanzacco%20Observatory/9P_19dec04_sos.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

gvnn64

> Date: Sat, 18 Dec 2004 23:32:51 -0000
>    From: "terryjlovejoy"
> Subject: Q2 - Dec 16.52 UT
>
> My latest image of Q2 on December 16.52:
>
> http://www.pbase.com/terrylovejoy/image/37557246
>
> This one I have been struggling with a little trying to fix what I
> though were 'light pollution gradients' and 'poor flat field'
> calibration.  It turns out this field may contain a very faint
> dark/reflection nebula complex (note the broad dark lane up the
> centre of the image) so I have presented the image 'as-is'.  Although
> conditions were very hazy with thin high cloud at times, I did have
> the luxury of the comet at the zenith!
>
> Terry

Date:  Sun, 19 Dec 2004 17:30:56 -0000
From:  Rick Wiggins 
Subject:  Re: machholz DSLR images of 14th december

Waldemar,
Your images are about as good as any I have seen. I do have a couple
of suggestions. Try posting a direct link in your post, instaed of
making viewers click through your web pages. Your image does not
show any signs of light pollution. The only thing that I can see
that would improve them, would be longer exposure or a higher QE
camera. Your images are spectacular!
Rick

Date:  Sun, 19 Dec 2004 19:01:48 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Comet 9P/Tempel
> How bright- magnitude do think it is in the image. congrats

Hello,
it's pretty faint: my measure gives a magnitude of 17.6 in the Cousins R band (accuracy is estimated to be of the order of +/- 0.4magn)
Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero (Remanzacco Obsvervatory, Italy)

Date:  Sun, 19 Dec 2004 20:08:22 -0000
From:  Mark S Deprest 
Subject:  New Member and New Image

Hello All,
I am an avid comet observer, and although most of my observations are
visual, I just received the Meade Deep Sky Imager and coupled with my
5" f/5 homenuilt refractor I hope do begin imaging all of my visually
observed comets. I am creating an album on this site to showcase my
work, however I am new to CCD imaging and could use any suggestions
on improving my efforts that this group may have. My first image is
of C/2004 Q2 Machholz taken on 12/17/04 at 23:00 EST. You can find it
posted in the Photos - file - MSDeprest. The only processing I have
done to the image is to convert it to grayscale. It is a composite of
10 - 4sec exposures autostacked with the supplied software from the
Meade DSI. All constructive comments are welcome.
Mark S Deprest
University Lowbrow Astronomers
Astronomical League
American Association of Amateur Astronomers
Association of Lunar & Planetary Observers

Date:  Mon, 20 Dec 2004 12:17:50 -0000
From:  terryjlovejoy 
Subject:  Re: K4 and Machholz wide film shots

Kearn,

Waldermar left a note on my webpage identifying the 'mystery nebula'
as LBN 981. I can definitely see it on your images as well -
especially when I put it through a contrast stretch.

Machholz is certainly showing a lot of tail variability from night to
night - worth following through the moon period I think. Last night
the tail seemed quite weak, but have look at this photo I found from
the previous night (not mine):

http://www.astroarts.jp/gallery/comet/c2004q2/gallery/041220arai1.jpg

Terry 

Date:  Tue, 21 Dec 2004 00:44:28 +1030

takers in Japan are truly sincerely Amazing!

And an interesting object LBN 981 is - weird how Q2's ion tail keeps kind of
pointing to it!

Cheers
Kearn

Date:  Mon, 20 Dec 2004 15:56:05 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C/2004 U1 12/20/2004 0432 to 0537 UT
C/2004 U1 12/20/2004 0432 to 0537 UT
Magnitude 16.5 accordng to The Sky

The following image is a composite of the aligned
frames to show the faint trail left by the moving
comet (No processing):
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/C2004U1-12212004-0537UT-Trail.JPG

The following image is a composite of the frames
aligned on the centroids of the comet body in each
image using CCDSoft (back ground stars trail off):
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/C2004U1-12212004-0537UT.JPG

Used 41 best of 60 frames (60 secs. exposure each)
41 x 60 secs
ST-2000 XCM + MiniBorg60
Meade 12inch 200LX-GPS

32 15' 59"N, 90 51' 22"W
Vicksburg, Mississippi

=====
Charles Bell
Vicksburg, Mississippi USA
32 15' 56" N 90 51' 20" W
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/ 

Date:  Tue, 21 Dec 2004 03:49:14 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2004 Q2 - 12212004-0214UT

Terry was correct to keep tabs on this comet. The Moon makes it
tough. A 3-part mosaic. Info on the original with 2 file sizes for
the original and the negative. I don't know a lot about these things
but it would appear this comet is the prime target for a class on
anti-tails if this is what is happening. Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/6E1D9D0D1BAF599/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/6E1D9D0D1BAF599/orig.jpg

Date:  Fri, 24 Dec 2004 12:02:26 +1300
From:  John_Drummond 
Subject:  K4 hits the Running Man
Hi all,

just a reminder that on Christmas night Comet LINEAR (C/2003 K4) will be very close (within half a degree) from NGC 2516 (the 'Running Man' cluster) in Carina.

I imaged the comet in this field last night and added where the comet will lay in the next two nights. Also attached is a wider field showing the comet and the False Cross...

Currently the comet is fading and is about mag 7 - 8ish.

Comet and NGC 2516 -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2003k4-comet_linear-041223-1x-30sec@800asa-280mmfl-f2,8-text2.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/4ypx3

Comet and False Cross -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2003k4-comet_linear-false_cross-041223-1x-30sec@800asa-112mmfl-f2,8-text.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/6fwue

Let's ask Santa for a fine night...

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 24 Dec 2004 00:20:01 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
> Wow
> Is the black dot in the middle the actual nucleus?
> Dr. Eric Flescher ( kcstarguy@aol.com),

Hello, thanks for your mail. The answer is no: normally any cometary nucleus is too small to be resolved by ground base instrumentation. For a few istances, there is some evidence (suspects?) of nucleus resolution using the HST.
The black dot in my image is due to an artefact of the algorithm I used to evidence any deviation from the theoretical 1/r model: its presence means that for the regions much close to the nucleus, the 1/r model doesn't work.
Cheers,
Giovanni

____________________________________________________________
Regala e regalati Libero ADSL: 3 mesi gratis e navighi veloce. 1.2 Mega di musica, film, video e sport.
Abbonati subito senza costi di attivazione su http://www.libero.it

Date:  Fri, 24 Dec 2004 10:23:54 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Three Galaxies and a comet - M65, M66, NGC 3628, plus Comet 62P-Tsuchinshan
Comet 62P-Tsuchinshan passed just to the south of
three bright galaxies in Leo the morning of December
15, 2004. I caught all four objects in the same field
of view of this image:

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/M65-M66-NGC3628-62PTsuchinshan-12152004-1118UT.JPG

or

http://makeashorterlink.com/?H2484291A

In the composite image, comet 62P-Tsuchinshan is in
the lower left. Included is the cropped region around
the comet aligned on the comet body which showed its
movement over a thirty minute period. M65 is near
center, M66 above center, and NGC3628 in upper right.
North is to the right and east up due to the piggy
back arrnagement.

These were combined from thirty 60 second frames taken
with SBIG ST-2000 XCM + MiniBorg-60 (A=60 mm, FL=325
mm FR=f/5.4)

The field of view FOV is approximately 124 arc min x
93.35 arc min.

When I first combined the images with CCDSoft, a
fourth fuzzy region was noted which I first thought
was another galaxy. The next day, curiosity led me to
discover that the fuzzy region did not correspond to
anything that was supposed to be there when comparing
the image with DSS images of the region. I thought I
may have happened upon a new comet, but that was not
to be. After going through the list of observable
comets and comet charts from Reinder J. Bouma and
Edwin van Dijk comet website
(http://www.shopplaza.nl/astro/) (and thank you
again), the fuzzy object turned out to be comet
62P-Tsuchinshan. I was happy that I finally resolved
what I had observed, but reluctantly dissappointed
that I had not made a discovery. It was a big exciting
discovery for me though!

I may be a total neophyte green horn, but I have a
functional CCD camera/fast telescope combination for
hunting comets.

This is my Christmas present from the big guy up there
who made all this stuff. I am very happy about it.

Merry Christmas to all of you. Best wishes for the
holidays and the coming new year.

=====
Charles Bell
Vicksburg, Mississippi USA
32 15' 56" N 90 51' 20" W
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/ 

Date:  Fri, 24 Dec 2004 12:26:39 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 U1 12/20/2004 0432 to 0537 UT
Inside the circle, its a blur because it has moved
over thirty minutes. Inside the little box, you see
the little dot that did NOT move while everything else
did (and trailed). That's the comet.

This was just a cropped portion of a stack of images
aligned on the comet centroid.

If you have a ccd camera, just stack a bunch of images
covering the area of sky where a comet is, and then
align and stack, you can find the comet as either the
blur or the end of any line of dots.

I think a reasonable CCD camera exposed for 60 seconds
will show a trace of a magnitude 15 to 16 comet. I am
guessing that two minutes per shot will may reach mag
18. (I am not completely sure about these numbers, but
I think they are in the ballpark.)

This way you can see a comet electronically, when you
can't see it in an eyepiece.

Detective work!!

I have some more images of the comet area that are
stacked and aligned on the comet head:

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/62P/AlignedOnCometHead.JPG

All thirty images are in the web folder at:
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/62P/12152004/

I put up an image player web page at:
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/62P/62P-12152004.html

You can see what I was seeing on all those 30 jpg
files. The little blur distinctly moves in each frame.
I named the frames with the exact time to the second
of each image.

Date:  Sat, 25 Dec 2004 20:25:25 -0000

Subject:  Comet 78P Gehrels  2nd Brightest in the Sky

The current rage is Q2 Machholz but I chose to image 78P Gehrels. It
is the 2nd brightest comet in the sky now at magnitude 10.7 .

Finder chart, isophotes, image and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Sun, 26 Dec 2004 20:07:30 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 Q4 Anti-TAILS not Tail

The two frame mosaic is a composit of 7 images each with a total time
of 14 minutes of imaging. The middle of this time was logged at
0436UT 12/26/2004 by CCDops. Her is a link to this image and a
negative for better detail (both reduced).

http://fototime.com/6BE2C8CF9D3D756/orig.jpg

http://fototime.com/D7E4A514F9CB646/orig.jpg

My session actually began earlier in the evening at 0110UT at which
time I took this image and lost interest with the extreme Moon and
low quality.

http://fototime.com/FD174344778909E/orig.jpg

Only later after imaging comet 78p and some other objects did I
return for a last look. It was a whole new ballgame. Hope this
helps, Mike H.

each image is 70x54 arc-min FOV. 4" refractor at F5.3 and a ST2000XM
CCD

Date:  Mon, 27 Dec 2004 15:54:59 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Anti-tail definition

>From JPL.

Comet Definitions

The following are generally accepted definitions for terms related
to cometary astronomy.

anti-tail or anomalous tail

When a comet's tail appears to be pointing toward the Sun, this is
called an anti-tail or anomalous tail. In reality, the tail only
appears to be pointing toward the Sun. To get an anti-tail, the
comet must produce large ("heavy") dust particles. If this happens,
these particles are left along the comet's orbit instead of being
pushed away from the Sun and the comet's orbit by light pressure.
Often dusty comets will produce particules of different sizes
creating a fan-shaped appearance. The smallest dust will be pushed
directly away from the Sun (like the gas tail) and the largest will
be left in the comet's orbit. When a comet is close to the Sun, the
angle of this fan can be 90 degrees or larger. If the Earth-comet-
Sun geometry is correct, the dust in the comet's orbit will appear
to point toward the Sun. [Try this...make a right (90 degree) angle
with your thumb and index finger. Your index finger is the main tail
and your thumb is the dust left in the comet's orbit. Point your
finger and thumb directly away from you (keeping the angle 90
degrees). Your finger seems to be going in exactly the opposite
direct from the thumb. This is what causes an anti-tail.] 

Date:  Mon, 27 Dec 2004 18:28:43 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2004 Q4 Anti-TAILS not Tail
Hi Mike, for me,
You have photographed an anti-tail of dust, an anti-tail that had been
foreseen also already in other mail of some days ago.

If you are able, it is better to direct always your good images with the North aloft, and
East to the left, so one is able more easily to check the image with the own sw.

Best Regards

Rolando

Hi Terry,
You've captured a nice long tail. I'm constantly amazed by how sensitive
the 300D is! Well processed too.

Coincidentally, I imaged the comet at exactly the same time last night,
but at a longer focal length (200mm).
See http://www.tip.net.au/~vello/2004q2/20041228.jpg for the inner coma
detail. The gaps in the star trials are from excluding images that
contained satellite trails (15 of the 29 original 60 sec images were
discarded!)

Cheers,
Vello
